Good Stuff - I did follow the advice of other reviewers:  1.  Sauted the onion 2.  Use seasoned bread crumbs 3.  Doubled the ketchup mixture and reduced the amount of mustard a tad 4.  1 tbsp Worstishire in the meat mix 5.  Line the pan with foil for easy clean up 6.  LET THE MEAT REST before slicing.  Served it with Paula Deens Cottage Potato's and steamed vegetables. No complaints from the boys who were over for dinner.   Went down well with a 2004 Pinot Noir. Will make this again.

text:
This was a great recipe.  I compiled and followed all of the advice of previous reviewers: 
 
-I lightly browned the onions in butter before adding.  
-I also added chopped green onions, mushrooms, and a green bell pepper. 
-I used italian seasoned breadcrumbs.  
-I tripled the sauce (many said that there was not enough sauce/topping) and 
-I baked for longer than the recipe states (I baked for a total of one hour and 25 minutes).  

It came out perfectly.  Thanks for the great recipe, and reviewers thanks for the great hints/amendments!

text:
I have tried some more "exotic" meatloaf recipes on this site which have turned out quite good, but my husband wanted more of a basic meatloaf so that it would be good on a sandwich the next day.  I chose this recipe based on the high marks and the easy ingredients.  I substituted ground turkey for the beef, and followed the "most helpful" suggestions of sauteeing the onions in butter + garlic, and adding 1 Tbsp. of worchestshire to the meat mix.  Other than that, followed the recipe completely, and it was wonderful!!!  Very tasty and moist (one thing I can't stand is a dry meatloaf, not this one!) and I have a feeling it will make great meatloaf sandwiches tomorrow.  Thanks for the post!

text:
I made this recipe and altered it according to previous reviews:  1) I added Worcestershire Sauce 2)didn't have any fresh onion so I used minced 3)added garlic powder 4) added 1 slice of bread ripped into pieces since it seemed too wet when mixing 5)used a glass baking dish 6)doubled the topping 7)used seasoned bread crumbs.  A 1.30# of meat cooked in an hour.  This turned out great and we went back for seconds even when my man is sick and said he wasn't hungry!  I personally thought the topping was a tad too sweet so I would do everything the same next time except reduce the brown sugar some.  This was very easy and a big hit.  Will definitely make again and again!!!

YUMMY!!! Made this dish for company the other night and WOW! It was a BIG hit! My 6 yr old had 2 huge pieces and my hubby even had leftovers for breakfast the next morning while we were all still sleeping! I used 2-1/4lbs. of ground beef, kept the 1 onion(1 of my guests is not a big onion fan), 2 eggs, 1-1/2 cups of both milk and SEASONED breadcrumbs, threw in some garlic powder and parsley flakes and doubled the ketchup mixture. Seasoned breadcrumbs are a must for this recipe; Would be very bland without them. Thanks for the great recipe! :)

text:
Hands down, this was the best meatloaf that I've ever made.  I used about 2.3 lbs. of ground beef.  

Following some of the advice of others as well as adding a few of my own tweaks, the meatloaf was perfect.  

Here's what I did:

1.  I sautéed finely chopped onion, 3 cloves (minced garlic) & 2 stalks of celery in butter (which really makes the loaf tender); then added it to the ground beef.

2.  I added 2 teaspoons of Worcestershire sauce to the ground beef mixture along with 2 eggs instead of 1, 1 1/4 cup of milk & about 1 1/2 cup of dried Italian bread crumbs.

3.  For the sauce:  I initially made it as the directions indicated with 2 TBSP. of brown sugar, and found it to be way too sweet.  I then added 1/3 more ketchup and a couple of dashes of Worcestershire Sauce and it was perfect.

4.  It was an abundance of sauce, and a lot of the other reviews said that there wasn't enough sauce, so I spooned a thin layer at the bottom of the loaf, molded half the loaf, then sauced the top, and then added the rest of the loaf on top and sauced it really well.  This was absolutely perfect.  

5.  Lastly, there was no specification on whether or not to cook the meatloaf covered or uncovered.  I used enough aluminum foil to line the baking dish as well as cover the top (so I essentially wrapped the loaf in foil) and cooked covered for 45 minutes, drained most of any accumulated liquid and cooked uncovered for an additional 30 minutes.

This was super moist and delicious!!!!!

Don't be discouraged by the unimaginative ingredient list.  I made this recipe exactly as instructed, adding some worcestershire to taste, but I think it would be fine without it.  The raw onions give a perfect crunch, I would not pre cook them. The flavor punch comes from the perfect sauce, my family loved it. I look for good meat loaf recipes like I look for the perfect purse. And this is IT for me.  It would be good to use it as a base for adding whatever else you wanted, but I don't want to mess with a good thing. This is IT for all you cooks.

text:
Absolutely love this recipe! It was so easy to make and so delicious!! My boyfriend and I both had seconds it was so good. I did some altering to the recipe, which I thought made it even better. I listened to the other reviewers and sauteed the onions in a little butter and garlic powder. I also did half a cup of crushed Ritz crackers and half a cup of Italian Seasoned bread crumbs. I added a 1oz packet of Hidden Valley Ranch seasoning for flavor. For the topping I did 1/3 cup ketchup, 1/3 cup sweet baby rays bbq sauce and 1 tbs regular mustard. I had bbq sauce on meatloaf at a really nice restaurant and it gave me the idea, the combination is perfect!!!

text:
Almost identical to the Ranch House Meat Loaf recipe I use.  I use 2 lbs gr. beef, 1 cup cracker crumbs instead of bread crumbs (trust me it is better), 2 eggs, 1/2 cup onion, 3/4 of 10 oz. can of beef broth (instead of milk), 1 tsp. sage, 1 tsp. thyme and 1/4 tsp. pepper.  For topping: 3 tbsp. brown sugar, 4 tbsp. ketchup and 1 tsp. dry mustard.  Bake meatloaf at 325 for 1 1/4 hours.  Remove from pan and place on plate (this gets the meatloaf out of the grease for the final cooking).  Put topping on meatloaf and return to oven for additional 30 minutes.  DELICIOUS!!!!

text:
This meatloaf was great! I did as some of the other reviewers did, I tweaked a few items. B 4 cooking I read some reviews about the meat being too mushy. The trick to solve this problem is to put two slices of bread in the bottom of the pan before the meatloaf. Also, use 1 packet of Lipton's onion soup instead of real onions. And to give the meat a nice flavor, use 1 tblspn of Worstcestershire sauce. Instead of using 1 cup of milk, use 1/4 cup. My family loves a more firm meatloaf and this was perfect. After dinner, my hubby fell right to sleep! :-) Guess that's what GOOD comfort food does to ya.

text:
This is a great, classic meatloaf, and the topping mixture is delicious! However, using all ground beef resulted in a very dense and sort of chewy meatloaf. I would advise using a "meatloaf mix" of either beef & pork or beef, pork and lamb. Many grocery stores sell a mix like this already pre-packaged, but you can always just buy them separately and mix them together. I used such a mix when I made this for the second time, and it resulted in a meatloaf that was moist and had a more pleasing texture. I did add about 15 minutes to the baking time. Other than that, I loved it and will make it again!

text:
Very tasty meatloaf but came out really mushy for me because I didn't let it sit long enough after it came out of the oven.  It needs to sit for at LEAST 10 minutes, this definitely should be in the directions.  I took other reviewers advice and did the following: 1) added garlic powder and worcestershire sauce to the meat mixture.  2)  Used less brown sugar in the topping mixture (probably more like 1 tbsp of sugar).  I also used crushed white cheddar Cheese-Its instead of breadcrumbs, gives it a nice cheesy flavor.    Some reviews say to double the amount of topping, which is true, it does need more, but I would suggest reserving some of the sauce and warming it up at very low heat in a saucepan.  Then, drizzle over the meatloaf after you slice and plate it.  Yummy sauce!

text:
This was very good!  I read through the reviews and took a few tips and added some of my own. First, I used ground chuck (80/20). It had a wonderful flavor and consistency. I think ground beef would be mushy and ground sirloin might turn out too chewy so watch that. Ground Round would work ok too.  I minced my onions very fine and they were great. I did add several splashes of woscheshire and some garlic powder to the mix.  I doubled the sauce (but not the sugar) and I thought it was fantastic. I baked this in a foiled lined glass dish that was round and I poked a hole in the middle of the raw meatloaf with the end of a wooden spoon  before the sauce went on to facilitate even cooking.   I cooked it for 1 1/2 hours on 350, took it out of the oven, drained away some of the fat that collected and then most importantly I tented it with foil and let it rest for 10 mins before slicing into it. You have to let the meat juices redistribute so resting is an important step. Also, the temp of the meat continues to rise another 5-10 degrees so you know your food is properly cooked. So what I ended up with was a moist, succulent restaurant quality meatloaf that looked and sliced great and tasted even better. This is the ultimate comfort food. This recipe easily serves 4 and makes great left overs. Thanks everybody! Enjoy.

text:
I LOVE this recipe!  It tastes great and is easy.  

The only modifications that I made were to:

1) Leave out the ketchup
2) Put the brown sugar in with the meat and other ingredients (a mistake the turned out to be great)
3) Use BBQ sauce as a glaze 
4) Bake it in muffin cups

By baking it in muffin cups, we were able to get 12 servings out of it, which helps with portion control, because when I slice meatloaf, there's never enough for two meals.

Great recipe that I'd certainly recommend to others.

text:
I tried this several times to see if I could tweak the recipe to something less sweet/more solid. The basic meatloaf ingredients are right but the ketchup/sugar/mustard sauce is way too sweet even for someone with a sweet tooth. I doubled the ketchup as other reviewers suggested but I don't think you need to add any sugar to it. I reduced the milk to 3/4 cup which helped a lot, kept the bread crumbs at 1 cup. My only other suggestion is to maybe increase the ground beef to 2 lbs or find a really lean 90% and above ground beef so that the natural fat in it doesn't make it so greasy. If you want to use this recipe, I recommend leaving the sugar out and using lean ground beef.

text:
This is a very delicious, basic recipe. I would have given it 5 stars, but I made a few alterations which prevented it from being on the bland side. I added about a tablespoon or so of Worcestershire sauce (I just eyeballed it), used Italian seasoned breadcrumbs instead of plain, sautéed the onion with a few cloves of freshly minced garlic, added some fresh chopped parsley into the meatloaf, and I added about a tablespoon of BBQ sauce to the glaze just to give it a little more dimension. And for my tastes, I used a teaspoon each of salt and pepper (if anyone wondered how much should be recommended). Don't forget to double the sauce! **Also, here's a helpful tip on how to cook it. Free-form the loaves, and place them on a cookie cooling rack. Line a large cookie sheet/baking pan with foil, and place the cooling rack on top of the baking pan. This will allow the fat/drippings from the meatloaf to fall onto the bottom of the pan, so any draining/soaking will not be necessary.** The original recipe yields a pretty good meatloaf, very moist and with the right proportions...but the modifications made it even better! It was my first time making it, and I even made my grandma proud. :)

Ok! So I rarely write reviews but I felt like this little jewel deserved a mention. So I decided to surprise the boyfriend with something new BUT old. I searched through the net for a simple yet easy meatloaf recipe.. Well because I've never made meatloaf before!! I stumbled upon this, quickly went to the supermarket, got all necessary ingredients and dashed back to my kitchen to put it all together. ***I definitely followed what other users said about sautéing the onions and adding 3 average sized garlic cloves - well because I just love anything oniony & garlicky!!! I have it a generous 4-5 round sprinkles of worcestershire sauce. text:
I had mine in the oven when I started to read all the reviews and was getting a little worried because of all the people saying it took over 2 hours to cook, that is was all mushy, and people saying it was gross.  First of all, what did those people do wrong??  
I followed the directions perfectly and mine came out great.  The topping was very good, people were saying it was too sweet and it soaked into the loaf...mine didn't.
There could have been a little more flavor it in and next time I might add some sage or some garlic but other than that this was very good.  I cooked mine for about 1 hour and 5 minutes, the very middle was a light pink but it was still hot.  My husband microwaved that part for 30 seconds and it was fine.  The cook time should be about 1 hour and 15 minutes to cook the middle.
I also really liked it because the meatloaf my mom always made was very good and would melt in your mouth, this was very close to doing that.
After the load was done cooking, there was some grease in the pan which is bound to happen because it is beef.  I didn't do this but next time I will let it cool for a bit then try to drain some of that grease out before cutting and serving it.
Basically, I love this and so did my husband.  I don't know what the others who claimed it was soup when they mixed everything together did but if you follow everything correctly you should end up with a great dinner.
Oh, I also used crushed croutons instead of bread crumbs.


Great recipe!!!!

Four star with no topping. I've never understood meatloaf topping and don't care for it when I've had it. I don't know anybody who puts on a topping. We use gravy or Heinz 57 for dipping...no topping necessary and a tomatoey or BBQy type topping doesn't do well with gravy, which we have anyways for the mashed potatoes that go with the meatloaf.

Good flavor. Next time I'll add celery salt and replace the bread crumbs with oats. Oats make for a more moist meatloaf, always, in my opinion, when the loaf is made from all ground beef...not so dense.

country:

text:
This was pretty tasty.  I didn't follow the recipe exactly, because someone decided that the bowl of hamburger defrosting in the fridge was an invitation to make themselves a hamburger for lunch, but I think I was close enough to the original recipe's proportions to review it honestly.

I sauteed the onion and about a tablespoon of garlic in some olive oil and butter.  I ended up using 2/3c milk and 1 cup bread crumbs (Italian seasoned).  The sauce was too sweet and it wouldn't have been enough.  I ended up tripling the sauce and adjusting the ingredients (NOT triple the sugar.) to make up for it. I ended up with: 1 c ketchup, 3T brown sugar, 1 T mustard, 1tsp vinegar, 1 tsp hot sauce.  It was tangy and just a touch sweet.  Overall, a very solid meatloaf base.  And it was super moist.  

Next time, I'll probably use 2-3lbs of meat since it shrank quite a bit in my 8x8 dish.

text:
Easy, very moist & quite good. I only used the recipe as a guide & followed some other suggestions, such as using seasoned bread crumbs & adding worcestershire sauce...I also sauteed the onion with diced bell pepper & garlic (in a small bit of butter), then finally threw in a bit of italian sausage I had leftover from another meal. Since I doubled the recipe I baked it for 2 hours, adding the sauce (used 1/2 the brown sugar) the last 30 minutes only. I have no doubt this will make terrific sandwiches tomorrow.

city:

country:
None
text:
Great meatloaf recipe.  this is basically how I make mine, however, you can also cook in the microwave.  I put a hole or a well  in the middle like a angle food cake pan and I put the sauce over the meatloaf & cook with a lid on it in the microwave for 20-30 minutes.  Keep an eye on it after 20 minutes.  Then let it sit for 10 minutes or so after you take it out and it should be done.  Keeps the house from heating up.  My daughter is the 'microwave queen'.  I taught her from an early age how to cook in the microwave to avoid her getting into trouble by cooking on the stovetop.  She learned well, and this recipe can be cooked in the microwave as well.  Still turns out pretty good if you need to use the microwave instead of a regular oven.

text:
A good, basic meatloaf recipe, but it seemed a bit bland. I sautéed onions, red peppers, and garlic in butter, waited for it to cool, then added it to the meat mixture. I also added a few Saltine crackers as well Italian bread crumbs. In addition, I added about 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce and a dash of A-1 steak sauce. I doubled the sauce, but only added approximately 1 tablespoon of brown sugar as I don't care for sweet things. I found that I had to bake it for approximately 1 hour and 20 minutes. Overall, a good, easy recipe.

text:
I was very disappointed with how this meatloaf turned out, especially given such high reader ratings. I always make Betty Crocker's meatloaf, and even though it is a great loaf, I decided to try a different one. Unfortunately, this dish turned out mushy and very much lacking in flavor. The only thing I liked about it was the ketchup and brown sugar sauce, but even that I altered after reading reviews. I will not use this meatloaf recipe again, but if I were to change anything about it i would add a handful of sharp cheddar cheese to it and I would recommend using Italian seasoned bread crumbs to help develop flavor. Also, it took at least 15 minutes longer to bake than the recipe claimed, so make sure to allot for the extra baking time!

I am brand new to cooking so anything with "easy" in the title gets my attention. Even though I have a reputation for ruining dinner, this came out awesome! Display Name:
Christina Giles Hester
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1662468.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a lot like my meatloaf but I like mine better. I do not like meatloaf with a bunch of stuff in it or any sauce on top. I use 1 lb (no leaner than 80/20 or it's too dry), 2/3 c milk, 1/4c ketchup, 1 egg, 1/2 cup bread crumbs, 1 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp pepper. A few tips: DO NOT overwork the meat or it will end up dry and tough--mix all the ingredients and then put meat in least and mix up by hand until combined. I never use a loaf pan.. always a 9x13. And like i said, don't use lean meat or it will be dry and tough. 80/20 is fine and should be fall apart moist.

This is the best meatloaf my husband and I have ever had! Neither one of us were big fans of meatloaf growing up, but this one blew them both out of the water! The only problem I had was it was really juicy? I used turkey meat so that might be why, next time I will keep it in a little longer. I used others advice and doubled the sauce, adding more or less of ingredients till I found the perfect taste. I also added Worcestershire sauce as someone suggested..wonderful! I do suggest also sauteing your onions and adding about 2 to 3 cloves of garlic..per taste, and oregano and basil to the meat as well.

country:
None
text:
I've made this meatloaf for 37 years!! I grew up on it! We put a 1/4 - 1/2 tsp of sage in it - an extra egg - and for the piquant sauce we put 1/4 - 1/2 tsp. nutmeg. ALWAYS make 2 - 3 times the sauce to serve with the loaf. Also we didn't put it on the meatloaf till it was about 15 minutes to being ready - that way when you pour the grease off during the cooking time (which gets rid of a lot of fat)the sauce won't get thrown away also.  THERE IS NO OTHER MEATLOAF.  P.S. it's great to make sandwiches with!!

text:
Pretty good basic recipe for meatloaf, but it definitely needed a few more ingredients. I added some finely chopped bell pepper, a few shots of worcestershire, a heavy sprinkling of granulated garlic, Italian seasoning and a big dollop of the glaze mix. While mom and I enjoyed it, we did feel it was still rather bland. Texture was perfect, though! Hubby and kids were less impressed, so I don't think I'll be making it again. Thanks for letting us try!

text:
Just a little tweaking. About 2 1/2 lbs. ground beef, 1/2 onion shredded, 2 cloves garlic, 1 c. ritz crackers smashed with rolling pin, 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce, 1 egg, 1 c. milk, salt and pepper. Formed in 9X13. 3/4 c ketchup, 4 tbsp mustard, 6 tbsp bwn sugar. Baked for 1 hr 10 min. YUM!

text:
Delicious! I am fairly new to cooking so this was my first time making meatloaf for my husband, and it was amazing! I love recipes like this one that are simple, easy to follow, and turn out great. I also read the many reviews and suggestions and sautéed the onion with butter and minced garlic before adding it. I also used 1/2 tablespoon less brown sugar than the recipe called for in my glaze  and it came out perfectly cooked in an hour and 10 mins. Thanks for another great recipe and to all those more qualified reviewers who gave such excellent suggestions on how to tweak it!

Update: after making this recipe an additional few times I tried just making it as written (because I forgot to sauté the onions) and my husband I both liked it better with the raw onion mixed right in before cooking because the flavor and texture was better then when I precooked the onions with the garlic!

None
text:
Absolutely fantastic! Our family (esp. the kids) seldom eat beef and this loaf has got everyone wanting a second serving, I ran out as I only made half the recipe.

Like other reviewers, I sautee the onion with a bit of garlic first. I used red onion but don't think it would make a difference. I used double the amount of egg (simply because half a recipe is 1/2 egg, which would leave the other half useless). I also added a sprinkle of fresh chopped spring onion and 1 stick celery (chopped) in the loaf mixture. For breadcrumbs I just chopped up 2 slices of wholewheat toasted toast in a food processor.

The sauce is the highlight. Like other reviewers, I doubled the amount of sauce, and it came out very juicy.

text:
This was very good. It has a dense, even texture that slices easily, essential for sandwiches. I used about 1-1/2 lbs of ground beef, with about 1/2 lb ground pork, and it took a full 2 hours to cook, and that was even turning the oven up first to 420 and finally to 450°! So by the time we ate, we were all good and hungry! -:) I only had plain breadcrumbs, so I added generous amounts of oregano, basil, marjoram and garlic
powder. I used a couple Tbl of dry minced onion instead of fresh, and just under 1 C of milk. I also added about 2 tsp Worstershire, and used bottled BBQ sauce for the top glaze.
My husband said I should use this recipe for all future meatloafs, so thiat's high praise!

UPDATE: Not long after I wrote this, I discovered that my oven has serious problems maintaining temperature! So you all should probably ignore that bit about taking so long to bake!

text:
Was pretty tasty, but I made a couple of changes. Lacking a fresh onion, I used some dried, minced onion (around a teaspoon and a half), added some garlic (about a teaspoon), and we're not big ketchup fans in this house, so I used barbeque sauce. I also used plain sugar instead of brown, since I realized I didn't have any halfway through making this. The end result was good, the crust being the best part!

country:

text:
This was soooo good! I did use over 2 lbs of hamburger. What I did is add about 1 1/4c. milk, 1 1/4 c. Italian bread crumbs, 1 T. worcestershire sauce, 2 cloves minced garlic and half of a green pepper with the onion and sauteed them in butter. Also doubled the sauce but used 2 T. spicy mustard and 2 T. yellow mustard and that took away some of the sweetness of the brown sugar. Made it in 2 small loaf pans which worked great and drained fat off occasionally. Meatloaf stayed together really well and it was very flavorful. It was delicious! Definately will make again and again. Thanks for the great recipe Janet!

So yummy! My first time making meat loaf, but with this recipe it will not be my last! I didn't have brown sugar so I used a few pinches of white sugar. I also added the topping in the meat by mistake, so I just squirted some ketchup on top to make it look pretty. Oh yeah we ate meatloaf sandwiches the next day but I didn't know how to make them. (special sauce or something?) I just buttered some wheat bread and sliced up the meat about 1/2 an inch. They were very delicious but I wasn't sure if something else usually goes on them... any suggestions?

country:
None
text:
I use this recipe with some variations based on what is available - but my one tip is this: instead of mixing in a a bowl, I add all the ingredients to a 1 gallon freezer bag - then do all the mixing in there. It lets me do a very thorough mix without getting my hands greasy.  Then, I actually use the freezer bag to shape the meatloaf - and release it into the pan by slicing the bottom of the bag with a knife or pair of kitchen scissors.  This gives me a nicely mixed and perfectly shaped loaf.

userID:
13582666
Display Name:
Hilda Garza
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
10
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1701402.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
best meatloaf that I've ever made. I used about 2.5 lbs. of ground beef. Following some of the advice of others as well as adding a few of my own tweaks, the meatloaf was perfect. Here's what I did: 1. I sautéed finely chopped onion, 3 cloves (minced garlic) & 1 green bell pepper stalks  with butter ; then added it to the ground beef. 2. I added 2 teaspoons of Worcestershire sauce to the ground beef mixture along with 2 eggs instead of 1, 1 1/4 cup of milk & about 1 1/2 cup of dried Italian bread crumbs. 3. For the sauce: I initially made it as the directions indicated with 2 TBSP. of brown sugar, and found it to be way too sweet. I then added 1/3 more ketchup and a couple of dashes of Worcestershire Sauce and it was perfect. 4. It was an abundance of sauce, and a lot of the other reviews said that there wasn't enough sauce, so I spooned a thin layer at the bottom of the loaf, molded half the loaf, then sauced the top, and then added the rest of the loaf on top and sauced it really well. This was absolutely perfect. 5. Lastly, i cooked the meatloaf covered for 45 minutes, drained most of any accumulated liquid and cooked uncovered for an additional 30 minutes. This was super moist and delicious!!!!!

text:
This recipe is actually pretty good, and is super easy to make. The pros are the taste-it's very good! I personally didn't find the sauce too sweet at all and felt it was just right. I WAS a bit worried at first, but I'm glad I didn't change the amount of brown sugar. I probably will add a little more of everything though to make it a larger amount of sauce for next time. The one thing about this loaf I didn't like was that it was a bit too mushy. I think if I used 1/2 cup of bread crumbs instead this meatloaf would have been pretty perfect. Will be trying again with some adjustments, including cooking the onions (and a little minced garlic) in some butter before mixing it in.

text:
I did try this and just as it smelled while cooking, it turned out marvelous! I used 1/2 cup of mushrooms, 1/2 cup of green peppers and a large onion, all finely diced and fried them in butter before adding them to the meat. I lined the meat with bacon before putting it in the oven, I had to cover it during the last 15 minutes of baking, as to avoid overbrowning of the bacon, aluminum foil does that nicely! I read many complaints on here as to the baking times and how people reduce stars due to that fact..I have recently purchased a new oven and I find that many things I have baked or even cooked previously require longer or shorter cooking times due to the new oven..not all ovens cook the same, you have to play with it a little sometimes. Love this meatloaf Recipe and so does my Family!

text:
This turned out pretty good, however I think next time I would use less bread crumbs - we thought it was a little mushy which is why I deducted a star.  I sauteed the onion in some butter first as others suggested. The sauce was yummy and reminded me of a sticky tangy spare rib sauce. I lined the pan in foil and greased it but it really stuck to the foil so I think next time I will just cook it in a well greased pan. I made it with some garlic mashed and steamed carrots and it was good comfort food.I think I will make this recipe again just with a few adjustments.

My family likes this, I tweaked it quite a bit during the process however, not only because I was serving 4 people but because by the description and reviews I hear its a little bland..so the glaze ingredients i decided, i would incorporate into the meatloaf itself, now keep in mind i adjusted all of the ingredients, so whatever was in the glaze i put in the meatloaf itself (except milk) then i formed a loaf and topped it off with a second glaze in a smaller proportion. It was delicious and moist. I'm actually glad that I changed it while making it.:) liked it very much!

Display Name:
Passionate_About_Chocolate

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/794305.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a very good recipe! I did make small adjustments to suit my taste. I used 2.25 lbs of ground beef, 2 eggs, 1 cup green onion, 1 1/4 cups milk, 1 1/4 cups regular bread crumbs, salt, pepper, garlic powder, seasoning salt, Italian seasoning, and worcestershire sauce. I cooked for 1 hour and 15 minutes but for the hour I put aluminum foil over the loaf to ensure the whole loaf cooked evenly and in the last 15 minutes I put the topping and allowed the loaf to brown slightly. Then I let it rest for about 20 minutes before cutting, which allowed for even and non crumbled pieces, just the way I like it. I would recommend this for anyone looking for a simple recipe. Even with all the additions it only took 7 minutes to assemble for me.

First of all, I don't cook.  Scrambled eggs, french toast, bacon at best.  But I've decided this year, at age 58, I'm going to learn to cook.  This was my very first attempt at making meatloaf and it turned out delicious!  My wife was shcoked to come home to the smell of meatloaf in the oven.  Anyway, I did triple the sauce as several people recommended (although I only doubled the brown sugar to cut down on sweetness) and I added some sliced olives since I've always liked olives in my meatloaf.  I can't wait to eat the last little bit of the meatloaf fun lunch today!  Maybe I can lear to cook afterall.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Awesome recipe!  My mods are:
-1 lb of g.beef and 1 lb of g.pork
-3/4C of milk instead of 1C, 
-1 small clove of mince garlic to meat mixture, 
-1Tbl of Worcestershire sauce to meat mixture, 
-broil on high for 10 minutes to get a crispy shell at 500 before adding sauce
-use BBQ sauce (non-hickory) instead of ketchup
-triple the BBQ sauce and mustard (but not the sugar)

I've made this about 6 times varying the ingredients to perfection.

This is a very easy and very basic meatloaf recipe.  It was alright, but we like our food spicy, (meaning flavorful not peppery), so this was very plain to our taste.  I would have preferred that the recipe had given an amount of salt and pepper instead of "to taste."  I can't taste raw meat to see if there is too little or too much salt and had to hope I added enough.  I tweaked the sauce based on what others have suggested and found it to be very nice.

country:
None
text:
Good base recipe for meatloaf.  I use 1/2 and 1/2 mixture of ground beef and ground pork; reduce milk to 1/2 cup; add parsley, onion powder, garlic powder, garlic, paprika, seasoned salt and worcestershire sauce and then adjust mustard and brown sugar amounts to taste in ketchup topping.  To make things easier and ensure the meatloaf comes out moist I cook it in the crock pot on low for 8 hours.

text:
Wow Wow Wow... my husband hates meatloaf, but he LOVED this recipe!  I followed the customization recommended by other reviewers:

1. Sauted the onion in butter
2. Use seasoned bread crumbs (did not have a full cup, so I mixed with crushed saltines) 
3. Doubled the ketchup mixture and reduced the amount of mustard a tad 
4. Added 1 tbsp Worchestershire in the meat mix 

This meatloaf was moist and delicious. We will definitely make again!

I threw all the ingredients in, with exception of mustard, which i didn't use.  I covered the top with plain tomato sauce out of a can.  I also used seasoned bread crumbs.  I also increased the cook time to 1.25 hours.  I would suggest cooking at 375 for 1 hour if you want more of a solid loaf.

text:
WOW!  Amazing...1st time I've ever rated something but had to! We both had seconds and would have more if we weren't so full!  Made the following changes - used 1 lb grass fed organic beef, 3/4 cup goat yogurt instead of milk, sauteed onion in garlic and butter, added grated zucchini (approx 1/3 cup) and dried basil, oregano and thyme (approx 1 tsp each).  For the glaze mixed 1/2 cup ketchup with 2 heaping TBSP maple syrup, 1 tsp worcestershire sauce and 1TBSP balsamic & pepper mustard. Cooked 1hr 10 mins. Served with roasted zucchini and curried quinoa with apples, toasted almonds and dried apricots.
FAB-U-LOUS!

text:
I gave this 5 starts after a few alterations :) I used onion soup mix instead of the onion and the seasoned bread crumbs that others suggested.  I used half the amount of brown sugar, as I like a little less sweet.  I like to broil on HI for 3 minutes, then let set for at least 8 to 10 minutes before serving.  Very flavorful, my 3 and 5-year-old daughters loved it.  Served with buttery mashed potatoes and green beans.

text:
Amazing meatloaf. I used about 2 pounds ground beef. Substituted doritos nacho cheese for breadcrumbs. Added good amount of garlic salt. Cooked onions with minced garlic, garlic salt and butter until brown. Added a little seasoned salt. Kept one cup milk and one egg. I added more brown sugar to the topping, I suggest doubling the topping like everybody suggests. Cooked for about 1 hour 10 minutes since I had more beef. Most delicious moist meatloaf ever. :)

text:
True to the title, this is an excellent, easy recipe. I followed the advice of other reviewers and added my own twists as well.
1) added sauteed onion, mushroom and green pepper, and crushed garlic.
2)doubled the sauce, and added a healthy tablespoon of A1 sauce for more bite.
3)added 1 tablespoon of Italian seasoning (plain breadcrumbs)
4) lined pan with tinfoil.

This was outstanding!!! And as the title indicates, very easy to make.  My husband, who is not a fan of mustard, even liked this. Generally when he likes something a lot, he will say it's "not bad", but he actually said this was "really good!" Very high praise.  :-)  The sauce gives the meatloaf a nice sweet/tangy flavor.  

I only used half an onion and used italian flavored breadcrumbs.  I'll definitely be making this meatloaf again.

This was the most amazing meatloaf I have ever had. It was very moist.  I sauteed the onions with some minced garlic in butter and used seasoned breadcrumbs.  I also doubled the ketchup in the topping but didn't double the mustard or brown sugar.  The topping was still very sweet.. I loved it, but if you aren't a fan of sweet, I would leave the sugar out.  It was overall very delicious and I will use this as my main meatloaf recipe from now on! (and delete the other one I have in my recipe box on here!)  Thanks :)

text:
I've made a lot of meatloaf recipes and this actually turned out the best.  I added dashes of worcestershire and a few squirts of ketchup to the mix. I sauteed the onion in butter first.  I also used 93% lean meat. I had 2.25 lbs of meat so I upped ingredients accordingly but used 1 egg.   I hand shaped 2 loaves on a foil lined cookie sheet and for the topping just coated with ketchup.  Baked until therm said 160.  So simple yet really good.  Sadly no leftovers for sandwiches!

My husband just wondered if maybe we could have this meatloaf for Thanksgiving dinner, instead of turkey.  This is as billed- simple food, easy to make- wonderful for weeknight comfort food. Very moist, it held its shape but my children had no problem chewing it.  The topping is awesome, used a little more mustard and a little less sugar than recommended. text:
You don't need so much milk if you don't have so many breadcrumbs.  The more breadcrumbs and milk the less you'll be able to really taste the flavor of the meat.  I used 2/3 cup of breadcrumbs and 1/4 cup of milk.  I added an extra egg and 1 T of dried parsley.  I liked the sauce for the top though.  GREAT recipe with changes - a little 'doughy' as is.  Also, flavored breadcrumbs can change everything - three cheese is my favorite.

text:
This was great!  My whole family really liked it (including my 2 year old!) Made a few changes that others listed:   -Sauted the onion before adding it to the meat -Use seasoned bread crumbs -Doubled the ketchup mixture and reduced the amount of mustard and brown sugar (don't like my meat too sweet) -Added 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce in the meat mix  - Put the loaf on a roasting pan b/c there was sooo much juice/grease that it spilled over into the oven

region:

country:
None
text:
This is really good for a quick nite meal.  I usually have everything in place.  The only thing I do differently and I do it with every meatloaf I make is to put the meatloaf in a 13x9 pan and add about a 1/4 inch of water I cook it this way for about 45 mins then drain add the topping.  This way I drain all the fat and the meatloaf stays moist, and comes out of the pan AND cleanup is easier!  I do the same with meatballs except use beef broth.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I wouldn't use a loaf pan as that allows the meat to sit in its own grease. Rather build your loaf on a wire rack sitting in a sheet pan with raised sides. This allows the grease to drain away from the meat. You can line the sheet pan for easier clean up. 
I also left off the brown sugar as ketchup already has some sweetness as does the onion.

text:
Made a few changes and took the advice of other reviewers as well.

I grated some carrot, chopped some onion, minced a clove of garlic and sauted that in some butter with basil and parsley. 

Used seasoned breadcrumbs and added a dash of soy sauce and balsamic vinegar (JUST a dash ;) ) Also added some garlic powder and mixed everything together.

For the topping I omitted the sugar (ketchup is sweet enough by itself) and instead added a tbpn BBQ sauce to the mixture. 

Came out amazing!! Will Def go into our reg rotation!!

text:
We thoroughly enjoyed this meat loaf. I love the basic ingredients, nothing pre-fab like condensed soup or soup mixes. I did add 1 tbsp of Worcestershire sauce like other reviewers, and used seasoned bread crumbs. I really liked the tangy hit of mustard in the topping which cut the sweetness. I did not see the point in cooking the onions beforehand as others suggested. There is no need for that extra step, as they were nice and soft after one hour in the oven.

userID:

Display Name:
Zach Owens

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2171208.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A friend and I made this recipe and heeded the advice of the other reviewers. The result was a fantastic dish! Note that this might only serve 2-3 people, I feel that a typical family will need two dishes. We used the exact ingredient list, with Italian seasoned breadcrumbs and a little more (.20 lb) of meat. Also, a whole onion, diced and sauteed in buyter and garlic beforehand. For the sauce, lots of brown sugar, very little mustard, ketchup and Worcestershire sauce, blended to taste. Also, some common kitchen spices didn't hurt. We baked it until the sauce caramelized on the top and the inside was nice and plump, this took about an hour and a half at 350. Served with quartered red potatoes and a ceasar salad, it was an excellent meal that we'll be making again!

Recipe was very good. I followed the suggestions of others and sauteed the onions and I also added some celery. text:
This is hands down the best meatloaf I have ever had! This recipe has actually become a classic staple in my house. I make it  at least a couple times a month. My family absolutely loves it! So much so that when I asked my uncle what he wanted for his birthday dinner with the promise he could choose anything in the world he wanted, he actually chose this meatloaf recipe!Every time I buy hamburger meat now I literally use it for nothing else but this meatloaf. It has the perfect moist inside but the top gets really nice and crunchy with the Delicious caramelized ketchup on top. I usually don't add the onion because my family doesn't really like them and honestly you can't tell a difference. One thing i will say though as a tip if your new to making meatloaf is always get hamburger that is really low in fat! If you get meat with higher fat content you will basically have delicious taco meat. It needs to have less fat so it holds its loaf shape and not fall apart. Hands down 5 stars but would be ten if they had ten stars!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good recipe with some modifications: 1) add 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce, 2) use 3/4 bread crumbs (Italian seasoned) and/or oatmeal, 3) I used 80/20 chuck ground beef (maybe use 90/10 next time- it was super oily!), 4) double ketchup portion for sauce (don't double mustard or sugar), 5) bake for 1 hour 20 min (maybe at 50 min drain the fat if using oily meat), 6) when done, cover with foil and let sit for 10 min), 7) if still wet and oily, place on plate and microwave for 3 min.

text:
Really good basic meatloaf. Nice and moist.  I do recommend you NOT put it in loaf pan, and instead shape it and bake it on slotted broiler-type pan so grease can drip through.  I used Panko breadcrumbs b/c that's what I had.  And to experiment, I cut bacon slices in half and laid them over half of the meatloaf. Good addition! I thought topping was good balance of sweet/spicy, with yellow mustard.  I mixed that up earlier, so maybe sitting awhile helped?  I literally spread it on top of meatloaf/bacon with my fingers since it was thick enuf and that allowed me to "paint" the sides.  Have saved this one to my Recipe Box.

text:
I have made this many times now and my hard to please husband still requests this for his lunches. It heats up great and is delicious! I would definitely double the sauce mixture to add on top! I typically use panko bread crumbs but have also tried regular Italian and both are great.  I always use Worcestershire  and add a few shakes to the meat mixture! If you are out of eggs you can use 1Tb of real mayo. If you have onion i would sauté them. i have made it without onion too and it still was received well. I have already had 2 requests for my meatloaf recipe! I never thought meatloaf would be such a loved recipe in our house! Definitely give this recipe a try!
UPDATE: I now cut the sugar in half (use 2TB only if you are doubling the sauce) and it is perfect!

text:
Made it twice now.  Like an old fashioned meatloaf that makes nice slices for sandwiches when cold. Last night I had to use Italian seasoned crumbs as that's all I had. The first time I used plain, but not quite enough to make a cup, so I supplemented with Italian. Both are great. I also added about 2 tablespoons of Worcestershire sauce each time. For the top, I used plain ketchup, put on halfway through cooking.  The proportion for the loaf are perfect.  This would nicely serve a family of 6, but there would be no leftovers for sandwiches. My husband of 40 years has asked me to make this every week! Good, quick, cheap and easy, my cooking criteria.  Editing:  today, I used one lb 85% lean hamburger, and two sweet Italian Sausages , about 1/2 lb for the two, meat removed from casings.  One half cup Italian dry crumbs, one half cup dry plain crumbs.  Cooked it in two small loaf pans, one to eat tonite, one to freeze for next week.  As before, used the Worchesester sauce.

My husband has been craving meatloaf for a couple weeks now. I followed this recipe ALMOST to the letter. Everyone likes to put their own personal touch when cooking...recipes are a nice guideline...not set in stone. This recipe is sooooo basic and easy to use. Almost impossible to mess this up. I added worcestershire sauce, used seasoned bread crumbs, used a season mix blend of onions bell peppers and celery, used bbq sauce instead of making the topping. It was FABULOUS!!!!! My husband loved it. My 2 teenagers devoured it. I only have enough left for 2 servings! I personally think this is the BEST meatloaf I've ever made. A cup of this and a cup of that, an egg and some ground beef made for an incredibly moist yet firm meatloaf. Such an easy recipe. I don't think I'll ever use another recipe again. This was fantastic!!!!

text:
Just made this recipe for April 1st (April Fools Supper) into "cupcakes".  I followed another reviewers advice and used Italian Seasoned Bread Crumbs.   It was very tasty.  After combining all the "loaf" ingredients I divided the meat mixture into large balls and put them into a muffin pan, then spooned the glaze over each serving.  I still baked for one hour and they were done perfectly.  When serving the "cupcakes" I bought premade mashed potatoes (easy) and tinted it bright pink.  The mashed potato "frosting" then went on the meatloaf "cupcakes".  I served each on a plate with a lit candle that we all blew out after saying our dinner prayer.  It was a fun and tasty meal.  My 6 year old niece told me I really "April Fooled" her as she thought we were having real cupcakes for supper.

city:

country:
None
text:
Because of the short ingredient list, I chose this recipe for my first attempt at making meatloaf and have now made it twice. I followed the recipe faithfully the first time with the only changes being that I used plain almond milk instead of cow milk, Italian seasoned dried bread crumbs, and increased cooking time to be about 1 hour and 25/30 minutes until the meat thermometer read 160 degrees F. The meatloaf turned out really good, pulling lots of compliments from my family. However, we all agreed that the sweetness of the topping was a bit much for our taste and that there wasn’t enough of it (which was probably a good thing since it was too sweet). The meat itself tasted good and was the perfect texture. The second time I made it, I used some of the suggestions from other reviewers.

Meat mixture: Used Italian seasoned dried bread crumbs (again) sautéed the onions with garlic, and added 1 tbsp of Worcestershire sauce (low sodium).
Topping: Doubled the ingredients to make more topping but reduced brown sugar by about half.

The recipe is mostly unchanged, however, because the original is just sooo tasty! My family said they loved it and want it again!

text:
I made this meatloaf for my family on Saturday.  It was so easy to make.  I tweaked it a bit, following other reviews.  I used a mix of ground beef and pork just to cut back a bit on the fat.  For the 1.5 lbs. of meat, I used 2 eggs (because the eggs I had were kinda tiny), 1 1/2 cups of Italian style dried bread crumbs, half a teaspoon each of dried basil and oregano.  I also added half a large green bell pepper which I chopped finely.  I left the rest of the ingredients for the meatloaf unchanged.  I added 1 tsp of worcestershire sauce to the sauce and not in the meat mixture.  I baked it for 1 hour and 20 minutes and it turned out perfectly moist and most importantly....DELICIOUS!  My hubby and 6-year old son loved it so much they want me to make it again!  And I definitely will.  Thanks for sharing this recipe!

text:
Had to give this 4 due to alterations that made it a 5! BEST MEATLOAF EVER! I sauteed the onion w 2 cloves garlic 1 stalk celery in 1 tbsp butter. Added about 1 tbsp Worcestershire to the meat, reduced bread crumbs to 3/4. For the sauce double the ketchup & add a few dashes Worcestershire.  I doubled the mustard because we like the tang and added about 1/3 c bbq sauce. The layering of the sauce on the bottom, middle, then top was a must.I topped w parsley flakes for a little color. cooked at 350 for 50 minutes foil covered, then uncovered for about 20 (kidz prefer beef well-done), then broiled for about 5 minutes. I did have to drain it several times and again right before broiling.  Seriously,  TRY THIS OUT!! Thanks reviewers for the tweak suggestions :-)  I'll never make meatloaf any other way again

text:
This was a great base recipe.  Using two pounds of g.b., I did what others suggested with the worcestershire, sauteed onions and a red bell pepper in lots of butter with garlic.  I was out of milk, so I used a bit under a cup of chicken broth instead and added another egg to make up for the milk.  I also added 4 pieces of cooked, chopped bacon.  A dash of nutmeg to the topping.  My guys liked it...being vegetarian, I didn't try it, but if my men like it I know it must be good.  Will be keeping this one :)  Thank you for sharing!  Also, I formed a loaf on a sheet (makes for easy removal of grease) and cooked at 350 for about half an hour, and another half hour at 365, let sit for about 10 minutes before serving.

country:
None
text:
I found this recipe in a childrens cookbook that I had when I was a kid.  I absolutely love it and have been making it ever since.  One difference is that in the cookbook it gives you the option to make mini meatloaves, which I usually do because it cuts the cook time down by 75% (only 15 min.).  You can do this by using a muffin tin or by forming small balls, about the size of a baseball, and cooking it on a foil lined baking sheet.  I also recommend not filling the loaf pan to the edges.  This way you can get the sauce on the sides, and in my opinion the sauce is what makes this dish.

Served this tonight. I used crackers instead of bread crumbs.  I also found a tiny bit of chili powder (the kind in an envelope for making chili, not regular chili powder)...it was probably about a teaspoon and I threw it in with the ground beef mixture.  I didn't salt much because I figured between the saltine crackers and the chili seasoning, it was ok.  The only mustard I had was Dijon so used that.  I browned the onions in a little bit of butter as many described and also sauteed some green peppers but forgot to put them into the ground beef mixture, so I just added them to the top after spreading on the topping. It looked pretty. I served it with rice.  My husband liked it so much he had two servings and he rarely does that.

text:
Good recipe.  After reading numerous reviews, I decided to adjust the recipe based on advice from others.  I completely excluded the brown sugar, reduced the amount of mustard to 1 tablespoon, increased the amount of ketchup to 1 cup, sauted the onion, and also added a tablespoon of worcestershire sauce.  I also ended up cooking it for 1 hour and 25 minutes rather than just an hour which was perfect timing.  Thank you everyone for the great suggestions in your reviews! I do not think mine would have ended up as good if I wouldn't have made these adjustments based on all your suggestions!

userID:
11257023
Display Name:
Lisa Park
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1176132.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is my base meatloaf recipe, and the very first thing I tried when I decided to start doing actual cooking instead of just warming up pre-made stuff in the oven or microwave. Although I alter it a bit, it's become one of my "go-to" recipes for when I need something quick and easy.

The first meatloaf I ever had was kind of ketchupy-tasting, so that's what my mouth looks for in a meatloaf. Therefore, I usually increase the amounts of ketchup and mustard by 50% (doubling the part that goes into the meatloaf mix, and leaving the glaze as is). I also quite liked it when I increased the sugar the same way, but I stopped doing that to try to keep some semblance of trying to be healthy! Also, instead of brown sugar, I use coconut palm sugar, which is healthier and tastes just as good. I try to add lots of different veggies, too, to make it a one-course meal that's easy to pack for lunch at work. Carrots are good, as are mushrooms, diced tomatoes, and chopped spinach.

BFF LOVED this recipe!!!! said it is the best EVER!! . He also said keep the topping per original recipe do not double it. LOL. Great Recipe. I did what others suggested with the sauteed onions and Worcestershire sauce, but I also used 1/2 a green and red pepper too. I used Ritz Crackers instead of crumbs for the salt and buttery taste. I also added some bacon bits to it. For the sauce I made a little more than the recipe and also to spice it up a bit I added a 1/2 teaspoon of Cayenne pepper. It came out amazing! My kids even ate it and they are picky eaters!

This meatloaf is perfectly moist, holds together well, and tastes delicious. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great basic recipe which I gussied up some by using 1/2 ground chicken and 1/2 ground sausage.  I didn't have any bread crumbs, so I substituted rolled oats.  Didn't miss the bread crumbs, plus I need lower gluten recipes anyway. I left out the sugar and mustard also. I layered half of the meat in the pan, then sprinkled a generous portion of grated sharp cheddar, then the remainder of the meat mix. Oh, and I left out the milk, too, but this recipe turned out very moist. I didn't grease the pan as I figured there would be extra fat from using the sausage. Everyone of the eight people at the table  pronounced it to be a 'keeper' for sure. It was absolutely delicious and I definitely will make it again. It proved to be a quick, easy recipe for short notice company coming. Great basic recipe you can switch up different ways for different dinners. Thanks, Janet!

country:
None
text:
This recipe was wonderful. I read a lot of reviews before making this and made some modifications. My fiance and youngest daughter are very picky eaters. My fiance wanted seconds and my daughter ate it so big success. I used 2 lbs of ground beef, 1/2 C. milk indtead of 1 C., we don't like onions so used I TBS onion powder instead, added 1 TBS garlic powder, and 1 TBS worcestershire. Also doubled the topping; however was too mustardy so we did 3 TBS mustard, 4 TBS brown sugar, 1 C. ketchup, and added I TBS worcestershire. This was wonderful. It cooked for an hour just like the recipe called. I think it depends on your oven.

text:
I'd like to ask how much onion is required (1 onion might be very big or very small).  Perhaps the quantity could be expressed in cups. 
Also, add a tablespoonful or two of freshly chopped parsley, hold the sugar, forget the ketchup.  Top with stewed tomatoes and grated cheese.   Also, in lieu of dried bread crumbs, try oatmeal soaked in skim milk or water to add fiber.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674130.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As written, this was okay. It need some seasoning and veggie love. For round two, I sauteed chopped onion, green pepper, mushrooms, and garlic and added it to the meat. I also added a packet of onion soup mix and some pepper to balance out the saltiness of the onion soup. I paired this with parmesan/roasted garlic potatoes. It was so good that I woke up in the middle of the night to pick at the leftovers. My advice to other meatloaf makers is 1) for tender meatloaf, don't squeeze the beef; gently mix together the ingredients until they're just combined, and 2) let the breadcrumbs sit in a bowl with the milk to absorb it, then mix in everything else.

My family has always loved meatloaf, but they have never asked for it until I made this recipe.  Based on other reviews I sauteed the onion.  I also use 2lbs of meatloaf mix (1lb gr beef, 1lb gr pork) and add a meatloaf spice packet instead of salt and pepper. The recipe is wonderful as written but such a great base that you can customize it to savory or sweet to suit your taste. Thanks!

text:
Awesome meatloaf recipe!! My boyfriend could not get enough of it it was delicious! I made a few changes though. 1) I used 3 lbs of ground beef(grass fed and organic) and used more of all of the other ingredients for the extra meat.  2) I added worstishire sauce to the meat, about 2 tablespoons. 3) I sautéed the garlic, onions, and red and yellow bell pepper and added that to the meat. 4) used seasoned bread crumbs. I also doubled the ketchup sauce mixture. Baked at 350 for an hour and a half. Made mashed potatoes and asparagus to go with it! Soo delicious I will definitely make it again!

text:
I have to say I made this tonight and it turned out absolutely wonderful.  It's not a new, exotic, type meatloaf.  Instead, it reminds me of the kind my  mother made growing up!  The sauce is so good, and I certainly agree with other viewers that you should make about a third more than the recipe calls for in order to give the loaf a nice glaze.  Additionally, I also sauteed the onions with a couple of cloves of garlic in some butter and oil, as others suggested.  It was so moist, so comforting.  GREAT recipe...will now be a staple!

text:
This was good (for a very basic meatloaf) and hubby loved it but I do agree, there isn't quite enough sauce, hence the 4 star rating.  Since I was just making for 2 ppl and only had just under 1lb 90% lean ground beef, I had to modify the recipe a bit.  I set the servings to 5 and used those quantities listed (except still used 1 whole egg).  I would've loved to try adding Worcestershire sauce but didn't have any in the house.  I didn't have breadcrumbs so I used crumbled crackers (the equivalent of about 8 'social crackers').  I also sauteed the onion a bit along with a large clove of garlic.  Still baked it for an hour and it came out perfectly cooked.  Next time I'll make more sauce on the side to ladle over individual servings.

text:
This was the best meatloaf I've ever made. My husband is a very picky eater, and he loved it too. I didn't have any onions on hand, so I used Lipton dry onion soup mix. This had plenty of seasoning, so I didn't add any salt or pepper. I also used Italian seasoned bread crumbs instead of plain ones. My husband is diabetic, so I didn't include any topping before baking it. I added a bit of sweet baby ray's BBQ sauce on mine once it was on my plate. I was pleased with the simplicity of this recipe, and how quick it was to throw it together. I will definitely make this again.

I've been using this recipe for years now, and discovered that you can perk up the topping by adding 1/4 tsp ground nutmeg and 1/4 tsp dry mustard to the ketchup mixture. It is so flexible that you can add any shredded vegetables and spice up or down with the same excellent results.

I gave this a 3 based on the written recipe not the taste.  The flavour is great, but it wasn't written properly.  I am AMAZED no one has said that the cooking time is WAY off.  I used 1lb turkey, 1/2lb beef.  I did 350 for an hour and let it rest and when I cut into it, it was not done.  So I put the temp up to 400 and did another 30 min.  STILL was bloody in the middle.  Did ANOTHER 30 min at 400 and it was finally done.  It isn't my stove because this is the first time I've had a recipe NOT turn out from AR.  So this took me double the time...we ate dinner at 8:30pm because of the timing issue....way too late.

It was so tasty and moist!  This recipe is going to be the only one I use to make meatloaf.  Tried other recipes and could not get away with extra lean meat without drying it out except this one.  Thanks for the recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was awesome! Probably the best meatloaf I've ever had (with a few tweaks). I made some changes based on others here and myself.

First off, I left out the brown sugar (kind of). I used Adam's Rib Rub which was sold in my local supermarket (Shop-Rite). It has brown sugar in it and other spices. I put this in my meat mixture as well as my sauce. I put more than the 2 tbsp of brown sugar called for. In total I might have used 1/4 to 1/3 of the bag between the meat and the sauce.

I tried this recipe twice. One person said to first saute the onions in butter. Not needed and made absolutely no difference. The onions get tender when cooked in the oven anyway.

As for the sauce, I tripled the quantity.. that means 1 cup ketchup, 6 tbsp mustard. I used Boar's Head Mustard, which made the sauce very tangy. Some said to use less mustard, but I enjoyed what I made and thought it was perfect.

The cooking time was perfect if you ask me. My meat was totally moist and not overcooked or dry in anyway shape or form.

text:
My 12 yr old son requested meatloaf and the whole family thought this one was amazing.I gave this 4 stars because of the sweetness of the glaze on top. Next time I'll just  really reduce or leave out the brown sugar. I served it with mashed cauliflower similar to the recipe on this site. I had 2 lbs of ground beef so I added 2 eggs, 1 1/3 c of both milk & bread crumbs. I did modify the recipe per other reviews by using only 1/2 onion and adding 1 pkg onion soup mix, some Italian seasoning, a couple shakes of Worcestershire in the meat and also in the glaze but I think if I would have just made the recipe as written I would have still given it a 4.    Thanks Janet!

text:
*note -  this would easily get 5 stars if you tweak the sauce like 95% of the reviews say to do. 
I did and my husband and i loved it (which is saying something since i wouldn't choose to eat beef. But he loves it so it better be good when i make it & we eat)
I used a loaf pan and when i took mine out of the oven there was quite a bit of liquid around the loaf which surprised me but i drained it before serving and the meat was very moist. I also put in 1 minced garlic clove, used half an onion and that was just fine, however the only thing i had in the house was Ritz crackers and those didn't seem to hold up as well.. They seemed to disappear.  i'll probably go for real bread crumbs or more substantial crackers next time (we crushed some on top & that was a great addition).
For my sauce i followed the recipe and then added hot sauce, BBQ sauce and some salt&pepper

Hope this helps!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
4 stars from me....2 stars from the family. I was THE laugh of the evening due to the brown sugar....my husband was having insulin rushes...hAha. My revisions/additions...I sauteed the onions, added fresh minced garlic, about a Tbls of baby rays (because that's the bbq sauce we like, added a splash of worcestershire sauce, parsley & fresh from the garden tomatoes. I also used ritz crackers instead of bread. I could tell without reading other reviews it needed some "extra" ingredients. Apparently others agreed (according the reviews I read afterwards...It didn't surprise me). It was more of a wet loaf, which I'm not crazy about. It DID have a great flavor though (a bit of the topping was scraped off & in place, I had some left over Ritz cracker crumbles to spinkle on top which the kids Loved). I divided my meatload into 3 smaller loafs, increased the oven temp to 365 & cooked it about 40 minutes. I added the sauce about 20 minutes after cooking to avoid burning. So, all in all, I give it 4 stars!

text:
I give this 4 stars only because I altered the ingredients based on other reviewers and my own likes.   I make my hamburgers very similar but wanted something that differs.  So I did what I normally do with hamburgers which is add the eggs, milk, sauted onion with garlic, worcestershire sauce. Except this was meatloaf and I desired it to be different.  Sooo, with this meatloaf I made my own seasoned bread crumbs.  Simply by using "thin whiches" and grinding them with "Italian Herb" grinder from McCormick. Who knew? they came up with a great blend.  Anyway it worked great.  I did cut down on  the mustard in the sauce.  Only because I'm more a ketchup person; Great Meatloaf thank you to the reviewers it means so much!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very good basic meatloaf recipe. I used very lean ground beef. The only problem I had was the fat bubbled on top of the meatloaf. When trying to drain the fat off, most of my topping went with it. Also, I didn't add enough salt. The next time I make this, I will add a little more salt and take the meatloaf out of the oven about 10-15 minutes early and drain the fat. Then put my topping on and bake for the remaining minutes. My husband is a very picky eater, but he liked this recipe. It is also great the next day.

It has replaced my Mom's recipe. (Paula Dean's potatoes were wonderful with it.)

text:
Super easy recipe and great results!  I read other reviews, and took suggestions that included adding Worcestshire, and softening the onions in butter with garlic before adding to meatloaf mixture.  I also made the glaze with just ketchup, Worcestshire, dry mustard and a lot of freshly ground black pepper - spicy!  Meatloaf was super moist, had a nice, mellow onion flavor to it which was balanced nicely with the heat of the ketchup glaze.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4134668.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm yet to taste it as a whole, but the juices and the topping plus the smell are divine, thus a 5 star rating.
I softened my onions in butter before adding it to the mix, I added 1tbsp Worcestershire sauce, only used 1/2c milk and started my bread crumbs at 1/2c and added gradually as I didn't want to make it TOO "loafy".  I used tinfoil throw-away pans so I didnt have stick or clean up.  I should have put bread on the bottom or used a lower percent fat ground beef because I had a LOT of shrinkage with 81% and a lot of juices.  
When I tested the temp it ruined the topping sauce, as a FYI, see if you can wait out testing the temp if you can/do. I only tested the temp because i wasn't using the recommended pan size and was making more than one loaf and didn't want to over or under cook.  How does the loaf in picture #1 turn out like that? I'll make this again, I won't give up!

I've been making this recipe for 20 years, but I omit the breadcrumbs to make it moister. Sometimes I make this into meatloaf muffins by greasing a muffin pan with a bit of oil, then adding the meatloaf mixture, and spreading the sauce on each. Makes about 10 "muffins", and my picky eaters love them!

Wonderful recipe. I modified based on other reviews. text:
This was my first attempt at making meatloaf ever and this one turned out very moist and flavorful with a few minor changes...  Took the advice to 1)Saute the onion in butter with some garlic before adding to the mixture and 2)Add 1 tbsp worcestershire sauce for flavor.  3)My fiance really hates mustard & won't eat anything with it, so I made the sauce just from brown sugar and ketchup and it turned out great!  I accidentally used 2lbs of ground beef instead of 1.5 but the overall taste and consistency was good... it came out moist but very "loose"... probably will cut back the amount of meat next time or at least add maybe 1/4 c. or more breadcrumbs to help fix the texture.  Anyway, because of this, mine took slightly longer, about 1hr, 7 minutes.  Just cook until the temp reads 160-165 or higher.  :)  Will definitely make this again!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first meatloaf I ever made.  Read a lot of reviews and made some changes.  I used 1/2 turkey, 1/2 beef mix to cut down the fat.  Was going to add Worcestershire sauce as other suggested and found I had none so used soy sauce instead. Sauteed onion,, green onion, and garlic in butter as other suggested. Also doubled sauce recipe, but used less dijon mustard. I read reviews on other meatloaf recipes that baked in cupcake form and did the same.  350 for 25 minutes with the convection on.  Much faster and each meatloaf cupcake was a serving.  Also put some bread at the bottom of each cupcake form to soak up the excess fat prior to putting meat in.  Hubby and kids both loved it!  Definitely a keeper.  Thanks!

text:
Loved this dish with a few changes based on the other reviews. First I sautéed the onions so they were not to crunchy, added garlic salt and a bit of BBQ sauce to the meat. Then cut down on the mustard and added Worcestershire sauce instead for the topping. It was a bit soggy based on the cooking time provided so I cooked it for 1 hour 20 minutes. It was very yummy. Everyone ate it and did not complain which is a miracle with a 5yr old and 22month old boys. The only thing I would do differently next time is make more of the topping which other users suggested as well.

I modified this recipe and it was fantastic!!! text:
This is a quick and easy get home from work and assemble meal.    Or even easier is to make it ahead and freeze!  Just take out and unthaw a day ahead and even the teenage boys can put it in the oven for an hour!  (Now one of my regular recipe's for batch cooking)   I have made it with and without sauteing the onions first and it definitely tastes better with sauteed onions.  I also add a bit of fresh garlic to the pan with the onions.  I found the milk to be too much liquid so I cut it down to 3/4 cup.  Great with a side of potatoes / rice and a salad!

text:
I made this with turkey and omitted the milk.  As others suggested, added worschire sauce and caramelized the onions too.  Very easy and yum. Another fun thing I did with some of the meat mixture is put a large tablespoon of it in a cupcake wrapper, topped it with 4-5 baby spinach leaves, topped that with 1 teaspoon of mozzeralla cheese, a slice of roma tomato, more mozzeralla cheese.  Put it in a cupcake pan and baked at 350 for 25 minutes (until cheese was browned).  Very yummy and gourmet.

city:

country:
None
text:
excellent meatloaf! I added the Worcestershire sauce and sauted the onion w/chopped garlic (as the other reviewer said) and it came out amazing. I used saltine crackers instead of bread crumbs. A tip: I mix the crumbs, onion, s & p, egg, & worcestershire sauce together first, then add the beef. I do that so i know there is even distribution of ingredients thoughout. I didn't add the milk and it was still excellent. For the topping I used 2 tablespoons spicy brown mustard, 2 tablespoons brwn sugar & 1/2 c ketchup and poured it on meatloaf at last 10 min. of cooking. Sauted onions did make a difference. When you take it out of the oven, let it rest about 5 min. before slicing. This was the best recipe for meatloaf i've found so far. My husband really loved it.. It was very juicy. thx!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A very good and easy to prepare meatloaf.  My family especially liked the topping.  I made a few small changes.  I used 2 lbs of beef because that's what I had.  I also only used half a yellow onion and sauteed it in a tablespoon of butter with one and a half teaspoons minced garlic.  I used mostly Italian style bread crumbs because that's what I had and I increased the crumbs a little (my 1 cup was mounded) since I was using more meat. I also added 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce.  After mixing everything together I patted it into an 11x7 pan and since it was a little thinner than it would have been in a loaf pan it only took 55 minutes to cook to 175 degrees on the meat thermometer.  It was very moist.

text:
I made this for the first time this week and my husband said "Make it like that from now on!" I followed others comments 1) adding 1 Tbsp Worestershire, 2) sautee 1/2 onion and 1/2 green pepper, 3) use Italian breadcrumbs and 4) double the sauce, (but only 3 Tbsp of mustard). The recipe doesn't specify cover or uncovered, so I covered for the first 30, then uncovered for the rest of the time. This one will be a regular in our house!

text:
My boyfriend and I both really enjoyed this meatloaf! I made it the first time about two weeks ago and was craving it again tonight! I made the following adjustments: I used onion powder instead of fresh onions, Italian bread crumbs instead of regular and for the topping, I only used one tbs of brown sugar and mustard instead of two. It was a little too tangy/sweet for me the first time. Also, I made it in a mini-loaf pan which cuts the cooking time by about 15-20 minutes and makes it easy to pack leftovers for lunch the nexdt day. This is a very easy recipe using very common ingredients that I will certainly keep in the dinner rotation.

text:
I really liked this recipe. I used 93/7 beef, substituted an envelope of onion soup mix instead of the onion (didnt have time to chop it up and saute it), used italian seasoned breadcrumbs instead of plain breadcrumbs, added 1/4 tsp of garlic powder and 1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce to the meat, doubled the ketchup mix (though I halved the amount of brown sugar that the recipe called for, to decrease the sweetness), and added about a heaping tablespoon of barbecue sauce to the ketchup mix to give it a little more tang. Wonderful!! Husband gobbled it down.

Such a great simple recipe. I've made a couple of meatloaf recipes in the last weeks looking for the taste of this one! 4 stars because I changed it up just a little bit. text:
Needed an easy meal and was short on ingredients and this fit the bill!  I doubled the topping and only used about a quarter of the mustard suggested.  Really didn't need the extra topping since it ran out into the 9x13 pan and just made a mess and burned (not affecting meatloaf taste).  I used seasoned bread crumbs because that's all I had and added a little worcestershire powder to the meat.  Not bad at all for a super-easy meatloaf recipe.  Would have given 5 stars, but mustard is way too much for my taste and prefer a little worcestershire in the topping and a smidgen of garlic in the meat.  Still, worth a solid 4 stars.

userID:
24644116
Display Name:
Don Hauptman
isPro:

1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6048107.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I confess, I am terrible about exact measurements. I get close, plus our minus.  I use brown deli mustard in the topping and am a bit heavy with it, plus extra brown sugar and I add a couple of fat dashes of Worstershire sauce.  It imparts a great flavor and helps tenderize the meat.   As for the beef, using the recipe measurements, I replace a half pound of beef with a half pound of Jimmy Dean's sage breakfast sausage.  Once you make them, wrap them in plastic wrap, put them in a gallon ziploc bag and then into the freezer for at least three days. It gives the ingredients a chance ro mingle and mature. 

My family is nuts about this recipe, especially my finicky nine year old.

Enjoyed this recipe. Very tasty. Made it with 2 lbs of turkey meat. Very easy to make, but took longer than 10 minutes of prep time. Wished I had the review that suggested letting the meat rest before cutting. May have been good to drain excess liquid during cooking or reducing amount of milk. Very moist, yet there seemed to bee too much liquid. My first time to make meat loaf :)

text:
Yes, very easy, and a crowd pleaser. I didn’t change a thing, except I doubled the recipe and froze half. We are the frozen portion tonight and it was just as good.  If you are one of those who likes to prepare meals ahead to freeze and have over the next couple of weeks,  there is a slow cooker meatball recipe in allrecipes that is identical to this one, except you add Italian seasonings and omit milk.  They are easy to make at the same time as you will already have the ingredients out. Very good!

I have made it according to directions as well as altering and it's always a hit. My husband really likes the brown sugar and ketchup in meatloaf so sometimes i omit onions and peppers and just add egg, milk, bread crumbs, brown sugar, and ketchup. Then glaze with only ketchup and brown sugar, leaving out mustard. It always turns out great, it's my go-to recipe.

text:
Made this recipe recently and it was the best meatloaf I've ever had!   However ... I made one mistake:   I mixed most of the ketchup, mustard, and brown sugar into the meat mixture.   I caught myself as I was ladling the last of this mixture into the meat mixture, so had maybe about 15% of the mixture still available to put on top.   I'm glad I made the mistake, because I think it improved upon the original recipe!  I'm making it again tonight, and I mixed about half of the ketchup mixture into the meat, and spread the rest on top.

text:
This was a great recipe and I will make it again! As usual, suggestions from previous reviews were very helpful. I used Italian seasoned bread crumbs instead of plain and added a tablespoon of worcestershire sauce. I also used a seasoning blend of chopped onion, green pepper, and red bell pepper instead of only using onion. I will likely add chopped or sliced mushrooms next time I make it. I was afraid I wouldn't have enough sauce so I doubled it. That turned out to be a good thing as it made just enough. The men in my family loved this meatloaf.

Outstanding!!!  I will definitely make this meat loaf again!!!  Followed the recipe and it was very good!!! - Feb 19, 2019
UPDATE:  Tried again for the second time--still outstanding!!!
This time I added chopped onions with red, yellow, and green bell peppers and minced garlic to the mixture.  I also added about five sprinkles of worchestershire sauce to the mix.  For the sauce topping, I used a blend of regular yellow mustard and honey dijon brown mustard.  Makes it a little more spicy!!!     --Mar 8, 2019

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first time making meatloaf and it was a hit!  I am guilty of making a few modifications based on preference.  Sautéed the onions with a bit of butter and garlic just to soften them up a bit.  Added a tbsp of Worcestershire sauce to the meat mix and about a tsp to the sauce.  Topped with a few slices of bacon before it went in the oven because that’s how my grandmother always made it, and bacon makes everything better!!  Used a foil lined baking dish with two pieces of bread in the bottom to soak up some of the grease.  Baked for an hour and 20 mins and served with mashed potatoes and peas.  This made an amazing comfort meal and I can’t wait for the meatloaf sandwiches tomorrow!
