Why is the prep time always so underestimated?

I JUST popped my loaf of meat in the oven. Rated 5 stars ahead of time because I know this is gonna be good! The raw meat smelled good to me and it's similar to the way my mom makes it. I don't think I've ever seen her use milk in hers.

I added a few good splashes of worchestshire sauce and a nice dash of garlic powder like a few others mentioned, along with some spicy brown mustard from another recipe. It looks and smells fantastic!

If it turns out not so good, I'll come back and change my rating. I'm pretty confident about this one though. Thanks for posting this recipe!

None
text:
I modified this recipe because I wanted a version with more veggies. I used 1/4 cup of chopped onion, 1/2 cup chopped celery, 1/2 cup chopped zucchini, 1/2 cup chopped spinach (frozen), 1/2 cup of shredded cheddar, 1 extra egg, and coconut cream instead of milk. For the sauce, I left out the brown sugar and added 1 tablespoon of BBQ sauce, 1 teaspoon of A1 sauce, and a few drops of liquid smoke for a smokier taste. The result was AMAZING! This gave me a beautifully moist and veggie-stuffed meatloaf that seemed like a meal all by itself. So good the pan barely made it to the table. Thank you for a giving me a great starting point!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
great recipe! i made some changes of my own for it being my first time making meatloaf. for starters, ive tried it three ways. i started with making the meatloaf. i used hamburger season ing, adobe, eggs, saltine crackers, little garlic seasoning a few very tiny cubed green bell peppers. i mixed that all up. i took half of the meat in a small square pan flattened it out evenly. then i took thick slices of velvetta cheese (i also used mozzerella and coby jack for the other two times) i placed those slices evenly over top the meat. after tht i then spread the remainder of the meat on top of the cheese. pressing the edges closed. lastly, i smeared BBQ sauce on top (traded it for ketchup, also tried different flavors of bbq) and placed it in the oven. after the w0 mins or so cook time, the meatloaf turned out AMAZING! had slight crunches and cheesy plus meaty. i called it a 3 in 1 LOL

text:
This is the best meatloaf  I have ever made.  My widowed father-in-law  loves meatloaf and every time I tried it,  it was dry and not very good.  I learned that I was using too lean of beef (97/3).  I changed to using 80/20 or so and you can mix it with a sausage too for depth of flavor.  The milk makes it really sloppy when trying to shape it but makes it so moist and delicious! Great leftovers as sliders on those Hawaiian dinner rolls too. Thanks for a great recipe !

ttsmom9103

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/483813.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I just realized I've never reviewed this meatloaf and it definitely deserves one! I've been making it for years, using all different meats.. beef, pork, veal, sometimes turkey when I'm feeling plump. The simplicity of this recipe is what makes it delicious. Don't get fancy people, it's meatloaf! I've  tried TONS of different meatloaf recipes, but always come back to this one. Very quickly you will not have to read a recipe because there are not a lot of ingredients making it easy to remember. I have tried to fancy it up, refusing to believe the simplest recipe is the best. I've sauteed the onions first, but the flavor is better with just raw onions, chopped finely. I've added other herbs and spices, nope, not as good. I wrapped in bacon, not so much and too greasy. Ok, so I do add one thing not on the list b/c I love it so much I could bathe in it... Worcestershire sauce, a few shakes in the meat and a few in the topping. Happy cooking :)

Very good recipe. text:
This was a yummy and easy recipe for a cold evening. I made it exactly according to recipe and found it to be moist and an excellent pairing for potatoes and carrots. I cooked in a 8x9 pan with potatoes and carrots cut up along side in the baking dish. I did cover with tin foil and uncovered during last 15 minutes. Leaving it to set on the stove 10 minutes before serving made it stand up nice on the plate. With a side salad my entire family loved supper. Will definitely make again.

region:

country:
None
text:
I lost my grandma's meatloaf recipe, and I was looking for something similar.  She used tomato juice instead of milk, but I thought the milk worked just fine and reduced the sodium. I would even cut back to 3/4 cup next time; this was very moist, even though I added 1/2 pound ground turkey to the ground beef. I added worcestershire sauce, as another reviewer suggested, and as Grandma did, I added 1 diced bell pepper, and here's where my only complaint comes in - next time I will remember to saute the onion and pepper, so that they are tender, because they were a little too crunchy without that extra step.
Second time I made it, I used 2 lbs. ground turkey, 3/4 cup milk, and I remembered to sauté the onion and pepper prior to mixing them into the meat. Also had mushrooms that needed to be used, so I chopped them and added them to the mixture as well.

I love this recipe and it has become a staple dish in my house. Today I doubled the recipe and this is what I did 1. I always you see a 2 to 1 ratio of beef and pork, not pork sausage just ground pork. 2 . I grated up a zucchini and added to my mix 3. I minced a couple of hand fulls of kale, with out stems minced it up so it looks like parsley. And I  just mix everything together even the brown sugar one VERY big bowl. Next I make a meatloaf and drizzle it with ketchup...yes I know. .but I live with all men  what can I say hince the zucchini and kale wink wink. Then the other half I make up as meatballs and sprinkle with parmesean. ..the real stuff...and bang I have 2 meals!  My guy's really love the meatball subs or just add them in with the sauce. I really like this recipe because you can use it as a base and add or subtract from it. I sauteed  1/2 of and onion, a 1/4 of a red pepper and green pepper, 3 cloves of garlic and 4-5 chopped mushrooms in olive oil and added them to the already mixed mixture of milk (not quite a cup) 8 ritz crackers, and 1/2 cup or so of bread crumbs egg and beef and some worcestershire sauce. I used only 1 spoonful of brown sugar in the topping. Very moist and yummy.  Served with mashed potatoes and a green salad.

text:
This is a really great recipe! I followed other reviewers suggestions and sauteed the onions in butter, doubled the sauce, and used Italian bread crumbs. I also went an extra step and mixed together all the ingredients before adding the beef. I did this to make sure the beef was mixed very well and seasoned evenly. I used 1lb of extra lean beef and .5lb of lean beef. Meatloaf came out perfectly moist. I checked the meatloaf at 50 minutes but ended up leaving it in the oven for the entire hour. It came out very tasty and I will definitely be making it again! Only thing I would suggest is maybe adding a bit more brown sugar to the sauce on top. That might help get rid of the strong ketchup/mustard taste and add more of a sweet taste sweet.

text:
I have been making this recipe for about 4 years and my family absolutely LOVES this meatloaf.  I have never had a complaint!  I don't always have  plain bread crumbs so I usually just chop up whatever bread I have around....I have used left over dinner rolls, wheat bread...anything!  Everytime I make this recipe, I have to stop and consider putting as much milk in as the recipe calls for.  I use the full amount and yes, it does seem soupy sometimes.  I might add a few much chunks of bread in that case,  but you don't have to.  The milk will absorb and cook out.    The sauce is perfect to bring out the beefiness of the meatloaf.   I always have an extra side of it on the table for dipping.   This is an absolute must recipe for anyone who wants a quick and delicious meatloaf!  Thanks for sharing!!

city:

region:

country:

text:
Meatloaf has always defeated me.  Up until now I've never made a decent one.  I used this recipe with variations.
I took out the brown sugar - I hate sweet flavors with meat.  Instead I used Worcestershire sauce in the mixture, and in the topping along with mustard and ketchup.  

I also sauteed the onions before adding them to the loaf.  I like a mellow onion flavor, and one of my family members can't eat it unless I cook the daylights out of it!

All I had on hand for the crumbs was a sleeve of Bacon Ritz crackers.  It made a surprisingly tasty change!  I could smell them very clearly while it was cooking, and I think I'll use those exclusively since this was a big hit.

text:
I've made this several times now.  Its a great and easy recipe. I make a few changes, but nothing that takes away from the original recipe. First,  I use Italian bread crumbs instead of crackers. It adds a little more flavor. I also usually use 2 lbs of ground beef and so I add a little extra of the other ingredients as well. Ex: I use 2 eggs but only 1 cup of milk. Add an extra 1/4 c bread crumbs and a little extra onion.  
I make 2 loafs so I can freeze one for later.  It's a great recipe that I recommend to friends!

text:
I made this tonight and it came out great. I'm a novice when it comes to the kitchen so a easy to follow meal like this was an all around good start. The simplicity allows you to add to it for your own taste, but if you're not brave enough for that you will still get a great meatloaf out of this recipe. I used less onion out of my own discretion, but I took the advice of one review and sauted the chopped onion before adding to the meat mix. For what it's worth to anyone like me trying to start cooking and getting comfortable in the kitchen; I'm a 26 year old male who knows nothing about cooking. If you're interested in cooking and don't know where to start, keep it simple and get rolling with easy recipes like this one. 
Best parts of this meatloaf is that it holds together, its juicy, the topping is easy and tasty, and if you want to add stuff it's doable without really hurting the recipe.

text:
I did what many other said by adding 1 TBS of Worcestershire, adding extra ketchup (almost double), reducing some of the brown sugar, and sauteing the onions beforehand. I also added about half a bulb of chopped garlic, half a chopped jalapeno, and I chose garlic herb breadcrumbs. I never cook and am just getting started trying to learn recipes, and this came out great! I may use more breadcrumbs and/or a leaner meat next time though, as it left a lot of grease in the pan (I used 80% lean beef). But I still got seconds last night and am eating leftovers now!

city:

country:
None
text:
First time I've had meatloaf since I found out I can't eat wheat.  I made it gluten- and lactose-free - I substituted 3.5 slices of gluten-free (semi-stale) bread for the crumbs, just tore them into relatively small pieces.  Instead of milk, I used gluten-free beer (made from sorghum).  I like my onions a little toothy so I used them raw. I did put 1 tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce in the meat mix along with squirts of ketchup and mustard, since that's what my mom always did.  In the topping, I used a little less ketchup and a little more coarse brown mustard, I also completely skipped the brown sugar.  We loved it, my son ate 3 pieces and asked me to make it again.  I look forward to having this tomorrow as leftovers!

text:
An easy recipe and quite good.  I made the recipe as is. Because of my long work days, I made the recipe the night before.  I put the meat in the loaf pan and stuck in in the fridge.  I mixed up the sauce for the topping and left it in a separate bowl in the fridge. The next day, it was easy for hubby or an older child to add the topping and stick it in the oven, so that I didn't have a lot of prep work after a long day at work.  My picky seven year old loved it.  The twelve year old ate it that night and again for lunch and still loved it the next day.

None
country:
None
text:
I have not made this recipe, but do make one very similar and want to share. Same amount of meat, grate 1/4 cup onion, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/4, pepper or more/less to taste. 1/2 cup milk and enough cracker crumbs to soak. Mix all together with 1 egg. Topping: 1/4 cup ketchup, 3 tblsp, brown sugar, 1 tblsp dry mustard, 1/8 tsp nutmeg. Mix well and spread on top. Hope you try it and enjoy!

text:
I made some modifications.  I read the reviews to saute the onions first, but I decided to grate the onion instead.  It definitely intensified the onion flavor without giving me large, noticeable chunks of uncooked onion in the finished meatloaf.  I also added a few dashes of worcestershire sauce, and a bit of garlic powder to the meatloaf mix.  Next time I make this, I might use the meatloaf meat blend of veal, pork and beef for more flavor.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1297881.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is a great outline. For those not used to the idea of brown sugar added to the topping, it's a classic carmelization tool :) it's in many bbq recipes and works amazingly with any meat. I always add a bunch of veggies in my meatloaf, carrots, celery (not too much), green and yellow onions, I love fresh peppers so it's not abnormal for me  to add some fresh jalepenos and/or green chiles. never forget salt/pepper/garlic as they're great in everything. Meatloaf is a lot like lasagna, you can make it whichever way you want. Mexican, american, italian, whatever you feel like or have in your kitchen. Happy Cooking :)

Display Name:
jmjimerson

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made this for my girlfriend she swears it tastes just like the meatloaf her mother made and loved it....I Mean Loved IT!  So it's the only meatloaf I make now. I did alter the recipe  slightly.  only had 1 lb of hamburger added  1 mild Italian sausage link, skinned sliced then quartered and added to to mixture before blending ingredients.  6 slightly toasted bread then cubed. I added two eggs because it  didn't seem to be enough to bind such a loose mixture. I baked the loaf as directed but it seemed to need more sauce so I made a double recipe of sauce. I drained the excess grease carefully out of the loaf pan then topped it again with the sauce and baked it another 30 min.  I'm making it again tonight the same way but plan to slightly sauté the onions   Thank you for a great recipe  and I consider it a 5 Star dinner!

text:
I eyeballed the measurements in the sauce, used spicy Dijon, added a bit of bbq hot sauce and minced garlic, and a bit of taco seasoning for some added flavor. I also added steak seasoning instead of salt and pepper (includes a few herbs) and I used Parmesan seasoned croutons for my bread crumbs. I forgot to add the milk but in the end it was moist and didn't need it. Loved this recipe, so quick and easy and delicious!!

She loves them and my meatloaf loving oldest daughter gets to wink at me and stuff her face. I used smashed chicken stuffing mix and a pre-packaged mix of ground beef and pork from the store to make this tonight. Definitely a winner. As long as we don't call it meatloaf, we'll be eating this again real soon!

text:
My Lady has to have gluten, soy, and dairy free, but Janet this recipe was absolutely one of the best ever, after I made the changes.
I wanted to find out what would happen if I replaced the milk (which I always used)entirely, and replaced with beef broth to keep the moisture. 
Chopped up 1 green bell pepper, and 1 onion, placed them together in plastic bag with 2 tsp of minced garlic, and shake till well mixed.
1 cup of Gillians Bread Crumbs (Wheat, Gluten, Soy & Dairy free).
My Lady and I absolutely loved it,and the beef broth was the best I have ever had. Hope this is helpful for those on special diets.

text:
Very good. I sauteed the onions & added a Tbsp. of Worcestershire sauce, as suggested, to meat mix. I had 1/2# grnd turkey meat so used it as part of meat measurement. Baked 1 hr. 25 mins.  I think the turkey meat makes it extra moist, so if using turkey, cut down on the milk a bit. Also, I should have added more salt to meat mix (cannot "salt to taste" when mixing raw meat). Doubled the topping. My husband loved it. Will make this on again.

Review:
Rating:

userID:
946689
Display Name:
Janis P.
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4220954.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was absolutely moist and delicious!  My husband had thirds.  Couldn't get enough and kept on saying "wow" with each bite.  I followed what the other reviewers did by sautaeeing the onions first and added worcestershire sauce to the mixture.  It's one of my favorite seasonings so I judt had to add it.  I also didn't have regular breadcrumbs only panko so I pulsed it first in the food processor until fine.  Worked really well.   I also doubled the glaze on top.  Doubled the ketchup, the mustard but the brown sugar still 2 tablespoons as I didn't want it overly sweet and true enough, when I tasted it it was just the right sweetness for me.  The entire mixture fit perfectly inside a 9 x 5 pyrex loaf dish.  To be sure about cooking temperatures I stuck a meat thermometer right through the middle but not all the way that it woukd be touching the bottom of the dish.  I wanted to make sure that  it reaches the proper cooking temp of about 160 F.  1 hour at 350 F did just that so the baking time stated was pretty accurate.  Next time I make this I will be using a leaner ground beef as grease just pooled at the bottom of the dish.

I was in a rush and made this recipe ver batim, without reading the reviews first. A whole onion is too much. Definitely sautee first or use onion soup mix. userID:

Display Name:
Jake Ballingham
isPro:
False

7

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1730290.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I mixed it up a bit and my roommates love it. When I sauté/soften the onions with butter I sprinkle about a tablespoon of brown sugar on it. Don't fully caramelize it but just run the stove on about 3. Next I substitute regular mustard with dijon and instead of ketchup I use Stubbs sweet heat. I also use the Progresso garlic and herb bread crumbs. And the real trick is after pressing the first half of the hamburger mixture in the pan I spread a layer of shredded mozzarella then top it with the rest of the burger. It's awesome! I've also used blue cheese crumbles and loved it but some people aren't fans of the strong flavor. Lastly, after spreading the sauce over the top I sprinkle siracha over the top for a little extra kick along with onion powder.

Super simple recipe! I did modify it a little, but used the above for a reference. 2 lbs ground beef (super lean), used seasoned bread crumbs , THEN added Worcester sauce, Dijon mustard, and a red pepper.  I also used my Cuisinart to chop the onion & pepper together, and chopped it to a very fine mixture. That way the onion & pepper were evenly mixed into the meat. Next time, I will add more red pepper & add green pepper. Bon appetit y'all!

text:
I love this recipe.  Only made a few minor changes, sautéed the onions in a little evoo with two garlic cloves minced, added 1 tbls. Worcestershire sauce to the meat mixture and doubled the topping sauce.  Baked 1 hr at 350, drained the grease with my baster and added six partially cooked bacon strips and returned to oven for 30 additional minutes.  Delicious...served with red smashed potatoes and green beans tonight.  Cannot wait to have leftovers tomorrow.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is awesome! I make my meatloaf into bacon wrapped meatloaf cupcakes, so I add the brown sugar/ketchup mixture into the meat and also add a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce. The I line the muffin tins with bacon, fill each one with a good amount of the meatloaf mixture and bake at 350 for 45-1 hour depending on how you like your bacon...also I place a cookie sheet under the muffin tin to avoid any spill over of grease from the bacon and meat...then I top then of with mashed potato "frosting". My family LOVES these!!!

Not bad!  Very simple, with some good base meatloaf flavors.  Too much onion, though.  I scaled the meat/breadcrumbs/milk mix up 50% and used half an onion, and that was still a little much.  That's just our preference, though.  All in all, good recipe.

region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time making meat loaf. Used a little less than 2 lbs. of 85% lean ground beef. Used same proportions of other ingredients. Took tips and sautéed onion before mixing it in. Also added some worcestershire sauce. Used small loaf pan to form 3 loaves and placed them on broiler pan to cook so loaves weren't swimming in grease. Doubled sauce mixture. Cooked for about 1 hr and 20 minutes. Last 20 I increased the oven temp to get some browning. Meatloaf was still moist. 

This was a good base recipe. You can tweak it to suit your taste. I'll definitely play around with this one in the future, especially the topping which I found just a tad sweet.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6540275.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great standard meatloaf recipe. I used a couple different techniques to make it even better. First, I soaked the breadcrumbs in the milk before adding it to the beef. Second, use a room temperature egg. Third, instead of sautéing the onion as some other posters suggested, I grated it on a box grader. I have made meatloaf with sautéed onions and grated onions, my family prefers the grated version because a few don't like the texture of onions. I also added a teaspoon of salt, a teaspoon of seasoned salt, and a heavy teaspoon of pepper. I'll add Worcestershire and some franks next time as well.

text:
Recently made this as I had a tonsillectomy and one of my few approved foods was meatloaf, and I was going a little crazy doing nothing but Convalescing. My dad LOVED it--he actually ate most of it--I found it a little too dry and a little painful to swallow, but I'm not sure if that's just because my throat still wasn't fully-healed or because I used very low-fat beef. 

It was my first time working with raw meat, and I probably could have combined the ingredients in an easier way than a potato-masher, and I didn't have a loaf pan of the right size so I had to use a casserole dish. I also forgot we didn't have any onion, so I went without. Next time, I think I'll double the sauce and try to find a loaf pan to make it a little less lumpy.

It is good as it is but fantastic with a few modifications.  I use Italian seasoned bread crumbs.  Also, I saute the onion in olive oil with garlic and add 1/2 of a chopped green pepper. I have probably made this 8-9 times and always a hit if made this way.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614246.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a delicious recipe and now the only meatloaf I will make. I did use the one and a half pounds of ground beef (90/10) and I also used one pound of ground pork. And because it wasn't a fully doubled recipe (one pound of pork instead of a pound and a half, I used one and a half cups of milk instead of two cups. I made this meatloaf gluten free by using gluten free Italian bread crumbs but I mixed them into the recipe ingredients before adding the ground beef and pork so they wouldn't be crunchy in the meatloaf (gluten free bread crumbs are crunchier than regular bread crumbs). I also (as suggested by other reviewers) sautéed the onions first which made them soft and flavorful. So I did alter the recipe a little, but it was still fantastic and the family absolutely loved it.  The sauce was delicious and even though I doubled it for the recipe, I am going to triple the sauce next time.  I cooked this for one hour and fifteen minutes but next time I will put it under the broiler for a minute after it is done and give the top a little crust, especially with the extra sauce.  MmMm Good!

userID:
1657243
Display Name:
Erin
isPro:
False
followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4526075.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was pretty tasty!  I didn't have an onion so I substituted 1/2 teaspoon of onion powder, & I also didn't have any bread crumbs so I ground up 1 cup of rolled oats.  To push it one step further, I grabbed a handful of baby spinach and chopped it up like you would parsley and added that as well.  It doesn't really add flavor to the food, but it sure does pack in a little more nutrition.  I also took some of the reviewers suggestions and added in some Worcestershire sauce.  The end result?  A meatloaf my kids LOVED and I love the fact that there's oats and spinach in it.  This was a great base recipe that was easy to make subs/additions to.  Next time, I will take some of the other reviewers suggestions and saute a chopped onion (and some garlic) in butter and then add that to the meatloaf.  The onion powder was good, but nothing like the taste of a real onion.  The one thing I noticed when I first mixed everything together was that 1 cup of milk seemed a bit much - it was a very sloppy mixture that I couldn't mold into a loaf in the beginning.  Maybe it was the oats I used instead, but once it sat in the fridge for about a half an hour, it firmed up better.  Next time I will probably only add 3/4 cup milk, especially if I need to bake it right away.  Also, this needs to cook longer than an hour.  Based on other meatloaf recipes I've made, 1 1/2 lbs ground beef needs 75-90 minutes to bake in order to cook all the way through.  I am making this into meatballs next time!

text:
This is a great recipe, I sautéed one green and red pepper, one onion, and about 6 cloves of garlic before I mixed them with the beer, pork and veal mixture and it came out great!!  I also didn't glaze it with ketchup instead I mixed about 1/3 cup of ketchup with it and after 30 minutes I poured a can of brown gravy on it and it changed the flavor completely from the first time I made.  I liked it a lot better and if you pour half of the juices from the pan into a small pot with another can of brown gravy, you've got a great gravy to put on the meatloaf and mashed potatoes to go with it.  Next time I'm planning on laying the meat the a layer of shredded mozzarella and then meat again and a layer of shredded cheddar and then meat again to see how it comes out.

text:
I've been looking for a good meatloaf recipe for years.  This is it. I did sauté the onions in butter for a few minutes, then added a couple of cloves of garlic, and cooked a couple of minutes longer.  I prefer sautéed onion flavor to raw onion flavor.  I also added little worcestershire sauce to the meat because it adds a great savory touch with little work.  I doubled the catsup so I had an enough to generously cover the load, which I baked in a loaf pan.  This turned out great. Held together when served (frequently a problem from past recipes), and was so easy.  I've made meatloaf with 2 times more ingredients and several more steps that was not nearly as good.

text:
I made this for my family and they loved it! I did make a few changes, instead of breadcrumbs I used 1 cup cooked quinoa (my father in law is allergic to gluten), about 2 tbsp of A1 sauce (I didn't have Worcester like the other reviews used), I sauteed the onion in butter, I only used 1 lbs organic beef and 1/2 cup milk. I forgot to grease the pan our use foil but I used a nonstick loaf pan so I didn't have any problems with sticking or cleanup afterwards. It wasn't super greasy thanks to the organic beef and the quinoa helped I think. I did double the sauce and I'm glad I did, but it was kinda sweet, my family liked it but next time I think I'll only use 3 tbsp off brown sugar instead of 4. All in all a great recipe will definitely make it again.

city:

country:
None
text:
This recipe is now a family favorite!  The sauce is what separates it from all other variations of meatloaf!  One day, my sister asked if we should put bacon on top of or in the meatloaf mix, and I responded that we should do BOTH! So, if you chop up three strips (or so) of bacon and put it into the meatloaf mix, and you line strips on top of the sauce on top of the meatloaf, then it adds a nice flavor!  When we don't have onion or breadcrumbs, or if we just don't feel like fussing too much, we pick up a pack of these pre-made seasonings called "fresh takes." They have cheese and breadcrumbs and herbs, and I found that the cheesy taste also makes the meatloaf more flavorful! My suggestions are obviously higher in calories though!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made a lot of mods but used this as a guide as far as ratio of meat to breadcrumbs to egg and milk and cooking time.  It came out beautifully!  Things I did differently were:  I doubled the recipe, besides the onion.  I think there was still plenty of onion.  For meat I used grass fee ground beef and chorizo (2:1 beef: chorizo), used some garlic cheddar bread for the breadcrumbs, sautéed the onion in some butter and garlic.  I didn't think the brown sugar would go with the chorizo so I sautéed some garlic and mixed it with the ketchup.  So my glaze didn't get caramelized like it would have with sugar but it was still really great.  Definitely a solid framework for meatloaf that's easy to modify to suit your taste.

This is one of the best meat loafs ever.  I added Worcestershire sauce (approx 2 tablespoons), sprinkled garlic powder over top before adding topping.  Cooked one hour covered in foil then removed foil and cooked 10 minutes.  Let it rest for 10 minutes and served with creamed potatoes and English peas.  It was wonderful!   I did double the topping because I had almost 2 lbs of meat.  The topping is so good you will want extra.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Just made this recipe last night for my family. It was tasty and well-received, however I did make adjustments.
1. Sauteed onions & 1 bell pepper (finely diced) in butter before adding to meat mixture
2.Used 2 lbs. of ground beef
3.Used cracker crumbs with Italian Seasoning added
4. Reduced milk to 2/3 c
5. Added extra seasonings (McCormick Montreal Syeak seasoning, a dash of Worchestershire sauce and a dash of A1
6. Reduced brown sugar & mustard to 1 TBSP but increased ketchup to 2/3 c.
This baked uncovered in my 350 degree convection oven for about an hour and twenty minutes and was perfectly cooked throughout.
In general this is a fine starter recipe for meatloaf and adapts well to various flavors to meet your families specific tastes. Only 4 stars, however because I feel the ratios of ingredients in the original recipe are a bit off and I did make changes.

I am not a huge fan of ground beef, but I wanted something similar to my grandmother's meatloaf.  This recipe was it!  My boyfriend and I LOVED the meatloaf, and it has been repeated several times since I discovered this recipe a couple of months ago! This one has already been a go-to recipe for me, and it will continue to be one!

text:
Yum! I made this recipe for my husband and I. The changes I made was to not use milk, substitute the breadcrumbs for 1 sleeve of Ritz crackers since that's what I had available, used ground veal and added 1 teaspoon of seasoned salt (1 teaspoon since crackers have salt) and roasted garlic to my meat to intensify the flavor. For the sauce on top I only used 1 tablespoon of brown lightly packed sugar. Also chopped up two small plum tomatoes and tossed it into the meat. Served with balsamic glazed carrots and toasted whole grain artisan bread this makes a great meal to serve to guests!

city:

country:
None
text:
Delicious. My family loved the dish. "This is the best meatloaf I have ever had," was actually said. I followed the advice of other reviewers: 1. sautéed in butter 1/2 large white onion 2. added 3 green onions, chopped 3. added 1 tbsp Worcestershire 4. added a dash of garlic powder 5. tripled the sauce but with a little less brown sugar (6 tbsp mustard, 1 cup ketchup, 5 tbsp brown sugar) 6. baked ~2 hours. Next time I will make even more sauce to serve warm on the side.

text:
1.  Used the following mix for the sauce and it was delicious:
2 tbsp brown sugar
1 tbsp Gulden's brown mustard
2/3 cup ketchup
1 tbsp Worcestershire sauce

2.  Diced, and browned the onions prior to mixing
3.  Used seasoned Panko bread crumbs
4.  Baked for 1:25 instead of an hour. Let set before slicing.

Later I prepared the meat an placed it in the frig.  Later as I was preparing to place it in oven couldnt remember if it was best to cover or not.  so I looked at this recipe on line once again and I PANICKED!! https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4582769.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Oh my gosh...First off, let me say that I love meatloaf. But seriously, this is GREAT!! Easy to make and delicious taste. I made a couple of  adjustments to this recipe though. First, I omitted the onions and replaced with minced garlic. Second, a few people complained that the whole meatloaf tasted like the topping, so I let my loaf cook about 40 minutes and then added the sauce to the top of it. I cut the amount of mustard in the sauce in half. I also cooked it about 15 minutes longer...rather, turned the oven off at 55 minutes into cooking and let it finish out another 20 minutes with the oven off. Turned out perfect! Not greasy at all, lots of flavor thanks to the garlic, and moist as can be. Even my boyfriend commented on how moist it was. :) Happy eating!!!!

text:
I have finally, after twelve years of marriage, made a husband-approved meatloaf!  I cannot describe my previous attempts at meatloaf in ladylike terms, but suffice it to say I had given up on the idea.  I made this recipe while I was home alone this weekend, just because I didn't want anyone to know if I failed again.  This was such a win that he photographed it for his social network sites!  36 hours later, and he has eaten the entire thing and requested another.  He is also sending out links to this recipe among his friends.  This is a winner.  I made it exactly as directed, except I used ground pork.  Thanks for a wonderful recipe! *Update: I make this meatloaf all the time now.  A couple tips I have picked up: one, line the pan with parchment paper: easy serving, easy clean up. Two (I think this one's from Alton Brown), put a couple of slices of bread on the bottom of the pan.  I use the heels that generally don't get eaten.   They help absorb grease, then can be easily discarded after cooking.

Review:
Rating:

dateLastModified:

helpfulCount:

userID:
849226
Display Name:
Shannon
isPro:
False
followersCount:
18

0

303
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2787858.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Scanning the ingredients,  it was obvious that I'd have to add more seasoning to appease our family's tastebuds. Easy enough, so I got down to business. Liberties I took with this recipe resulted in a perfectly done main dish: 2lbs. lean (93/7) ground beef seasoned to taste with worchestershire, sea salt, pepper, garlic & onion powders, dried chives and parsley. I sautéed a small onion with minced garlic in 1 T butter until just translucent, and added it to the ground beef. I used the called-for 1 egg, but scaled back on the milk (used 2/3 c) and breadcrumbs (3/4 c total of a mix of 1/2 c roasted garlic seasoned crumbs and 1/4 c panko). I always use the same topping for meatloaf, which I just eyeball (a combo of ketchup, prepared mustard, bbq sauce, brown sugar, garlic/onion powders, black pepper, ground mustard, and parsley.) I make extra and keep it warm in a small saucepan until serving. I baked it 50 minutes at 350 in a 9x5 glass pan and let it rest for another 10 minutes after removing it. Perfect! Served with mashed potatoes and corn, this will remain in my recipe box.

city:

None
country:
None
text:
Truly the best meatloaf I've ever had!  I too modified based on other helpful reviews: 1. I had 2 lbs of organic beef, so added a bit extra of everything else.  2. I browned the onions in oil and added a garlic glove.  3. I used plain breadcrumbs and added my own seasoning: oregano, basil and paprika, as well as Worcestershire sauce (along with salt and pepper).  4. I tripled the sauce, and used a tad less mustard and brown sugar (I'm convinced the Bone Suckin Sauce hot and sweet mustard is key).  5. I cooked it for an hour and 35 minutes and let it rest for a bit before serving.  Incredible!!

Excellent! I agree with others to double the sauce. A lot of it caramelizes and cooks down, so the extra sauce is welcome. Also, line baking pan with non-stick foil completely or you will be scrubbing pan later. I also added 3 crushed cloves of garlic to mixture and oregano. I left off the milk but added 2 T heavy cream. Also, seasoned bread crumbs.

After preparing this meatloaf many times, we finally have it down to a T on how we like it. Keep the beef, egg, bread crumbs, salt, pepper, mustard and ketchup. text:
This was a very easy to make meatloaf that had great flavor. I used ground turkey instead of beef and the recipe still turned out nicely. The only suggestion I would make is if you are not a fan of mustard, you may want to exclude it from the glaze. The listed measurements for the glaze was more than enough for the meatloaf, so losing the mustard won't affect amount needed to cover the loaf.  My son loved the meat but hated the mustardy flavor of the glaze.

country:

text:
I was looking for a "traditional" meatloaf recipe that didn't have too many frills.  THIS IS IT! This is a great basic meatloaf recipe.  With a few minor tweeks, this was amazing! Firstly, I used 1lb. of ground beef and 1/2lb of ground pork. I used about 2Tbsp of Worcestershire, I used about 3 cloves of fresh garlic minced and I used fresh breadcrumbs as I had a left over baguette that I blasted in the food processor. The sauce - I doubled the recipe, not including the mustard. Added some Balsamic Vinegar and a finely diced Jalapeno pepper for a bit of heat.  This was truly a great recipe - so good there were no leftovers. Next time I make this, I will double every ingredient!

text:
This turned out wonderful everyone loved it.
 I did double the sauce because we are huge fans of ketchup. I also took the advice of some of the other cooks reviews and added the minced garlic and sauteed the onions and garlic before mixing in with the meat as well as adding Worcestershire sauce and I replaced the milk with low sodium chicken broth due to being lactose intolerant.  I then cooked it on the grill indirect heat due to it being so hot out lately I did not want to heat up the kitchen and work the air conditioning anymore than necessary.  This will be my go to recipe for meatloaf.  Thanks for the recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I followed the recipe except I left out the mustard because I am allergic to it and left out the pepper and salt (I am sensitive to salt and hate pepper). I used a meatloaf pan that has an insert to keep the meatloaf above the grease. The problem is that the meatloaf held onto the grease. The breadcrumbs soak up all the grease so NONE dripped into the pan! If I use this recipe again I will cut the breadcrumbs to 1/4 cup so that the grease comes out of the meatloaf. The texture was mushy and greasy. I will also use less brown sugar because the topping was too sweet

text:
I have been making this recipe for over 50 years. We use tomato juice in place of the milk. In place of the bread crumbs, we used crushed saltine crackers or oatmeal. Both make a nice meatloaf that will not fall apart.   Excellent for sandwiches the next day. If you want a less sweet sauce on the top, use less brown sugar.

text:
I actually made this meatloaf recipe in a cupcake tin. I used 1 pound of ground chuck and 1/2 a pound of ground turkey. I didn't have an onion or bread crumbs, so I substituted dried minced onions and crushed saltine crackers. I also added some Worcestershire sauce and Cholula hot sauce to the meat mixture. (My family likes things with some zing to it.) I also added Cholula hot sauce and some dijon mustard to the sauce mixture for on top of the meat. The recipe was really easy to follow and I can't wait to make it again.


I don't know the caloric intake and such because I tweaked it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great flavor - enjoyed by everyone.  Have made over and over again...best served with mashed potatoes of course! I also made a simple brown gravy and added some of the topping mixture and Worcestershire sauce to the gravy to give it great complimenting flavor. 

Notes below. 
I made with 2.25 lbs ground beef and so adjusted other ingredients to: 2 eggs, 2-3 shakes of minced onions, 1.5 cups of milk, 1.5 cups of seasoned bread crumbs (the SEASONED part makes a big difference) and I sprinkled Worcestershire Sauce all over the top prior to putting the brown sugar/ketchup/mustard on the top. 

I made 3x the sauce to put on top as I made 2 loaves with this recipe.  

I also cooked it for the 1 hour at 350F and then an additional 30 minutes at 225F.  Internal temperature 160-165F.

text:
I made this meatloaf without any changes to the recipe, other than using ground pork instead of ground beef, since beef is unavailable here. It was absolutely delicious, and made me a fan of meatloaf for the first time in my life. With the addition of bread crumbs and milk, the loaf is much less dense and heavy than the ones I grew up eating in the 60's. The glaze is indeed sweet, but is a nice burst of flavor ~ especially with the tangy mustard. I'll definitely make this again!

text:
I made this for supper this evening and it was absolutely delicious. I did a couple of things differently which I do believe added to the wonderful taste. I added 3 tablespoons of brown sugar to the meatloaf itself and I also added 1 teaspoon of garlic. Lastly, I cooked it for 1.5 hours instead of the one hour that it was calling for in the recipe. I find that meatloaf tends to be mushy in the middle if it isn't cooked enough. My husband, my 8 year old son and I loved it and will definitely be having it again in the future. Excellent recipe!!!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Good base recipe. I use half ground pork and half ground beef. Finely chopped onion and a couple garlc cloves in food processor, then sauteed in a little extra virgin olive oil. Italian bread crumbs with romano cheese. 1T worcestershire sauce. Mound mixture in center of lightly greased 9" square baking dish and surround with peas (I use steam-in-a-bag, prepared). Cover meat with 3x catsup/mustard mixture and only a tablespoon or 2 of brown sugar. During baking process, I periodically mix peas so they don't dry out. I serve with Chef John's Perfect Mashed Potatoes (sometimes adding blue cheese, cheddar, or garlic to them).

Used Italian breadcrumbs for flavor, added a dash of garlic powder, and mixed a couple tbsp ketchup into loaf. I actually didn't have prepared mustard on hand, so I used a little bit (about 1 tbsp) of yellow mustard - it tasted AMAZING in the "glaze". BF loved the brown sugar flavor, too.

text:
Tonight was my first shot at a meatloaf and I tried this recipe. I didn't add any onion, because my son (or I ;)) don't like onions, so I substituted with some minced garlic. I also used some Italian Bread Crumbs because that is all that I had. I didn't add any brown sugar to my mustard and ketchup sauce, but that's pretty much the only things I tweaked on this recipe. I also gave it an extra 15 minutes of bake time just to be safe :) 
This meatloaf came out amazing!!! I can't wait to serve it to my husband, who is in the military and is away right now. 
New dinner to add to the roster! :)

text:
I have made this meatloaf for 4 years now and it remains a family favorite. The only thing I take out is the onions as my family doesn't care for the texture of the onions in meatloaf.  I do add a bit of onion and garlic powder, as well as some italian seasoning to the mixture.  I also use spicy brown mustard in the sauce. I do have to add more ketchup as others have stated for enough sauce. I bake it on a sheet pan shaped in a loaf and it comes out perfect.

I wasn't sure how many stars to give this because I have to give it a mixed review. The sauce that topped the meatloaf was absolutely delicious. Whether or not I make t his meatloaf recipe again, I will definitely use that sauce again. But after following this recipe exactly, the meatloaf came out too soft & squishy. It was done & I even cooked it longer than it said, but still very soft. I think the problem was the milk. My advice would be leave out the milk altogether because it adds way too much moisture.

text:
Wanna make it fantastic? Next time you make it, add sliced olives, chopped mushrooms (whichever you like most) and drained, whole kernel corn (BONUS: you can actually save $$$ on ground beef this way) to the actual meatloaf mix before cooking. If you're like me, you'll also add crushed/minced garlic and a touch of chili (or spicier) seasonings to the mix for a little added kick. I don't include quantities because I pretty much "eyeball it" according to my mood. Tasty tasty!!!

8274737
Display Name:
kstannard
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614255.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Really turned out amazing; I used shallots instead of onion, as far as sautéing them, I just fried them gently in butter and still near raw, added a teaspoon and a half of pepper, almost a tablespoon kosher salt.  For the topping instead of straight up mustard, I made some with 2 tbs of ground mustard, 2 tsp of vinegar, .5 tsp sugar, mixed well, added 1/3 cup, and tablespoon ketchup, 1.5 tbs of brown sugar, mixed well, and sealed the top of the loaf with the mixture which made it medium rare near the top as it cooked up.  I also used 6 slices of italian bread for the bread crumbs, and made sure the baking dish was buttered.  I didn't need any Worcestershire sauce for this, and it had the fresh red meat at the top cooked to 145 degrees inside.  The whole baking dish was gone in a matter of 16 minutes!
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:
2012-03-08T07:59:39.05

It was amazing!

text:
This is a great, basic recipe that can be altered according to tastes.  Kudos to Janet!

I used Italian breadcrumbs and a different sauce:

1/2 cup catsup
1 tsp cumin (or less)
Dash Worcestershire
Dash hot pepper sauce (optional)
1 tablespoon honey

I form the loaf by hand so I can slather sauce on all 3 sides.  Also I have added pureed vegetables to the recipe with great success.  (One way to hide them from certain children)

Pam T~

This was my first attempt at making meatloaf, and I have to admit, the mix looked WAY too watery with all the milk, so I added in some more breadcrumbs. Other than that, I followed the recipe exactly. It turned out good, but still a little TOO moist for my tastes, I think next time I will cut the milk in the recipe down to make it a little less mushy. It was a good tasting meatloaf though, and tasted even better the next day, although I usually dislike leftovers. I will definitely make this again with a little tweaking in reducing the milk.

text:
I was very excited to try this recipe based on all the reviews I've read here but was diapointed with the end results. Though I followed the recipe exactly I ended up with what is best described as meatmush rather than meatloaf. I found the taste quite bland and used lots of mustard to bring it up a lot. I only added mushrooms and garlic to the recipe. Perhaps using fine bread crumbs was my mistake in the the mushy part of the dish?. I will try this recipe again but will use more bread crumbs and additonal spice to pick up the flavour. As an aside it did make fine sandwiches the next day after a night in the fridge to from the mixture up. Mayo and mustard added to the rye bread for a nice sandwich.

country:
None
text:
I used 1 pound of meatloaf mix (ground beef, pork & veal) instead of the ground beef. As the other reviews suggested I sauteed the onions along with the garlic first and doubled the ketchup topping. I also added 1 T A1 into the mix because I was out of Worcestershire sauce and used seasoned bread crumbs. I lined the pan with foil for easy clean up and let it sit 15 minutes before slicing.  I made this for my aunt & uncle for their 25th anniversary (meatloaf is my uncle's favorite dinner!) and it was by far the best meatloaf I ever made! I am keeping my modified version of the recipe in the family recipe book!!

text:
I've been making this meatloaf for a couple of years and for a family of 6 who hates meatloaf, this is a winner.  My hubby and kids eat every drop of this.  I do make a few changes such as adding about 3tblspns of worthshire sauce, cooking the (only a half onion chopped in butter and using garlic cheese crushed croutons.  I also make more sauce but the mustard overpowers the coating so I only use half of the suggested amount.  

I usually serve this dish with mashed potatoes or a seasoned roasted red potatoes recipe I found on here with brocolli or apsaragus.  Never fails.

Love it! I've made this several times. I can see why people might want to sautee the onions, but we like ours firm so I don't. I always add a good health squirt of ketchup (probably like 1/3 cup or so) directly into the meat mixture. It gets the sweetness throughout the whole meatloaf that way.

Excellent base here are my tweaks: I kept everything the same and added the following: 1/4 pound ground pork. 
1 yellow onion nearly caramelized added to the meat mix. sauteed garlic in meat mix. Seasoned meat mix with lawrys seasoned salt and several shakes of Worcestershire sauce.
For the topping: I added Worcestershire and lawry's to taste. (You can use your favorite bbq sauce too.)

I've never been a huge meatloaf fan but this was wonderful! Followed all the basic suggestions from other reviewers and the resulting meat loaf vanished at dinner time! It smelled so good cooking my kids were lining up in the kitchen counting down the time till it was ready. I did cook for about 1/2 the time without the sauce on the meatloaf. I used very lean beef and turkey and when I went to drain fat there was little. The top was nice and brown though, yum. Added the sauce and finished baking. The end result was a nice crisp top much like the ends we all love so much!

text:
I chose to try this recipe because of it's rating and simplicity. My family and I LOVED it! Even my 21 month old son was begging for more and he is going through a phase of refusing all meat! 

The only thing I changed on subsequent times using this recipe is that I now saute the onions a bit before adding them so that they cook down a little more and are not quite so crunchy in the finished product. I'm not so great at dicing. If I could chop them a little smaller I might not have to do this... but I don't mind since it only take a couple of minutes and a small pat of butter.

text:
So I thought I messed up when I added all of the ingredients, even the sauce stuff, but it was actually really good. I added Worcester to the meat, sauteed the onions with some garlic.  I also added a few cups of fresh, chopped spinach to get some veggies in there.  I didnt have bread crumbs so I used Wheat Thins, ground them up first, instead.  I made additional sauce, ketchup, creole mustard, Worcester sauce, brown sugar, to actually put on top, about half way through cooking.  It cooked for around and hour and a half.  I also took the advice and put bread at the bottom of the pan to suck up some of the juicy fat.  The result was so good!  My people loved it.

No need to line or grease the pan, instead line bottom of pan with bread slices and then place the formed meatloaf on top.  It absorbs the grease while baking and after removing the meatloaf is easy to throw away and clean up.

text:
Awesome recipe!  I've made this recipe a few times now so this time I made a few changes. 1) added green peppers 2)Italian bread crumbs 3) one heaping Tsp minced garlic 4) Mushrooms 5) I sauted the Mushrooms, Green Pepper, Onion & Garlic in butter and once they start to cook down I add 2 or 3 splashes of Worchestershire to the sauted veggies before adding to the meat. For the topping I used one Tbsp of Southwestern mustard instead of regular mustard. Even our picky eater likes it...

text:
This recipe was excellent. Both my husband and son loved it.  I did change it up a bit, using some of the suggestions from the other ratings. I sauteed the onions in a little olive oil and garlic just for a few minutes until the onions were softened.  The topping was a little to sweet for my taste. So I doubled the mustard and ketchup but left the brown sugar the same. We haven't had Meatloaf for years.  This recipe is now back on the list.  Thank you!

This is a really good! I did do a few things different though. I used about 2 to 2 1/2 lbs of hamburger, since that's what was thawed. Then I followed the recipe except for these addtions; a few splashes of worcestershire sauce, green /red peppers, a little garlic salt, & a cup & 1/2 Italian bread crumbs, & last of all a baby food jar of sweet potatoes (that was to add a little extra veggies for my daughter ;)  It cooked for 2 hours @ 350

text:
I made a modified version of this recipe, adding a lot of Worcestershire sauce and several seasonings. I also used BBQ sauce instead (since I don't care for brown sugar). I used about 1/2 cup of toasted bread crumbs and one egg, and the 1 1/2 lbs. of meat held together just fine for me. I baked it at 350 for 1hr and 20 mins and it came out perfect... My boyfriend LOVED it! I personally am not a meatloaf fan and even I had two slices for dinner. I probably won't get to try the leftovers (because of the aforementioned boyfriend). I will definitely use this recipe again.

text:
This was my first time making meatloaf and the recipe made it very simple. It was very moist but too moist... Maybe it's my oven type, I'm not sure, but it took me an hour and 40 minutes just to cook it to where it wasn't pink... It was personally a little bland for me, but still tasty nevertheless. Doubling the ketchup like others had suggested I think made it not cook as well. It kept soaking into the meat and the top layer would not cook. I eventually scraped off the majority of the ketchup mixture to get it to cook thoroughly along with upping the temperature to 400 degrees.

Fantastic recipe - the simplest recipes are usually the best, in my opinion.  Like many other reviewers, I used a couple of the common modifications for this recipe.  I sauteed the onion with some butter and garlic, and added Worcestershire to the meat mix.  I also used quick oats and some seasoned salt instead of seasoned breadcrumbs, since my husband is sensitive to too much wheat.  It turned out beautifully.  Thumbs up!

text:
This was DELICIOUS!! My husband and I have made it multiple times and absolutely love it. We did do one odd thing, however, which made this meatloaf a favorite for us. Not reading the directions properly, we put the ingredients for the sauce inside the meatloaf itself and WOW. It makes it tangy and great for leftovers, as it's so moist. We also added a cup of carrots, a cup of celery, two tablespoons of chives and a clove of garlic to make it more to our taste. Give this recipe a try, you won't regret it!

Super quick, super easy and the family loved it.  I was a bit skeptical about the ketchup and mustard mix but it changes in the oven with the brown sugar in it.   Instead of bread crumbs I used garlic and butter flavored croutons I had in my pantry and in addition I crumbled up some crackers (just to break up the beaf).  The flavored croutons added garlic flavor which was yummy.  I'm glad I made a double recipe!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My fiance and I thought this was a delicious recipe. I stuck pretty close to the original recipe; I had an extra lb of ground beef I needed to use so I just added more bread crumbs (I used the italian seasoned kind), 1 extra egg, a little more milk until I had the right  consistency, an additional 1/4 cup or so of chopped onion (which I sauteed in butter first) and 2 tbsp of worcestershire.  I ended up with enough for 2 loaves and it took about 1 hour, 55 minutes to bake them both together.   I served it with garlic mashed potatoes and sweet corn and it was so good! My son, who doesn't really like most meats, even enjoyed it.   I was skeptical about the sauce but decided to try it anyway and I wasn't disappointed. The only thing I did differently with the sauce was to pour it over the loaves after the first hour of baking. I was worried it might burn. As it was, it carmelized perfectly so my theory is that if I'd poured it on from the start it may have burned but I'm not sure.   Overall, it was an excellent recipe and I'll be making this again often. Thank you!

I did saute the onion and a yellow bell pepper in a little butter to gaurentee softness and I only used 1 Tablespoon of mustard in the sauce, but I had to double the sauce to cover it all. It was awesome, and I think I'm going to use the sauce on chicken next time my husband bbqs..thank you for a wonderful recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a grad student who can't help but play mother to her roommates this recipe has become a staple to make in the morning and have ready to toss in the oven after work/class. I've combined the reviewer recs (tbs worcestershire sauce to the meat, fry up the onions with a little garlic, double the sauce, seasoned bread crumbs) with a few little things of my own. Halving the ketchup in the sauce with tomato paste gives it a bit of a tang and since for some reason we seem to have honey mustard in the fridge more than regular old hotdog grade stuff I've taken to using that - it just adds something a little extra. And bacon, there must be bacon on top of a meatloaf if you have it lying around - layer of sauce, a few strips of bacon, and another layer of sauce. After over a year of making this I've even gotten my mother to swap it out with grandma's recipe from her childhood! Thanks!

None
text:
Great Meatloaf!  I used 2 lbs. of meat; substituted half a cup of hot salsa for half a cup of the milk; added minced garlic; and added a tsp. of Worchester sauce to the meat  and the sauce.  My guests could not stop eating!  I doubled the sauce mixture but would have had enough if I did one and a half times.  We still have plenty left for some cold meatloaf sandwiches we all love!  My guests asked for the recipe. Want a pretty sliced meatloaf?  I add a hard-boiled egg or two, forming the meatloaf around them.  When you slice it you will have meatloaf with a slice of egg in the middle.  Tastes good and the kids love it.  Make sure you let the meatloaf set for about 15-20 minutes before you slice it so it gets firmer.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this recipe with a few modifications & OH MY~~it was THE best meatloaf ever.  I reduced the milk to 3/4 C, I used 1 1/2 C of seasoned bread crumbs, 1 TBS Worcestershire Sauce, 1 tsp cayenne pepper & sauteed the onions as well as 2 TBS minced garlic & 1 large bellpepper in butter before adding it to the meat mixture. For the topping I ditched the ketchup & used 1/2 C honey barbeque sauce with the mustard/brown sugar (& will probably go to 3/4 C BBQ sauce next time I make this) I lined my loaf pan with tin foi for easy clean-up & cooked for 1 hr 40 minutes, transferred to a serving platter & let stand 10 minutes before slicing.  There were NO left-overs; wish I had doubled the recipe.

I took the advise from other reviews and sauteed the onion with a bit of garlic and added a tbsp of Worcestershire Sauce too. I used seasoned bread crumbs instead of plain. As Meatloaf can sometimes be dry, I mixed the bread crumbs with the milk and let it sit for a couple of minutes before adding it to the meat mixture. This will always give you a moist meatloaf!!!! All-inall this recipe was OK. My boyfriend and I both thought  the meat itself was very bland. You definitely have to double the sauce mixure!!!

This recipe is absolutely delicious and so easy to make! I had never made meatloaf before and heard that everyone messes it up on their 1st try. None
country:
None
text:
This was very good, but I actually found it to be a little too soft for my preference.  It was really moist and tender, but it was so tender that I couldn't get one single piece out without it falling into a couple of pieces.  I think I'll use fewer bread crumbs next time.  After reading several reviews, I used chili sauce instead of ketchup because it's very similar to ketchup but it's less sweet.  I also used a spicy brown mustard instead of a plain yellow one.  As other reviewers suggested, I sauted the onion (and cooled it) before adding to the beef mixture.  I also added a grated garlic cloves and half a red pepper to the mixture.  Very good.

I was quite impressed with this recipe. Im not a meatloaf fan persay, but my husband suggested it for something different and decided to give it a try. I didn't have any breadcrumbs with spice, so I added just the normal italian spices. Also with the topping I ran out of ketchup so I added bbq sauce.  I thought it was awesome!  Thanks for sharing this recipe...it was VERY moist, which is a nice change from my dry meatloaf!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great base recipe. I scaled up the recipe for 20 servings because we like leftovers! You'll have to scale the recipe up to 20 servings for my below changes to make sense. I used 4lbs of ground chuck and formed it in to 2 seperate loaves in a 13 X 9 baking dish and cooked for 1.5 hours at 350 then let rest for 15 minutes. Here is what I changed. I used 2 packets of onion soup mix instead of onions. I used no salt or pepper. I used no worceshire as other suggested. Instead of doubling the ketchup as other suggested I added 3/4 cup barbecue sauce. I halved the brown sugar. I subsituted bulgar wheat for half the bread crumbs. My wife said it was the best meatloaf she's eaten!

country:

text:
I've used this with both turkey and beef. Tonight I made a meatloaf w/ ground beef. I was out of bread crumbs and used a combo of oatmeal and crushed wheat crackers. Once I read the ingredients for the 'sauce' I decided to just use a few squirts of ketchup and a few squirts of bbq sauce along with a couple of splashes of worcestershire sauce...I didn't want it as a topping so I mixed it it. I started the 1 1/2 lb. meatloaf at about 425 for about 15 minutes and then 350 for the remaining hour so it cooked for an hour and fifteen and then I let it rest for about 15 minutes. It was moist and flavorful. Really liked the combo of the bbq sauce and ketcup...lots of flavor w/ out being overpowering.

text:
First meatloaf ever and it was a HUGE hit. I wanted something I could make from what I had around the house, and this was *it!* I didn't measure everything out, sort of eyeballed it and it was still fantastic! I did brown the onions in olive oil with garlic and added at least 1 tb of worsteicher sauce to the meat. Also used hot mustard in the sauce, adding more worsteicher to that. I made about the same amount of sauce and it was great. I will make this again and again! Goes great with steamed cauliflower and baked potatoes. *runs off to eat her leftover meatloaf sandwich for lunch*

text:
Great meatloaf, although a tad bland if you don't make changes. Saute the onion with a clove or two of garlic, use seasoned breadcrumbs, and add a tsp. or two of soy sauce. I also used soy milk instead of regular. With these changes we loved it! I'm on a diet that doesn't allow me to mix carbs and proteins, so I made a small part of the meatloaf without the breadcrumbs and the brown sugar and it was also delicious.

city:

country:
None
text:
My changes to this basic recipe: 2 lbs. grnd. chuck; 3/4 c quick oats; 1/2 c catsup; 1/4 c milk; 2 eggs; 1 Tbls. horseradish.  Topping= 1/2 c catsup; 1 Tbls. horsradish; 3 tabls. brown sugar; 2 tsp. mustard.  So really the oatmeal and the horseradish are the major difference. Horseradish is the secret ingredient to give it a great, different flavor. Honestly, I tried meatloaf recipes for years and this is the very best one I've found!

text:
Great! Like some other cooks, I browned the diced onion along with garlic, mushrooms, Italian parsley. I added Worchestershire to the meat and cut down a little on the bread crumbs (I used seasoned) and milk. For the topping, I used 2/3 cup ketsup, 1 Tbsp brown sugar and about 2 Tbsp Mezzetta "zesty" bell pepper relish, and the result was perfect - not too sweet. My fiance loved it, and I can't wait to have the leftovers in sandwiches today. I'm giving just 4 stars since I changed up the recipe but will definitely make again.

text:
Excellent with ground turkey too!  I sauteed the onion with some chopped garlic in olive oil.  While that sauteed, I added milk, egg and 1 T Worchester sauce to breadcrumbs and let absorb. Doubled ketchup to the 2 T brown sugar and 2 T mustard, and cooked loaf exactly one hour.  Super moist with a great flavor.  This is our family's new meatloaf recipe.

text:
I have a bigger family and doubled the recipe. I added garlic powder and 1 tbs of Worcestershire sauce (2 tbs if doubling) and changed the mustard to half yellow mustard and half spicy brown mustard. It offset the sweet of the brown sugar. (don't forget to double the topping if doubling recipe). It had to cook for an hour and a half. We even added a little more ketchup on the plate to dip the meatloaf in. I like meatloaf a lot but I've never made it before. This recipe was fairly quick and easy which is right up my alley! It came out great and we had leftovers!

excellent meatloaf.  I had already thawed two pounds of ground turkey, so I increased the recipe slightly by using two eggs and a rounded cup of bread crumbs to get the right consistency. excellent - with modifications (I made it the original way the first time and it was good but a tad bland for us) Sauteed the onion and garlic with small diced carrots. Used 2 lbs lean ground sirloin/chuck mix and 2 eggs. 1 1/4 cup seasoned bread crumbs.  Added Emeril's steak seasoning, and anout 2 TBS each of Paul Newman's Steak Sauce and Worschester.  Dash of oregano. Instead of the glaze I used BBQ sauce. Everything else stayed the same. It was FANTASTIC. Served with the Italian Peas from this site.  Thanks for a good base recipe!

text:
To me, it's hard to make a bad meatloaf, although I suppose plenty have tried. I followed other reviewers' suggestions and added garlic, oregano, parsley and worchestershire sauce. I did not, however, find it too wet when finally all well mixed. The sauce on top was a little too sweet for me, but not enough to ruin this dish. I think a good alternative would be to use hoisin sauce instead of the sugar to add a little more tang and little less sweet.

text:
Funny story about this meatloaf...I made it last night when I got home from work, using cheap, fatty ground beef that was on sale.  When it was done cooking, the loaf was literally floating in grease.  I tilted the pan over my sink, and holding the meatloaf in with a spatula, proceeded to drain the liquid....along with the ENTIRE meatloaf...into a dirty, soapy sink.  I was devastated!  I made it again tonight using lean ground chuck and it made ALL the difference in the world.  No draining necessary!  This recipe is everything I expect a meatloaf to be.  I think it is even better than my mom's (but I would never tell her that!).  The only thing I will do differently is maybe make a bit more of the ketchup mixture/topping.  Other than that, this is the perfect meatloaf recipe!

text:
Ive been making this recipe 3 years now and its one of my favorites! When I made this recipe everyone moaned at the sound of "meatloaf" but after the first bite they were hooked. I now have to make 2 batches when i make this recipe as there is never enough. I never add all of the milk, i add half and see if i need the rest later. I use minced onions as we never have regular onions in the house. I also used 7 grain bread that was toasted then grated in place of bread crumbs. It gives it a great texture and taste. You can always substitute and add more for the consistency you want. Where the guy got soup on one of the other reviews i dont know. LOL! I always double the sauce but i use spicy mustard thats already prepared(i also squirt a tablespoon in the meatloaf mixture), the brown sugar sauce gives it a great flavor. My family loves it!

The name says it all, easy!  A couple of changes - used 2 pieces of whole wheat bread instead of the bread crumbs, used dijon mustard instead of regular yellow and used about 3/4 cup milk.  I saw that other reviewers sautéed the onion before but I just diced mine pretty small and it was fine.  Next time I'll add some garlic and try the bread under the loaf trick because it did get fairly greasy.  My boyfriend was a big fan as was I.  I will definitely be making this again.

Revised! And the second time was better...  I initially gave this 4.5 stars and substituted herb-seasoned stuffing and evaporated milk for the bread and milk, used 1 lb. of ground turkey, added 1T. worcestershire sauce, and reduced the onion by half. But after Round 2, I now give it 5 stars by leaving the recipe virtually intact. I used turkey again (personal preference) and because I had no bread, 1 c. of store-brand dry (unprepared) stove-top stuffing instead. I used one whole onion and did *not* saute the onions this time.  SO MUCH BETTER. Yay!

text:
This is an excellent and simple homestyle recipe.  My husband is a picky eater and likes good old homestyle cooking, and this was great!  I used lean ground beef, you know, the kind you can buy that says that it's only 8% fat.  I was glad that I did, because the lack of fat didn't make the recipe turn out dry at all and I didn't even have to worry with draining off the fat.  I've since made the recipe with ground chuck, which seemed like way too much fat to drain.  I used seasoned bread crumbs instead of plain, and added Worcestershire sauce as other reviewers suggested.  Great recipe, thanks for sharing!

text:
It's not a very dense meatloaf. But I do enjoy the texture as is. I opted for breadcrumbs, added Worcestershire sauce, and a garlic powder to flavor the meat. I used two eggs instead of one. I added 1/2 cup of leftover prepared Lipton Mushroom Rice Sides. I substituted the topping with good old ketchup. Five minutes before meatloaf finished, I topped with fried onion topping and placed it back in the oven uncovered until topping lightly browned. Delicious. Thank you for the recipe.

text:
This meatloaf was AWESOME!!! I only made a couple changes (I have an unhealthy obsession with cheese). I added a handful of shredded cheddar, and a small handful of cheddar french fried onions... and about 1/4 cup warm water to the glaze ( because I knew I would want the glaze flavor in EVERY bite)
But just the base recipe itself was perfect! It blended easily, held it's shape for me to plop it in the baking dish ( I prefer not to use a loaf pan), and the end resultwasn't crumbly OR gooey. It was exactly as a meatloaf should be! I couldn't be more pleased!
Just for the record... my extremely finicky 6 year old gave it 2 thumbs up, literally!
Janet, your are a meatloaf diva!
Thanks for sharing this recipe... it will be a favorite in our family for generations, I'm sure!

text:
This was very easy and tasty. I made only minor changes to fit what was in my cupboard. I used crutons that I ground in my processor for the crumbs, then chopped the onion plus some garlic in the processor, so that there were no 'chunkies'. After that I also processed up a carrot to sneak in some extra veg. 

I did saute the onion/garlic/carrot for a few minutes before adding to the meat mixture, but besides that everything was the same.

Toddler and husband gobbled it up in great amounts!

text:
This was my first meatloaf and it was easy like the title said. Some people complained of it being too greasy. I used 93-percent lean ground beef and there was no grease at all after baking. I followed others' advice and added worchshire sauce, parsely and a sprinkle of ginger, and garlic powder and Lowrey's seasoned salt. I also added some carrot and green pepper. I would think this recipe would be pretty bland without some adjustments. But overall, it's a great base for creating a meatloaf to your liking. Like others, I liked the sauce, too.

text:
AHHHHHH! I wish I had read everyone else's reviews first! The meatloaf itself was very tasty and moist but the glaze was WAY too much. It should read 1/2 cup brown sugar NOT 2 cups brown sugar. Once we scraped off some of the glaze the meatloaf was very good. WARNING- DO NOT USE TWO CUPS OF SUGAR! I even doubled the recipe to 2 1/2 pounds of hamburger and the glaze was still way too sweet!

country:
None
text:
Perfectly simple with ingredients most already have. I didn’t have to add Worcestershire, Dijon, $5 dried mustard or other ingredients because they aren’t needed. The sauce on top was a perfect tang with a hint of sweet, not overly ketchup-y. I did use half an onion and it was enough for us but I had to cook the loaf for 1 hour 20 minutes to ensure cook through. I also used plain bread crumbs (my mom used to crush crackers which is great but bread crumbs make it fast for busy schedules). It could have been my oven but it was juicy and spot on still. I will definitely make extra sauce! Even my kids liked it so it’s a win.

country:

text:
It doesn't get much easier than this! Such a good meatloaf! I did take the advice of many of the other reviewers and add Worcestershire sauce, extra seasoning (garlic powder, onion powder, paprika, oregano, and thyme), and sauteed my onion before adding it to the meat mixture. I used a mixture of ketchup, BBQ sauce, and mustard for the topping (left out the brown sugar since the BBQ sauce was sweet) and that worked wonderfully! Tasted great! I also used 1 lb ground venison and a 1/2 lb lean ground beef. It took 1 hr 15 min to bake. Thank you for the recipe!

text:
Modified to make this vegetarian and gluten free and it was awesome. To be fair, how I made mine is pretty different from the instructions here because my partner kinda messed up the recipe and incorporated the sauce into the loaf instead of pouring it over top, however it turned out delicious! We are ketchup lovers so we didn’t mind putting a little ketchup over the finished product.

 In addition to that change, we used almond/coconut creamer instead of milk and added a clove of garlic, 1 tablespoon of organic vegan worchestershire sauce into the mix, used udi’s gluten free italian seasoned bread crumbs and changed the sauce as follows: 
2/3 cup ketchup
3Tbs each mustard and brown sugar

Next time i would want to try it without incorporating the sauce into the mix to see what it tastes like. However, I think that was a lucky mistake because we hypothesize that by incorporating the sauce into the mix we could actually forfeit the egg, which would be a great way to make it  for vegans.

text:
This is delicious, and I have made it many, many times.  I make only two changes.  Number one, I use meatloaf mix that I buy at the grocery store (beef, pork, and veal) and number two I make my own breadcrumbs out of 3 or four slices of Original Pepperidge Farm bread which is sweeter than most breadcrumbs.  I cut them into pieces and then put them into the Vitamix on just the "on" button so they get a very gentle chopping.  Then I dry them in the oven on a low setting for ten minutes or so.  Otherwise I follow the directions exactly, and the meatloaf is just wonderful.

userID:

Display Name:
Tammy Mattke
isPro:
False

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7469575.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have been making this for almost 10 years now and it is so moist and delicious. It's a basic recipe. Beef, onions, salt and pepper.  For those who said it was gross and threw it away...really? You threw it away? Then I believe a mistake was made on those individuals part.
One thing I do is combine the bread crumbs and milk first. Let that absorb nicely then add it to your mixture.  Also no need to precook the onions, just dice them instead of chopping. They cook up nice and tender.
Years ago I use to add everything but the kitchen sink into my meatloaf and everyone loved it. Today I believe less is more as with this particular recipe.
Also reading the negative reviews sounds like people are putting the ketchup and brown sugar mixture into the meat itself.  It is a sauce for the top and is VERY good. You can make it as sweet as you like.
Overall this is a super delicious recipe just on its own. You can certainly add to if you like. 
I thank you Janet!

city:

text:
I did a quick search for a new meatloaf recipe. The amount of reviews & 4.5 stars sold me on this recipe without actually reading any reviews or the recipe...I needed to get dinner on quickly. I printed the recipe & I was out the door to get the ingredients. When I finally looked at the ingredients I was  shocked that there were so few...I made it as per recipe, and it was DELICIOUS and EASY!!!! Many times I decide on if a new recipe is a "keeper" by the "taste to difficulty" ratio. Was the recipe worth making again? Many times it's just too much work and the results are just average.  This recipe is the opposite.  I will make this again AND I will make it exactly as written again.  I do have an excellent "go to" meatloaf recipe, but it's quite a bit of work and tons of ingredients. Point being the bar is set high on my meatloaf and this was an enthusiastic thumbs up! I used 80% ground beef and formed it into a loaf shape and put it on a sheet pan. Cooked as directed.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2019-12-16T14:32:29.937

So... I didn’t read the directions initially and I put ALL the ingredients on the list into the meat (including the topping ingredients). Once I realized what I had done, I made another batch of the topping ingredients to place on top the meat. Other than needing to take some of the liquid out of the loaf pan near the very end, it turned out AMAZING! Honestly, I am going to always make it that way going forward. Toppings inside and out! A happy accident!

text:
I am a very inexperienced cook, I can only make a few dishes well but this was very easy for me to make! We're lactose intolerant so I swapped the cup of milk out with water. I also didn't use as many onions (I might omit them completely next time) and I added some garlic salt and garlic powder. I used Bell's Meatloaf mix and one pound of beef since it was serving a smaller group. It was delicious! The sauce was amazing too and my dad had me make even more of it. It was an excellent experience. One tip I recommend is using latex gloves while mixing the meat since you should always be careful with uncooked meat handling, while your hands might be clean, the meat is not!

Display Name:
