photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/682581.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a solid base recipe for a meatloaf! There are numerous changes that anyone could make if they wanted to create a "more complex" meatloaf recipe, but for being toted as an easy one, it is very tasty AND quick in terms of prep. 

I will include a list of change ideas that can be made for those looking for more complex tips.

-Use a mixture of beef and pork, or even better, beef, pork, and veal. This can be found in some groceries already mixed or you can ask a butcher to grind and mix for you.
-Sauté the onions in 1 Tbsp butter until slightly browned.
-Add in 2 diced celery ribs and 1 Tbsp minced garlic when sautéing the onions along with 1 additional Tbsp butter.
Meat mixture adjustment suggestions:
   -1 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce. 
   -1 tsp each of garlic powder and onion powder.
   -1/4 cup freshly chopped parsley or 2 Tbsp dry parsley.
   -Seasoned breadcrumbs vs plain.
   -Whole fat milk vs lower fat variations.
Topping adjustment suggestions (it's a BBQ sauce base):
   -1 Tbsp apple cider vinegar
   -1 tsp Worcestershire sauce
   -1 tsp honey or molasses
   -1/4 tsp smoked paprika
   -1/4 tsp garlic powder
   -1/4 tsp onion powder
   -Hot sauce or cayenne to taste
   -Maple extract, bourbon, whiskey, etc.
Review:
Rating:
5

text:
I cut back to 1/2 cup of milk and added in about 1 cup of shredded cheddar.  I also added in 3 cloves of fresh garlic and pan fried along with a 1/2 an onion before mixing in.   I baked in a more shallow pan since I was in a hurry and cut back cooking time to 40 mins.   This meatloaf had good flavour, was moist and my 7 year old ate without a problem.   Thanks for the family-friendly recipe :)

None
text:
I’ve been using this recipe for quite some time now, with a pinch of garlic powder, onion powder, and oregano. As far as the topping goes, since I was little we always used a ketchup and brown sugar glaze! As I read through the other reviews, I wanted to note that along with the ketchup and brown sugar, I also add a touch of mustard and Worcestershire sauce for the perfect mixture of sweet and salty! I saw that people prefer it in the meat mixture, but in case anyone else has toddlers or older parents that prefer less salt, it’s a nice compromise!

text:
I made a mistake and put too much bread in it. My recipe is very altered from this one.... I add bell peppers and fresh garlic, season my meat with more spices, used hickory bbq sauce and raw honey, pasta sauce because I didn't have ketchup, and for the bread: saltines, low sodium chicken-flavored stuffing mix, and a few croutons. Probably wasn't more than 1 cup of bread but in ground turkey, it turns out too dry.

We made fresh garlic mashed potatoes, green beans, and Sister Shubert rolls. It was a fantastic meal and my husband and I had fun making it together!! :D

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
TRIED AND TRUE
I made this recipe for my dad when it was first posted as he was in a rut as far as what he prepared for my mom.  He liked meat loaf and LOVED this meat loaf. I didn't like meat loaf but did like this one.  So whenever I made this, I made an extra one for him. Three years later when he passed. . .I made this recipe x5 for his Funeral Dinner and got so many rave results that I had to print the recipe in the church newsletter.  I'm thinking that the sauce for it was a very mild sweet tangy sauce without being too overwhelming BARBECUEY (I know--I just made that word up) or sweet--a nice balance of flavors. . .though my taste buds are far from being the end-all and be-all of the Universe. For those who favor a bit of sweet with their savory--try this reworked recipe. It is simple and lets the meat shine through without being too fussy.  If you are strictly a savory type of person--find one with a beef or mushroomy gravy.  One more thing--many people also add changes to this recipe. . .
when I had no onions, I would occasionally add a pkg of dried onioin soup that I mashed up for better distribution throughout the recipe.  Once added mushrooms and that too was a hit.  Don't be afraid to experiment--just keep it simple. . .there are many "add 1/3 C of tomato sauce and 1/2 cup of oatmeal--dry"  recipes with a very regimented blend and they're good too--just different.    I like to KISS when cooking since I am always pressed for time.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6723669.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious and simple; definitely worth a try! I use seasoned cracker crumbs (the kind you use to make a meat and cheese cracker platter for a party, but- of course -smashed to bits) instead of bread crumbs, and threw in some onion and garlic powder along with the salt and pepper. Sautéing the onions in a little butter or vegetable oil with some garlic not only adds flavor, but greases the pan as you put the meat in once its all mixed together. 

For the sauce I use cranberry ketchup and dijon. Together they have a nice kick that tempers the otherwise desert-y glaze.

Made x2 now and plan to make it more in the future!

text:
This recipe was so easy to make and tasted super good! I followed the advice of some of the other reviewers and sautéed the onion in fresh garlic (I used 3 cloves) and butter, I added a TBS of Worcestershire sauce to the mix, and I used Italian breadcrumbs. I also doubled the sauce because we love sauce! I did keep the ratios of ketchup, mustard and brown sugar as written and we really liked how the sauce came out! I don’t think it was “too sweet” at all. And the consistency of the meatloaf was perfect, I cooked it for an hour and 15 min just because some of the reviews scared me that the inside was raw after only an hour! Great meatloaf!

I used 2 lbs hamburger and added 1 tbs Worchester  to the meat ingredients. I also sauted 1 medium red onion, 2 tbs chopped garlic in 1 tbs butter and added that to the meat mixture. For the sauce I used 1/2 c ketchup, 1 tbs mustard, 1 tbs brown sugar, 1 tbs Worchester. 

Cooking took about 75 minutes and it was delicious! Everyone from 16-45 years old LOVED it!

text:
I love this meatloaf recipe and have made it many times. My variation is omit the mustard. I put the brown sugar and ketchup on the bottom of the dish, then add the meat, and possibly some bbq sauce on top if I have it on hand. The ketchup and sugar then bubble up through the meatloaf as it bakes, wonderful! I’ve also turned this recipe into freezable meatloaf muffins for meal prep. Such a great dish, I love it!

Display Name:
TrishDHM

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1065709.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I loved this recipe! I didn't give it 5 stars because I made a few adjustments as well after reading the reviews. I used 90/10 beef so it would be less greasy, as well as a pan that kept the meat on a lifter pan so the meat didn't sit in grease at all. The package of meat was a little over 2.5 lbs, so I used two eggs, 2 onions, 1.25  cup of milk, 1.5 cup of Italian seasoned bread crumbs. I did saute the onions in a little butter as well before adding. At first it seemed like it was going to be too loose, but I continued to mix the meat with my hands and it was perfect. I tripled the glaze, but I cut down the mustard by half and it was more than enough. I cooked it uncovered for 1.5 hours and let it rest about 5 minutes before cutting and it was by far the best meatloaf we have ever had. SO good in fact that my fiancé said it was way better than his meatloaf, and the whole family actually wants to have it for Thanksgiving instead of the traditional ham we make. So thank you! It was excellent.

text:
This was great! I used my copper chef  grilling oven pan. I did use some suggestions from previous reviews, which is why its only a 4...I so wanna give it a 5! I did add about 2T worshtershire, 2 eggs, reduced the milk to 1/4 C and I added green pepper and onion, sautéed the onion and garlic then added the chopped green pepper at the end.  I also added only Italian bread crumbs. I did double the ketchup mix, but I added 1/2 ketchup 1/2 bbq and a splash of liquid smoke. I did use a brush and brushed the top at first and last 15 min of cooking I brushed on the remainder. I did follow advice to use bread slices before placing meatloaf in the pan and worked excellent! MY KIDS LOVED THIS!!  Thanks for the recipe!!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674140.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my first time making meatloaf and this recipe was quite tasty. After reading the reviews, I did make some small modifications. I sautéed the onions in butter like some other reviewers recommended. I also added 2 teaspoons of Worcestershire to the ground beef mix. I cut down the recipe to 6 servings, so if any of you are making more, I would add maybe 1 tablespoon or more of Worcestershire. The recipe also didn’t specify if the meatloaf should be cooked uncovered or covered. I cooked it covered for 40 mins and cooked uncovered for 30 mins. The meatloaf came out perfect! The only reason I’m giving it 4 stars is because I wasn’t too fond of the ketchup sauce. I’m not big on ketchup in general so it’s a matter of preference. I felt that the ketchup sauce was too overwhelming. I’ll have to play around with it in the future, however, the meatloaf itself was delicious. I also read others saying that the sauce wasn’t enough, so many doubled on the sauce. In my opinion, I don’t think it’s necessary. I thought it was just fine. I will definitely make again!

text:
I don't usually do reviews but this meatloaf is a big hit in my home.  All 3 of my young kids will eat it without complaint so any recipe that pleases all of them deserves 5 stars in my book!!  I have made it just like the recipe, but my favorite version of it is with Italian Bread Crumbs, and I like to sub the onion for dried minced onion - it keeps the flavor for me but the lack of obvious onions for the kiddos.  If I make for adults, I salute the onions in butter or olive oil before adding them to the meat.  If they go in raw, they are a little to crunchy for me.

text:
the title says "EASY MEATLOAF" for those complaining, heres what i did, i read the ingredients, knew that i would be changing it up so its not some basic meatloaf,  like sauteing the onions with some garlic, using real bread soaked in milk, adding worcestershire sauce and some shredded up cheddar, a little bit of green stuff, cutting back on the sugar, etc. dont be afraid to make it work, i followed their instructions along with my own ideas and had a delicious meatloaf.

text:
Loved this recipe! I’m not a fan of cooking but this was easy enough to do and doesn’t take much time to prep (about 20 min). I used 2 lbs of beef and made 2 loaves. 
In addition to sautéing the onions in garlic and adding Worcestershire sauce, I also added green bell pepper and cilantro. I’m allergic to egg so I used an egg replacement mix (potato starch) and it held up just fine. I doubled the amount of ketchup but didn’t change the mustard portion. Can’t wait to eat this again for the rest of the week!

Per the other reviews/suggestions, I sauteed the onions with some minced garlic, used seasoned breadcrumbs and a few dashes of worchestershire sauce.  Next time I will also add more more salt and maybe even sub in some vegetable juice for the milk to give it more flavor.  My family liked the sauce/glaze, but they wanted more of it, so I will make more next time.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

text:
For my first time making meatloaf, I really enjoyed it! There were a few things I'd do differently next time, though. The meatloaf was super moist, and I didn't even use the full cup of milk, so next time I would use less than 3/4 cup. I also think that seasoned bread crumbs would add more flavour to it, or maybe just mix some seasoned with some regular. I also added a green pepper, and cooked it for about 80 minutes. Overall, my sister loved it so I was very satisfied with this, and will definitely be making meatloaf again in the future!

text:
I sauteed onions with garlic then added them to the meat mixture.  I listened to other reviews and added 2 tbsp of  worcestershire sauce to the milk mixture.  I reduced the brown sugar to 1 tbsp and only used 1/3 cup of ketchup and 3 tbsp of mustard.  I also used just over 3 lbs of meat so I doubled most of the ingredients, eggs, italian bread crumbs, onions, and 1 1/2 cup of milk.   I'll rate it after they eat it tonight.  Done; maybe 1 hour was too much because the top of the meatloaf burnt.  I'll try again for a shorter period of time &/or eliminate the sauce all together.  Will update when done next.

userID:
24969996
Display Name:
RobinM
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
24
favoritesCount:
372
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Like other reviewers, I tweaked the recipe. I like meat loaf to be solid so after reading several reviews that said this was too mushy, I used only 1/2 cup milk. Several reviews said it was too bland, so I used Panko Italian style breadcrumbs  for extra seasoning. Because I don’t like to chop onions and the recipe was vague about the amount of salt to add, I used one packet of onion soup mix for both onion flavor and salt. I threw in 1/2 tsp of black pepper and it looked like enough. I shaped into a loaf and placed into an oblong casserole dish so the grease would drain out. Me and the rest of the family loved it!
Review:
Rating:
5

userID:
16169801
Display Name:
Olya A
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
11
favoritesCount:
3
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5966761.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this recipe many times but I have adjusted it quite a bit. Firstly, know that it works with turkey or beef.  Secondly, there is no need for the sugar at all. 

I am wheat free (which makes me gluten free most of the time as wheat is in everything), I have replaced the crumbs and milk with greens. Instead of those two, I usually use a pound of spinach or a mix of hardy greens. I pan fry them to wilt them first, then drain and chop them once cooled a bit. Because the greens have so much moisture, they make the meatloaf very moist and a healthier option as well. As the greens cool, I pan fry my onions. Then I mix everything in a bowl with spices (I have a mix I love to use that has thyme and rosemary and other herbs as well as pepper and salt as a blend), and after spraying oven safe dish with a cooking spray (Avocado oil in my case as it has a high heat tolerance) I spread the meat mixture into my dish.

For the sauce, I have used a mixture of ketchup/bbq/Dijon mustard, and I mix to taste so proportions vary. I have also used a creamy bell pepper dressing mixed with ketchup and mustard as well for a twist on it. 

Also, because I’m in the mountains at over 5000 feet, I always change the cooking temp to be a little higher. So in this case, I cook at 375F.

Hope you enjoy the recipe! It’s a great base to adjust to your family’s tastes.
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2019-01-21T23:15:37.657
helpfulCount:
0

text:
I made this according to the recipe, other than doubling the main recipe and tripling the glaze recipe. I used 80/20 ground beef. Next time I'll use 90/10 just to reduce the amount of grease released. I made it in a 9x13 pan as a full-pan and it came out awesome. Everyone loved it! I paired it with mashed potatoes and sweet peas for sides. Great dinner with only a few minutes of prep. In total I think we had 90 minutes from entering the kitchen to serving the table. Clean up was a breeze.

text:
3 times:  #1 a little sweet for me, #2 tweaked w/ half onion/ half green pepper 4 star, #3 same as #2 except reduced brown sugar to 1 Tbls. and made 2 loaves side by side in a 9/9 glass pan, to me 5 Star. Shortened bake time & better topping coverage. P.S. check with meat thermometer might not take the full hour. #1 & 2 took 1.3 hours.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/393834.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent base for meatloaf and you won't be disappointed with it as is.  I have made a few adjustments to suit my family's tastes.  I replace a few tablespoons of milk with ketchup and add some celery to the mix.  I mince my regular bread and the vegetables in the mini food processor so they are the texture of relish; a very small mince (kids, you know!)  I also add some thyme with the salt and pepper.  I love the sweet/tangy topping.  I use a little less sugar, though.  If I decide to make gravy, I omit the topping.  Wonderful recipe..I recommend this as a guideline to those who ask for the recipe I use..and encourage them to adjust it to taste.

text:
Doubled recipe.  
-
Added sausage, dried onion rings, diced tomatoes - zesty chili style, oats, Horseradish.

-Substitutes:
Meat: 2 lbs. ground beef, 1lbs. sausage, 
Milk: 1 can of dice tomatoes add milk to make 16oz.,
Breadcrumbs: 2 tbls oats, add dried onion rings, crushed, to equal 16oz.,
-
Omitted: chopped onion
-
Added: 2 tsp. garlic powder

Topping: add 2 tbls horseradish, or to taste.

text:
This is a great recipe and pretty close to what my mother use to make for family dinners. What I found to make it just right is replacing the katschup with a nice smokey BBQ sauce and using sweet onions (I prefer vidalia but all work). I also use the BBQ sauce on top instead of the brown sugar mixture. You still get the sweetness without it feeling like dessert. As well as  Italian bread crumbs. Hope this helps!! (Usually I serve it with cornbread green beans and sweet tea! Yummy)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is very similar to the meatloaf our family has made for over 50 years. However, I can’t imagine how it would taste without the spices we always use. In the meat mixture we add 1/2 teaspoon ground sage. In the topping we add 1/4 t nutmeg and 1 t dry mustard. I replace these spices every six months for optimal flavor. Also, the original recipe calls for crushed saltine crackers instead breadcrumbs. I use the unsalted top crackers if I’ve added salt to the mixture. This makes wonderful sandwiches the next day!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-19T23:10:37.15

text:
I actually increase the brown sugar mixture just a little and I almost  double the ketchup, (since my men can drink ketchup lol), and add some to the hamburger as well as pouring on top. I also do not buy breadcrumbs so when making any kind of a meatloaf I will use old cereal, corn flakes, chex, or potato chips! Flavored potato chips are super yummy! My husband and boys LOVE THIS and have to have it with mashed potatoes.

text:
Great tip,for all of you meatloaf makers, spray your pan with non-stick spray, then use about a 3"wide strip of parchment paper, long enough to hang over the ends of your pan.  When your loaf is ready to cut, run a knife along the long sides if needed, then just lift the whole thing out of the pan with the parchment "handles".

text:
This is very much like the meatloaf I make. I don’t generally measure, but I probably only use 1/4 to 1/3 c of fresh bread crumbs, and enough milk to make soggy. My “secret ingredient” is about 1/2 tsp of sage, depending on how much meat there is. You will not taste “sage.” It just adds flavor. I also use seasoned salt, such as Lawry’s. I make extra topping, because it makes a great spread for your cold Meatloaf  sandwich. Ease up on the brown sugar to your taste.

Rating:
4

text:
My new go to recipe for making meatloaf.  It is very easy and very delicious.  I have used several over the years.  When I lost my favorite one, I found this one on the internet and now it is my favorite meatloaf recipe.  I have been using this recipe for about 2 years now.  I have even used this recipe with substituted ground lamb and ground bison and it works well with both of them.  I usually up my ground beef, ground lamb, or ground bison to 2 lbs and I just adjust the recipe accordingly.  I even have my picky daughter eating this meatloaf.

text:
I've made hundreds of meat loaves over the years but this is by far the best I've ever made. It's simple, quick and extremely juicy without falling apart when you cut it. I used ground chuck (no idea what the fat content was but I'm guessing it was an 80/20 mix). The only changes were to add some Italian seasoning since I only had plain bread crumbs and I didn't make the ketchup/brown sugar glaze for health reasons and it doesn't appeal to me. I'm done with experimenting on new recipes. This is my go to from now on.

None
text:
The meatloaf was delicious and the recipe is awesome. 

If you’re going to complain it’s undercooked when thousands love this recipe, get your oven checked or cook it longer. 

If you think the sauce is too sweet before you even taste it, don’t add as much sugar.  Add sugar to taste.

I added a tablespoon of Worcester sauce and the meatloaf was a little loose, but it was absolutely delicious.  

Thank you for sharing!!!

text:
Yum! 
Some customizations: I used one  pound of ground beef and 1/2 pound of ground pork, both purchased at the local farmer's market, and half of the breadcrumbs that I used were from a ciabatta bread baked at a local dairy farm and purchased at the farmer's market, and the other half were 4C Seasoned Breadcrumbs.  I cut back on the amount of milk, and used just enough to keep the mixture moist.
This might have been the best meatloaf I've ever made.

text:
I made this recipe based on the ratings. When putting it in the oven I thought, hmm there's not much seasoning or flavor in this besides ground beef, onion and the toppings, I hope I added enough salt and pepper.  While it was cooking for an hour (it came out raw in the middle) I read some reviews and noticed everybody added something to this recipe. And you need to, it came out bland as hell. Gnarly is the first word that comes to mind. Waste of money and time.  Needs at least worcestershire sauce and garlic powder, and I regret not thinking of this before putting it in the oven. This recipe is a starting point, but on it's own it's gross.

Display Name:
Susie C

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4766637.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not a big meatloaf-lover, but I did really like this and will use this as my go-to recipe going forward. I made some changes after reading reviews, and I also improvised slightly. After reading reviews, I lightly sautéed the onions with garlic, and a few mushrooms and green pepper. I reduced the brown sugar to about 1 TBS but only because that's all I had. 
Here were my more improvisational changes and I'll share my final thoughts:
I only had 1 LB of grind beef so that's what I used
I used about 3/4 of a large yellow onion
I added 3 cloves of garlic, 5-6 chopped mushrooms, and 1/3 chopped green onion to the onions then lightly sautéed in butter. I used just under 1C of italian breadcrumbs and about 1/3 of that amount I included some crushed herb crackers which I think was a great touch in the end. I didn't have milk so I used low sodium chicken stock. 
For the sauce: I used slightly less than 2 TBS of dijon mustard (I would use the full amount next time though), and I used about 1 TBS of brown sugar based on some reviews. The sauce was actually amazing and way better than just ketchup alone. It was the perfect amount for 1 LB of ground beef so if I had more meat I would increase the portion. *My end result was not incredibly "meaty" since I had so much veggies and didn't follow the recipe exactly; BUT my husband LOVED it and he is a big meat eater. I will make this again - it was SUPER simple and tasted a bit different (better) than the traditional more dry, meaty meatloa

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Amazing with a few additions!! I have 3 boys so I use 1 lb of beef and 1 lb  of Buffalo. I also Brown the onion as suggested by other users and added 1 Tbs Worcestershire and 1Tbs liquid smoke with no change to to the other ingredients in the loaf. Since buffalo is not as fatty/moist I change the sauce a little. For starters I double the amount of sauce because we like extra to have on top of each slice. I also add 2 Tbs of mayonnaise and 2 Tbs barbecue sauce for additional flavor. After pouring over the meat I layer bacon over top and bake covered in a roasting pan for the first 30min then uncovered for the last 30min. If the bacon isn’t quite crispy enough I broil a few minutes until desired crispiness. The bacon adds extra fat so be sure to skim off Tom of sauce after done cooking before pouring over each piece.

I had been using another recipe for years my hubby didn't like it so I rarely made meatloaf. I looked online for recipes and tried a few. This recipe has been the best, however I make the sauce differently after the first time making it. The sauce is very sweet. I just add less brown sugar.
The meat is tender, juicy and has a sweetness from the sauce but leaving out some brown sugar makes this perfect. I recommend it just go easy on the sugar unless you like sweet meatloaf.

text:
I am a perfectionist when it comes to cooking. For years I have had trouble finding just the right ratio of wet and dry ingredients so my meatloaf would be either dry, greasy, or crumble. I did follow this recipe but not exact. I used it as a guide. I had used 3 pounds of ground Chuck it was a extremely lean meat so I made sure to season and add a little extra moisture to make sure the meatloaf didn't end up dry. I think this recipe is great. Some of these comments are ridiculous really it's not like you can't add extra seasoning. And if you think it's to soupy because of the extra milk it's called add more bread crumbs that's what I did. Turned out amazing. Way to go poster.

I’ll start off by saying that I made only 1 substitute, instead of beef I did ground turkey. I also did 1/2 an onion instead of a whole. I followed the recipe exactly aside from these two things and it turned out horrible. It was lacking flavor majorly and seemed wayyyy too moist. The sauce on top just tasted off as well. Not sure what went wrong but I would suggest anyone who follows this to start off with less milk and add more as needed when your mixing. I would also suggest some additional seasonings and an adjustment to the sauce on top. This recipe has potential with some adjustments but main thing is lack of flavor.

I made this last night for dinner. I followed the recipe except for a few changes. 1) I added minced garlic (1 clove) to my beef. 2) I had Ritz crackers (no breadcrumbs) in pantry so I crumbled that up and used it. 3)Only added ketchup for sauce (did not have any brown sugar). My family LOVED it. I am so glad I tried this recipe.

5 stars for simplicity, but then I WAS talking as I prepped dinner and just carelessly mixed all the ingredients together (no glaze). text:
I followed the changes on the first review. Sauteed onions and garlic with butter.  I also changed the meat mince to a pork / veal mix and used Panko bread crumbs.
Switch out the brown sugar with a tablespoon of molasses (or golden syrup). Splash a teaspoon of Tobasco into the sauce to liven it up.
This recipe produced a delicious and balanced savoury flavour that will be on my home menu for a year to come or more!

I have a family of 6 (4boys) and they tear this dish up! It’s a very simple and incredibly easy meal. I love to fall back on this recipe on my lazy after work days. I think it’s a basic meatloaf recipe that if your new to meatloaf, this is the best one to start with. You can tweak it to your preferences later.

text:
Excellent results. As suggested by others, I sauteed the onion with 2 teaspoons crushed garlic before adding and also put in one tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce to the beef.  I used Stubbs BBQ sauce instead of ketchup. Meatloaf came out nicely firm rather than crumbly. I used Panko breadcrumbs. My pan was a Williams-Sonoma Goldtone meatloaf pan with lift out tray. Finished off with a bottle of Kendall-Jackson Pinot Noir and a Magnum Mini ice cream bar for dessert.

text:
I have been making this recipe for months now. My husband doesn't even like meatloaf, but he loves this meatloaf! So does my mom, my kids love it, and I could not be happier that I found this. It is important to use high-quality low fat ground beef in order to get the desired result. If this recipe is followed exactly, it is amazing! Every time I make it, my mom begs me to send her leftovers. My husband is in the car business and works long hours. He has brought left-overs to co-workers just to show off! Thank you so much for sharing this. I make it at least once every two weeks. I never leave reviews, but I just had to for this recipe.

userID:
3546987
Display Name:
mary
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674163.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used 3 pounds of ground beef 80/20. I soaked  1 pint of 1% milk and  1 sleeve of saltine crackers together. I added  1 cup of chopped onions, green bell pepper,red bell pepper and parsley. I seasoned with powder roasted garlic, slap your mama, 2 eggs and  some curry powder. I mixed it all up and shaped it into a 13x9 inch  oiled pan. I baked it for 1 hour at 350. I poured off the fat and poured  brown gravy over the top and baked it for 30 more minutes. I served the finished dish with white fluffy rice and  steamed broccoli florets. YUMMY!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My first meatloaf. Made with ground turkey and Italian sausage, red onion (not sautéed as some suggested, I liked the texture better) and mushroom, both diced fine, seasoned Italian bread crumbs, and bunches of spices. Covered for first 45 minutes of cooking in glass dish, then cooked another 15 uncovered, pouring out extra liquid in between. I also made my own sauce mix with BBQ sauce, Worcestshire, A1 and a little horseradish sauce, don’t like too sweet, gave it a little kick. I put a layer down the center of the loaf too. Yum.

text:
Mmm.  Mine turned out so tasty, and MOIST.  I used a trick I found on another meatloaf recipe.  Place a pan of water under the meatloaf.  Just an inch or less, so it heats quickly and steams.  Makes all the difference.  Meatloaf is very moist and tender.  Oh also I added a tablespoon of balsamic vinegar to the sauce, to level out the sugar a little.  But then I like vinegar in a lot of my sauces.  Deliciosio!

Display Name:
Patches O'Rourke

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6503987.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it. Used ONE teaspoon brown sugar [any meat loaf recipe asking more I think is suspect as error or typo!!]. Used crushed (pureed) tomatoes, added dash of worcestershire sauce & abt 1 tsp dijon mustard to this mix for topping. No bread crumbs so used crushed crackers mix (-4 roasted  onion flavored , 3-herb/spice mix and 3 seasalt&pepper crushed crackers plus some panko [all gluten free as it happens]. Added 2 tablespoons tomato puree to meat mix plus S&P & 1 grated carrot plus celery powder. No milk so used 1/4 c 5% plus bit of water. Cooked 45 mins then removed from oven to add more of the tomato sauce topping. Back to oven for 15 (turned oven off after 5 mins & let sit in oven for another 10). It was good but next time may add a bit more 'zing'.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
A few changes... Used 1/2 an onion minced. Sauteed the onions with minced garlic and butter. Used half the amount of salt and pepper. Used 1 lb of venison with .5 lb pork. For sauce I used can of tomato sauce with 2T brown sugar and 1t Worcestershire sauce. I ignored the mustard/ketchup bit. Any saying sauce is too sweet it is not the brown sugar. It is the ketchup with the brown sugar as ketchup already has so much sugar in it so mixing the 2 is overkill. That is usually how I make my sauce. I also don't put the sauce on top until halfway through cooktime and put a sheet of foil on top for remaining half hour. Wanted to try a twist on my meatloaf and this recipe was a great addition with some tweaking.

Review:

2018-07-02T02:09:00.56
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
23894687
Display Name:
BenOrtega
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Decent recipe but omit the brown sugar unless you want your dinner tasting like a dessert, if you really want to kick this up try my variation, double the ketchup and add just a couple drops of your favorite hot sauce (tabasco, chalula, ect) for the topping. Add Worcestershire sauce 3-4 teaspoons, use stove top stuffing instead of bread crumbs. Mix 1-2 to 1 cup shredded cheddar cheese and a half cup Kraft parmesan cheese or freshly grated real parmesan. Other tips to make it easy if you hate chopping and prepping stuff like i do is use dried onion flakes instead of cutting your own....these are amazing because they soak up tons of yummy juices and end up being just as good as sauteed onions with out the hassle, and using the pre packaged minced garlic, saves time and money as well, about a tablespoon.....or 2...or 3 or more of you really like garlic...lol...another alternative I've used for the topping and is always a hit, instead of ketchup use your favorite bbq sauce. Another ingredient i use once in a while is some bacon crumbles, especially if I've got some Apple wood smoked bacon....that's especially Yummy with the bbq sauce topping. Last suggestion, if you've got the patience and the equipment....instead of the oven.....try letting your creation come to life in a smoker....takes hours but worth the wait!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2018-07-02T01:26:49.5
helpfulCount:
0

Fantastic meatloaf recipe. I cook this every month for my husband. The only critique I have is I usually make 2 pounds of this meatloaf, and the recipe calls for 1 and 1/4 egg and 2 is actually needed. But that might just be personal preference. If I use less than 2 the meatloaf ends up being a little dry. Regardless thank you for making a recipe I have used for years!

text:
Turned out fantastic. I doubled the meat and therefore doubled all the other ingredients as well. I did use a little bit less brown sugar in the sauce and I think it would be good without any added sugar as well.
To the meat mixture I added sauteed onions and garlic, a handful of cheese, a splash Worcestershire sauce and a bunch of spices.
I have never had a meatloaf this moist and juicy before, it was bursting with flavor. Definitely husband and toddler approved :) 
Will make it again

My family loved this meatloaf! I sautéed the onions to soften them before adding them to the mixture and used garlic salt with parsley and a pinch of kosher salt. I served  the meatloaf with the following sides:italian green beans with potatoes and mini corn cobs.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I actually love meatloaf because when you don't know what food to cook thats quick and easy meatloaf is the #1 go to . Also, it isn't expensive either because all you need is ground beef, ketchup,mjustard,salt&pepper, bread crumbs or cracker, 1 egg and garlic. I know a lot of people put BBQ sauce or spaghetti sauce on top of their meatloaf but, I suggest they put nothing on top of the meatloaf it just taste better to me thats one of the things I would change about how people make their meatloaf. The best side dish to go with meatloaf would be Garlic red potatoes or even regular fresh potatoes and some dinner rolls would just make the meal more amazing. Lastly, I recommended meatloaf when your trying to make something quick that taste good at the same time.

text:
I've made this recipie many times now and everyone loves it! I follow the recipe with 2 minor change saute onions with 1-2 cloves garlic.  Make in a silicone muffin pan.  To do this roll the meat mixture into about 2 inch diameter balls and bake for about 40 mins.  It's a little more work but does it ever freeze nicely for a quick meal later. Plus it's a perfect portion size and my SO loves to call them "man muffins"

text:
The milk was the perfect ingredient to the perfect meatloaf! The only adjustment was using Saltine Cramer crumbs instead of bread crumbs. After making this the first time and finding it a bit oily, I now shape the mix into a loaf (no need for a loaf pan!) and just put it on a cookie sheet sprayed with Coconut oil to cut the grease down to a bare minimum, it was still the moistest meatloaf we’ve ever had! This recipe is a keeper!

text:
This recipe is really good.  It always turns out moist and flavourful made just as the recipe is written.  The sweet and slightly tangy glaze along with the onion in the meatloaf makes it a keeper for us.  It is easy to make and one nice feature is that it holds its shape very well so you can bake it in about any type of dish or pan.  Serve with mashed potatoes or mac 'n cheese and your favourite salad and you have a full comfort food meal.

I was needing some warm comfort food. Meatloaf came to mind. I'm thrilled I chose this recipe. It was simple and truly delicious. The only thing I did different was  I swapped the ketchup for steak sauce and added minced garlic. I prefer earthy and savory. This was the best tasting meatloaf I’ve ever had. I have made this recipe several times- I’ve used ground beef but also ground turkey and ground lamb. I personally love mustard so I didn’t change anything about the sauce. I use seasoned bread crumbs in place of plain, green onion (and a lot less) in place of a regular onion. I add a splash of Worcestershire sauce. Thanks for the recipe and "correcting" my decades-old behavior. hahaha Old dogs DO learn new tricks.

I agree with some of the others.......please rate THIS recipe.  When you start adding this, that, browning, adding turkey meat, celery, etc. you are changing the recipe completely. The idea is make and rate this recipe, not make your own recipe and pick this one apart.

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2018-03-13T14:11:25.07
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
17200748
Display Name:
Cassara Wagner
isPro:
False
followersCount:
5
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
6
favoritesCount:
50
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5217874.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This meatloaf was a simple recipe to follow. However it is very plain, it's a great base for someone to get creative with! I followed to advice from previous comments adding Worcestershire sauce to the meat mixture(just eyeballed it, maybe about 2.5tbsp). I also added garlic powder, basil, parsley, thyme, and oregano. I mixed in Italian seasoning with my bread crumbs. I caramelized the onions in butter and garlic before adding to meat mixture as well. I also added some more cheddar cheese, my family always made it like this. For the sauce I used ketchup, yellow mustard, Worcestershire, brown sugar, and Sweet Baby Rays BBQ. I didn't measure out anything, just mixed until it tasted good, living on the edge a little. I lined the glass cookware in tin foil which made for a very easy cleanup and also allowed me to take the meatloaf out of the pan for easier slicing. I added about 20 minutes to the cooktime labeled in the recipe to ensure a fully cooked meatloaf. The time ended up being perfect! I made zucchini and squash as a side, half in the oven with a garlic and herb steak seasoning and olive oil, half sauteed on the stove with garlic, onion powder, and the same seasoning. I also served it with Knorr's shell noodle packet. This was my first time making meatloaf so I was very nervous when my boyfriend's friend came unexpectedly for dinner. They both LOVED it and even went back for more! Great recipe and will definitely be making it again!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-03-12T17:41:00.037
helpfulCount:
0

text:
The past few years my husband has been making his moms meatloaf recipe which uses applesauce instead of egg. It’s good, but nothing special. This recipe is special. My husband also has approved it. I used 1 1/2 lb ground beef, 1 egg, 1/2 on onion, 1/2 a green pepper, bread crumbs, garlic powder, milk, salt and pepper. I did NOT sauté my onions and don’t feel they need it. I just dice them super fine. I made the top sauce as is and it is so good!  Baked at 350 for an hour then 425 for about 15minutes to get the outside nice and dark. Delicious!! We will be using this instead of my mother-in-laws recipe from now on.

text:
Made this meatloaf as recipe called for, but did sauté the onions in butter and minced garlic.  Once done, I added them to the meat and mixed everything together, adding 1 tbs of Worcestershire sauce.  Baked in the oven in a 13x9 glass pan for 60 mins.  Meat was very moist, maybe even too moist as it didn't have texture.  I definitely didn't like the sauce topping.  It made the dish too sweet and while baking, it smelled like I was baking hot dogs - yuk.  My mom's meatloaf never had a sauce topping so perhaps Im not accustomed to the idea.  It also makes a lot of food so I probably won't make this one again.

Meatloaf is one of my husband’s favorite dishes.  I’ve never had a set recipe.  I made this the first time and I got carried away just putting all the ingredients in the bowl, I mixed it all together and then I read the instructions.  I had put the topping in the body. text:
So delicious.  I'm almost 40 and this was my first time making meatloaf. I added adobo, sautéed onions and a few slivers of green pepper along with all the ingredients.  I also added a bit of garlic powder and Italian seasoning. I followed other reviews and cut the mustard in half and use 1.5 tablespoons of brown sugar as opposed to 2.  BTW I was going to skip the topping sauce as I didn't have brown sugar but it made allllllll the difference. It came out super moist and yummy. My teenage picky eater loved it and had 3 servings. Next time I will add a few more veggies to see. Thank u!

text:
I am literally sitting here eating this right now. I only made a few modifications based on all of the reviews I was reading. 
1. I diced mushrooms (because I had a handful left needing a home) and sauteed them along with the onions in a little butter before adding to the meat mixture. 
2. I doubled the topping sauce while cutting back slightly on the mustard. 

It is delicious and moist! this is my new Go-To meatloaf! I served with steak fries as a compromise with my kids for the mushrooms and onions they caught me adding.

text:
Variation that my super picky 4 yr old and toddler will actually eat is using 2.5 tablespoons of brown sugar rather than regular sugar, using only 1 tablespoon of mustard rather than the two called for, using a whole sleeve of whole wheat Ritz crackers rather than bread, and using only about 2/3 of a large egg rather than a whole one. I have made it about a dozen times sometimes with less mustard, sometimes with more sugar, sometimes with the amount of egg called for, and sometimes with more ketchup, but the variation above actually has my super picky 4 year old requesting meatlove and yes she really does call it that.

text:
Very easy prep and delicious meatloaf!! My family and I like a heartier meatloaf, so I reduced the onion, milk and bread crumbs to 1/3 cup each. We love the sauce so much I usually almost double it. When we eat the meatloaf, we spread the leftover sauce on the rest of our slice, yum! I've substituted crushed corn flakes to make the meatloaf gluten free. It's delicious with or without gluten!

text:
This was a great recipe. I've always disliked meatloaf---Why I decided to make it the other night, I have no clue but this will now be a staple in our house. I read several of the reviews before preparing and I decided to add a 1/2lb of hot pork sausage with the 1lb of beef- great decision there & I added 1 tbs of Worcestershire to the meat mixture and a few dashes to the sauce on top. I also used  grey poupon as my mustard. This was delicious. I paired it with some mashed potatoes, a balsamic green beans. I have over 1/2 a pan of left overs and it's been a great lunch these past few days. I definitely recommend this.

None
text:
As is, I give this recipe 3 stars.

Now, to make it a 5 star dish: Throw in some Worcestershire sauce (to taste) in the meat mixture. I also use Italian bread crumbs instead of the plain and trade out the reg. mustard with Dijon or brown. Line the pan with bacon grease before baking and your taste buds will be in heaven with each bite. The meat comes out so juicy and delicious! The great thing about meatloaf is you can really play with the ingredients to your liking. Sometimes I'll add some frozen corn or green bell peppers to give a little more texture and flavor.

Display Name:
Katie Travis Johnson
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4881068.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this meatloaf; this is my go-to recipe. I only make two changes: Because I'm a ketchup lover, I double the amount of ketchup mixture and stir half into the mixture of beef, milk, and breadcrumbs. I also use onion powder instead of fresh onion because it isn't as overpowering (also, I don't care for the texture of onions in meatloaf, whether or not they're sauteed ). The meatloaf turns out beautifully, but doesn't hold together well once sliced. This doesn't bother me, but if you like a firmer meatloaf, I would reduce the amount of breadcrumbs to 3/4 cup or 1/2 cup, depending on desired firmness.

So moist and soft inside and the outer layer had the perfect firm but not hard as burnt bread texture. I've always had problems with getting 'too bready' loaf, it would be too dry but this was awesome and so simple. I used reduced fat buttermilk instead of regular milk because i ran out of milk haha but it worked. I also used a half pound of ground pork and one pound of beef instead of doing a pound and a half of just beef just to give a subtle hint of that porky goodness.

text:
This was a pretty good recipe, but I made some minor changes too. I used 1 lb of ground chuck and 1 lb of ground Italian hot sausage. I omitted the bread crumbs (I hate bread crumbs added to meat dishes).  As others posted, I  used more ketchup, less brown sugar,  instead of prepared mustard, I used a pinch of ground mustard, and a dash of worcestershire sauce for the topping. I formed the meatloaf in a 9×13 baking dish, as others suggested, covered with aluminum foil, and the last few minutes baked it uncovered.

text:
This recipe was amazing! I, too, made some substitutions. Instead of an actual onion, I used Lipton Beefy Onion soup mix (both packages in the box). Instead of yellow mustard, I used Walmart’s “Stone Ground Mustard”. For the breadcrumbs, I used crushed Ritz crackers (one whole sleeve makes about a cup as it turns out!). It might not be necessary, but about halfway through the cook time, I make a few small slices in the meatloaf to ensure heat gets to the middle. I have never had a problem with losing moisture this way, and I have comfort that I haven’t undercooked something.

text:
I absolutely love this recipe! I make this one just the way it is for the fussy eaters (those people that won't anything green) For  everyone else, I added 2 tbsp of the Worcestershire sauce, I added garlic and green pepper and sauteed it  in butter with the onion just as the other commentators suggested.  I don't make the ketchup topping because it's too sweet. It was so sweet that everyone scrapped it off and threw it out. Really, using this basic recipe, you can tweak it anyway you want.  Also, using Italian style bread crumbs did make the meatloaf tastier.

userID:
2422491
Display Name:
johsplenda
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
9
favoritesCount:
51
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this a little more weight helpful.  I use 86% lean ground beef & use 1 lb beef & 1/2 lb turkey - this reduces amount of grease.  Adjust to your liking.  I use Splenda Blend brown sugar for topping, 2% milk or even 1/4 cup fat free half & half, and a little less than 1/2 cup 2% milk (probably about 1/3 cup).  I reduced bread crumbs to about 1/3 cup and mixed in about 1/3 cup of oatmeal with bread crumbs.  Chop onions small.  Adjust milk & bread crumbs to make the loaf manageable -  make first time by recipe and then adjust to your liking the next time.  I usually add just a sprinkle of garlic powder & a couple of drops of Lea & Perrin and a few drops of Soy Sauce.  I have gotten rave reviews and requests from family and friends on this meatloaf.  This meatloaf fits my stoneware loaf pan perfectly.

5

text:
I will definitely make this again. I made changes to the recipe: (1) 2 lb of ground check instead of ground beef, (2) added 2 tbs worchestershire (since I doubled the recipe), (3) 2 cups of Italian bread crumbs (since I doubled the recipe, and doubled the milk, and used 2 eggs, too), (3) sauteed the 1 large white onion, (4) only put 2bs of mustard seasoning for a doubled recipe. I did not read the directions, so everything was mixed into the meat (except the brown sugar). I only did ketchup for topping, which I put on the meat 10-15 minutes after being in the oven. It turned out AMAZING! My family, which includes picky eaters, loved this recipe (even though I made changes and screwed up directions).

text:
While the ingredient list is simple enough, this recipe is always inconsistent for whatever reason. I've made this exact recipe a dozen times, following the few short instructions on it and cooked each one in the same stove. I've had some come out completely burnt. Others took, and this isn't an exaggeration, 3 hours in the stove and the last hour on 400 degrees. After 3 hours in the oven with the last hour being at 400 degree the entire top of the loaf was raw meat. I did all the tricks and tips to more evenly cook food and nothing worked. I won't be using this recipe again that's for sure.

This was my first meatloaf and it turned out delicious.  Being my first I have nothing to compare this recipe to and I probably won't.  This worked out great! text:
Excellent meatloaf! I followed suggestions in comments and added a tablespoon of Worcestershire sause and replaced milk with tomato sauce and sauteed half of the onions to give the meat more flavor. Before adding sauteed onions I pulsed everything  in my Cuisineart food processor to get rid of grainy ground beef texture - the result was a nice smooth texture. The glaze is really good too. It was very easy to make and my family "destroyed" it all in one sitting.

text:
I just made this last night and it was delicious! Because I only made it for two people, I used just one pound of meat instead of the pound and a half that the recipe calls for. I didn't sauté my onions like other reviewers suggested for the simple fact that I didn't want to wash a skillet. I just chopped them up finely and they were fine. I only added 1/3 cup seasoned bread crumbs and 2/3 cup milk since I reduced the meat quantity. Oh, only change I really made was instead of adding the salt and pepper, I just used one package of Hidden Valley salad dressing and season mix. This meatloaf was so moist and delicious. The glaze on top really adds a delicious flavor. Served it with some sweet corn and seasoned potato wedges. My husband loved it!

text:
This was great and I don't even like meatloaf ;) I took the advice of other reviewers and sautéed the onion in butter because I'm not a huge fan of crunchy onions in my food. Next time I will probably grate the onions before sautéing them because I have picky eaters and the finer the veggies, the less complaints! I saw a lot of reviews that suggested doubling the sauce, which I did, but found the meatloaf to be too sweet. So the next time I made the sauce as written and it was perfect!! Oh and I used 2 eggs and skipped the milk, only because I didn't quite have enough. Wonderful recipe!

text:
So I've never made a meatloaf before. I'm still slightly new to cooking certain foods and my boyfriend requested meatloaf for dinner. This recipe seemed easy enough to follow. So I put all the ingredients in a bowl, combined all together and put into a loaf. I didn't notice on the directions that it said to combine the ketchup, brown sugar and mustard for the topping. I accidentally put it right in! Lol. Well, it still came out good but kinda mushy at the bottom. Will add more breadcrumbs next time. My way came out pretty good for my first meatloaf. For a topping I mixed about 1/3 cup ketchup with 2 tablespoons brown sugar, mixed together and spread on top. I also used 1lb ground beef and 1lb ground turkey instead of all beef. This recipe made me 2 loaf pans worth. Super good and easy.

text:
First time making meatloaf and it came out well! I used a pack of magic flake crackers (basically Asian buttery saltines) and supplemented the rest of 1 cup with chopped up french bread. Added copious seasonings (Italian seasoning, s&p, and garlic powder). Sautéed garlic, onion, and celery. Do not overwork the beef, mix in meat after all other fillings incorporated. I drained the meatloaf twice, at 45 mins and at end of 1 hr and 15 mins. A lot of liquid came out. At about 45 mins in the meatloaf shrunk quite a bit in length so I jammed baby carrots in the pockets, that was a good addition of veg. The glaze was delicious, I added a bit of hot sauce :)

text:
I made this because it sounded easy and it was.  Everyone loved it, and it was delicious and simple.  I followed some of the other suggestions about sautéing the onions in butter and did a few of my own: added some sautéed green peppers; used seasoned bread crumbs;  doubled the sauce amount; added Worcestershire sauce; and used Dijon mustard as that was all I had on hand.  It was perfect and simple.  I really loved it but my husband and mother raved and raved...we had leftovers (barely) and gobbled it up the next day.  Goes great with mashed potatoes!  So happy I found this recipe.  ENJOY!
Review:
Rating:
4

2017-03-20T12:35:01.25

country:
None
text:
I loved it! While the recipe is perfect by itself, I added some vietnamese chili garlic sauce; 2 table spoons. It adds a small kick that I like in my food. The sauce itself doesn't pack a high amount of heat, but it gives you all the attributes of adding garlic and some chili pepper.  Other than that, as my grandma used to do, I hardboil 3 eggs, peel them, and stick them inside the loaf before I bake it. 

Amazing, all together, but the recipe is perfect on itself. If you're feeling adventurous, try it my way - you won't be disappointed.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made this many times, as it is my go to for meat loaf. I tear up two slices of bread and add to it.  Also, I added1 T worcestershire  sauce., parsley flakes and garlic powder. My husband doesn't like cooked onion, so I add 1 T onion powder.   I used the seasoned bread crumbs(crushed ritz crackers are excellent to use instead of bread crumbs too). I triple the topping and add 1 packet of Splenda to it. We like it sweet. I also use EVAPORATED milk, much better than regular milk. I pat it into a 13x9x2 pan so it bakes the fastest.  I like to serve it with Tater Tots. All of my picky eaters LOVE IT.. Thanks to all of the cooks for the extra tips and additions.

city:

country:
None
text:
Loved it, this is now my go-to meatloaf recipe.  I added a dash of liquid smoke to the ketchup mix, which I think really helped, I recommend that.  Also, I know a lot of other commenters thought the instructions yielded too little sauce, but I think that's more a matter of personal taste.  I really wanted more of a glaze than a drenching, so if anything I'd probably cut down on the sauce next time.  Two other tips: first, this goes great with beef mushroom gravy.  Second, this was even better reheated in the microwave the day after, so make a little extra for your next day's lunch.

text:
Good recipe!  Easy and delicious.  I followed other reviewer's tips and added about a tbs of Worcestershire, and also sautéed the onion and 1 clove or pressed garlic in butter to soften it up.  I dumped that into the meat mixture and followed all of the other instructions.  I also added a bit of bacon because bacon always can be counted on to add a little extra goodness!  I didn't add much, just a little, already cooked but not too crispy.  To my delight my family LOVED it!  Even the sauce.  I served the meatloaf with green beans and mashed 'tatoes and gravy.  I will use this recipe again for sure.  :)

text:
Great recipe! I added about a half cup of sausage and even though I accidentally added the ketchup, mustard and brown sugar, meant for the top, to the meat mixture, oops!, It turned out great! When I realized what I did, I grabbed the ketchup and mustard back out of the fridge and mixed it with the brown sugar and poured the mixture on top, as per the recipe. This recipe filled 4 mini loaf pans, I cooked them for 40 minutes, until the internal temp was 160. Really good. It's a keeper!

text:
Apparently I don't know how to follow a recipe and this meatloaf turned out to be THE BEST DARN MEATLOAF I've ever eaten.
Instead of reading the directions, I simply added all the ingredients into a bowl. Yes, all of them.
I couldn't figure why it was so mushy.
Til I read the recipe fully.
I wasn't about to waste it so I cubed up some whole wheat bread (3 slices) and added it to the mix. That did the trick and the result was the most tender and delicious meatloaf. 
I will make this way from now on and be happy it turned out so well.

text:
Very simple, but very good recipe.  I either don't add the onions or I will add a dried onion soup packet to it. People I know don't like the fresh onions in their meatloaf. Something to do with the texture. Otherwise, fantastic go to recipe.  I did cut down on the sugar for the topping because the Ketchup has a lot of sugar to start with. Also...for something a little different...use a lasagna pan and flatten/spread it in a thin layer. So you can divide it up into squares after cooking to make sandwiches.

country:
None
text:
Excellent. I have to modify most recipes due to a variety of serious dietary issues and if it was excellent after my changes, then it would be as good or better without them! I had to make the following changes:
- 1/2C cooked quinoa in place of breadcrumbs/eggs
- no eggs
- unsweetened almond milk instead of cow milk, and only about 1/4C since there were no breadcrumbs for absorption.
- Dijon mustard in place of prepared mustard (it's all I had on hand)
- coconut sugar in place of brown sugar.

This was the best meatloaf that I've ever made - even my husband liked it more than usual.

text:
I am the type of person who makes her meatloaf by the everything-but-the-kitchen-sink method, meaning I use whatever I have on hand and dump it in. I have never used milk in my meatloaf for the liquid (preferring ketchup, steak sauce, wine or beer), but I like it in this recipe. I took the advice of other reviewers and sautéed the onions (adding minced garlic) and included Worcestershire sauce. I also used panko crumbs. I thought it was very good, but my family didn't like it as well as my regular never-the-same-way-twice meatloaf.

text:
I used the fattier 73/27 beef, left out the milk, used italian breadcrumbs and added 2 teaspoons of mustard in with the meat mixture. I also added 1 teaspoon of garlic powder, sauted the onions in butter and put a single layer of maple bacon over the top before adding the sauce. I left it on an extra 5-10 minutes. It came out perfect; sweet but not too sweet and the aroma swept through the whole house. Probably the best meatloaf I've ever made. The only other thing is my roommate suggested to add jalapeños next time to add a little kick.

text:
This is a very good meatloaf recipe.  I love how moist and juicy it stays after cooking.  Nothing dried out about this meatloaf. I did follow some of the changes that others talked about.  I used 2 lbs of ground turkey along with doubling the ketchup mixture. I added maybe 1/2 cup more bread crumbs.  I just toasted some bread and cubed it . I also cooked it for another 20 min or so. I have another recipe that I have used for years but wanted to try this one because of the many reviews.  I'm glad I did. I'm sure that any meatloaf lovers out there would love this version.

This was yummy.  I used 2.25 pounds of 93% lean meat.  I followed the ideas for the Worcester sauce, and the  butter sauteed onions and garlic. text:
Holy moly this was better than the band. Always loved meatloaf, first time maker. Would've given it 5 stars however as others have mentioned, the alterations required become a separate recipe altogether. This is a fantastic base. 

I doubled the topping and added Bullseye BBQ (eyeballed and tasted)
...I used Ritz buttery crackers instead of breadcrumbs 
...Skipped the milk...Added a tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce...
Added fresh parsley and green onion...
Added cumin, chili powder, garlic powder, oregano, basil and a garlic salt seasoning (two pinches each) ...Served with balsamic veggies. Covered in foil for 1h10m at 350. Make sure you let it cool a bit before slicing - I was so hungry and it crumbled a tad. Destroyed it anyway! Yum.

I've made this multiple times.  It's not the same as my mom's meatloaf recipe, but it's definitely become a family favorite.  Whenever I've made it for company, they too have thoroughly enjoyed it.  I, personally, don't make any changes to the recipe; however, I'm sure the added suggestions would turn out great.  In my opinion, the brown sugar mixture really makes this recipe. I made this for my husband and I but I thought the 1 cup of milk sounded like a lot of liquid and bland so I used only about a quarter cup of milk and about two tablespoons of steak sauce into the beef mixture with the onions, panko bread crumbs and the egg, with salt, pepper and   added some garlic powder to add some more flavor.  The sauce I made as in the recipe and this meatloaf came out very moist, very flavorful and maybe the best meatloaf I've made to date.  My husband just loved it!  I normally make a recipe as written before reviewing it but the one cup of milk and lack of spices made me question and make changes.  With the tweaks I would give it a five and more.

text:
omg!!!!  this was my first try making meatloaf, and this one is DA BOMB!!! and sooo easy to make!  Whoever said it wasn't good...your taste buds are dead!  I used 1 lb 90/10 sirloin and .8 lb 94/6 ground chuck.  There wasn't much grease.. only lots of flavor!  I used italian style bread crumbs, added green bell pepper and cut the mustard in half.  i sauted the green pepper, onion and some garlic in a bit of butter before mixing it in.  added just a bit of ws sauce also.  it was perfect.  any more mustard might have made the flavor too pronounced.  i think i might make more of the ketchup mixture next time.  definitely recommend this recipe.  it's delicious and you can adjust it to your tastes.  thanks allrecipe!!

This recipe was delicious!!!! I usually make my meatloaf with crackers and tomato sauce so I was skeptical about using milk and losing the texture of my crackers. But I took everyone's advice and added a little worsteshire sauce and sautéed my onions in garlic and butter. I did add my own twist though-- I cooked my onions down then added about half a pound of bacon and just cooked it for a few, for sure was still raw, and added it in my mixture. The best meatloaf I've ever made! Hubby ate so much we are both kicked back on the couch lol
I should also mention I didn't mess with the glaze. Good old fashion ketchup

text:
This was AMAZINGI  I didn't have bread crumbs so I was going for a slice or 2 of loaf bread when I saw the "bread crumbs or CRACKERS" in the ingredient list. I had about a 1/4 bag of cheezit crackers left  and decided to give it a try. I also added a tablespoon of minced garlic (jar) and 2 eggs, but cut the milk to half a cup. One cup of milk seemed way too much. A large whole onion was right on, even though I thought it would be too much. I did use the recommended 1 and 1/2 pounds of meat and added a tablespoon each of salt and pepper. I did not saute the onion, I just threw it in raw,  because it was easiest. I followed the directions on the topping and wouldn't really change it, I don't think.  It was a little "spicy" with 2 tbsp of prepared mustard so I might cut it next time to 1 tbsp. This was truly a great meatloaf - and, I have NEVER made good meatloaf, even when using a recipe. This was juicy and scrumptious.  It's a keeper for sure! And really easy. You cant go wrong with this recipe!  LOVE LOVE LOVE it.

text:
The changes I made were: 1. Softened 1 onion and 2 cloves of fresh Garlic in a pan with a bit of Oil before adding it to the meat. 2. Added 2 Table Spoons of Worcestershire Sauce. 3. Used flavored Bread Crumbs 4. I didn't have any Milk so I didn't put that it. For the sauce I used 3 Table Spoons of Brown Sugar, I doubled the Ketchup and 1 Table Spoons of Mustard. I cooked it at 375 for an hour  without the sauce, then pulled it out added the sauce. Cooked it for another 20 min. It came out great!

text:
I used 1lb ground Hamburg, didn't have an onion, so I used 1 tbsp onion powder. I used like a tiny dollop of minced garlic, sprinkled a bunch of salt & tiny bit of pepper (can't "season to taste" with raw meat...). Used 1 tbsp mustard, 4 tbsp light brown sugar, 1 tbsp dark, 1 cup ketchup (Hunt's all natural, prefer Heinz then 2nd choice is French's but hunts was the cheapest). Didn't have a loaf pan, so did my best to form it. 
Hubby says it's FANTASTIC! (He's usually pretty critical of my cooking). Said it was cooked perfectly, not over or under. Only suggestion was that his mom would make a layer in the middle of the ketchup sauce instead of just on top, so next time maybe do that middle layer of ketchup stuff.

I actually screwed this up, I was in a rush and added everything to the meat instead of making the sauce to pour over. You know what? It was delicious anyway. Also I added 2 tablespoons of soy sauce to it as well.  I needed another 15 minutes to cook it through and then broiled it to get a nice caramelized top. On it's own it was tender and tasty. 

Then I had an idea...

I made wine braised short ribs a few days ago and had lots of sauce left over, which would be a shame to waste. So, I mixed with the drippings from the meatloaf and used it as gravy over it and mashed potatoes. Y U M.

text:
Based on a suggestion, I sautéed the onions (with some chopped garlic) before adding them to the meatloaf mix. I did use a mix of meat (pork, chicken, beef) and also added a bit of Worcestershire and liquid smoke. After I put the mustard, ketchup mix on, I added some breadcrumbs on the top. 

It did take longer than the hr to bake, about 1hr 20m.

This was much better than the meatloaf I used to make (which I loved as well) and it has become my new go to!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm almost famous around here for making undercooked meat loaves :) I wanted to find a recipe that I could not screw up and with all the positive reviews I thought I'd try this one.  I didn't even try without, I added the worcestershire to the meat and sauteed the onions first. I used alittle over 2 pounds of 90% lean meat, panko crumbs and 2% milk.  I ended up having to make a last minute dentist appointment for my son so instead of scrubbing the meatloaf in favor of take out I decided to put it all together earlier in the day and pop it in the fridge for 2-3 hours while we went to his appointment.  Came home and to be on the safe side I cooked it for 2 hours :) It was still moist and got really good reviews from my sons (hub was working). In that time the topping caramelized somewhat too and made a little bit of a crust. I should add that I have one of those healthy meatloaf pans where there is room for drainage at the bottom and you can just pick up the meatloaf out of the pan - I won't make this meatloaf again until I get another pan and I can double it  :) I think I may also make it the night before, foil the top and cook it next day instead of take out. I also oiled and spiced some small potatoes and put them in the oven at the same time. We like them well done so that was easy too :) Yay! :)

text:
I have used this recipe quite a few times now. I did however have to make a few changes after the first time making it to meet my families needs... first off with the brown sugar it is too sweet so I would recommend only half the sugar or most times I use bbq sauce instead. I add 1 TBS worstershire sauce and need to use 2 lbs ground beef. My kids HATE onions so I dice 1/2 onion and a stalk of celery..... in variation I use 1c shredded cheddar cheese in the middle (or mixed with the meat and diced mushrooms. For my husband sometimes i will add a can of diced tomatoes and chilies to the meat and 1tbs (or half if you don't like it spicy) of chili habanero sauce (or any hot sauce) to the topping. All these are delicious.

text:
This is very good and easy to make. I read  many of the reviews and the only thing I did different was add celery & 1/4 of a green pepper for moisture as some of you recommended. I put them in a food processor and processed into a chunky smooth consistency. It did come out very moist. I used seasoned bread crumbs. I cooked it for 1 hour, but the middle had a few pink spots, next time I will leave it in longer. I did not make the ketchup topping my family does not like ketchup.   I cooked it uncovered. Some have recommended 1tablespoon of Worcestershire sauce I will try that the next time I make this and their will be a next time. It still was very good without the topping.

text:
It was very good.  Followed recommendations in other reviews, primarily sautéing the onion w/some garlic and doubling up the sauce (w/reduced b/sugar & mustard).  Only thing I would be careful about is not "mounding" the meat mixture into a loaf shape in the pan since the shorter ends will be done before the middle is completely done.   This lead to the topping burning a bit.  I had to slice and finish off the middle part of the loaf in a sauté pan.  Still came out very good!  It's a keeper!!!

city:

country:
None
text:
I make this meatloaf regularly, around once a month. I double the whole recipe because we eat like it's a contest. In a double recipe, I caramelize one big onion with a big spoonful of garlic, some garlic salt, pepper, and thyme/oregano. The other onion, I keep raw and stir it into the hot onion pan to cool it off a little, since I mix the meat mixture by hand.
The only other addition i make to my double batch is a packet of Lipton golden onion soup mix. Just like that, we're gourmet!

This is my go-to meatloaf recipe.  It seemed weird to me to have a cup of milk, but it's really good.  I've added Worcestershire sauce, hot sauce, Lipton Beefy Onion soup mix and other sauces/spices and it always turns out really well.
I didn't like the mustard and brown sugar glaze (too sweet and too mustardy), so I use 2/3 ketchup to 1/3 Franks Red Hot sauce and top it with that.  Or skip it; it's still really good!

text:
I never make anything according to the recipe because rarely do I have all the ingredients on hand. I used 3 teaspoon  honey mustard instead of prepared mustard.  Used a little brown sugar and added a specialty mixture of Vidalia and orange marinade, make sure to use a chopper to make sure the Vidalia onion is finely chopped. I spread half the mixture at beginning of cooking, then 10 minutes prior to end, I  added the rest of topping with breaded onions.   I added a teaspoon of Italian seasoning to the breadcrumbs.   Turned out great, goes great with frozen peas and butter, and mashed potatoes.  Not your old fashioned meat loaf for sure....

userID:
16847460
Display Name:
Becky Drenth
isPro:
False
followersCount:
4
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
12
favoritesCount:
23
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/3399279.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
CHANGES:
1. Reduce the milk to 3/4 cup.
2. Add 1 cup of carrot: shredded, then chopped, and then lightly sauteed, to the meatloaf mix.
3. Lightly saute the chopped onion. 
4. May use parsnip or potato chips, crushed, for the bread crumbs, for a gluten free meatloaf. 
5. Use an extra egg.
6. Double the ketchup mixture. Or make it with some 'heat': 2/3 c ketchup, 3 T brown sugar, 1 T mustard, 1 tsp vinegar, 1 tsp hot sauce.  
7. Top the meatloaf with the sauce before baking the meatloaf. 
8. Bake meatloaf, uncovered, at 375-F, 1 hr 25 minutes, if you're baking potatoes at the same time. You may even bake the potatoes (and carrots) in the pan along side the meatloaf, roast-style, or you may bake the potatoes separately, but potatoes need 375-F or hotter to convert the starch.
9. Bake the meatloaf, uncovered, at 325-F, 2 1/2 hrs, if you have the time, for deeper flavor. 
10. LET the just-baked meatloaf REST 15 minutes before serving.
11. MAKE AHEAD TIPS: cover unbaked meatloaf after placing it in a sprayed loaf pan and refrigerate it. Next day, bake it.
OR bake it and then rest it to room temp. Cover and refrigerate it. Next day, bake it at 350-F for 25 minutes.
12. You may form this into a loaf (or double it and form it into loaves) and refrigerate it, then bake the meatloaf resting directly on a cooling rack that is placed in a sprayed, lipped cookie sheet. This is especially good if you want to make it for sandwiches. (Use a lipped cookie sheet that the cooling rack fits into,

text:
Wonderful!  Very moist and flavorful (with adjustments, substitutions, and add ins ).  I took the advice from other reviewers and used seasoned breadcrumbs, sautéed green bell pepper mushrooms and garlic with the onions.  For the sauce: I used one tbsp of mustard plus one tbsp of Worcestershire sauce instead of two tbsp of mustard and Heinz Sriracha ketchup instead of regular ketchup.  The heat from the sriracha tames and compliments the  brown sugar nicely.  I will definitely make this one again.

text:
I made the recipe and followed other reviewer's suggestions. I doubled the sauce mixture but reduced the amount of mustard ( perhaps bit more than half of what recipe asks for), added the tbsp of Worcestershire sauce, used seasoned bread crumbs. I went further and finely chopped up some carrots and mushrooms and sautéed them with the onions. The result was a tender and juicy meatloaf.  The key is to let the meatloaf rest after its out of the oven!

country:

text:
Doesn't  get any easier than this.( Followed recipe as suggested) I happen to Love it bc, it's a very flexible recipe to add too. I went with the 3 meats beef,veal and pork added Worcester sauce to taste with a teaspoon di jon mustard and ketchup( a bit less than recommended). ( mix separately ) Added garlic by the hand full (my preference )and Italian seasoning mix. With seasoned bread crumbs and bread and 2 eggs. 350 for just over an hr and then topped it off with the sauce for the last 10-15 mins at 400. Let sit for 5 to 10 mins and cut and enjoy. Serve with stringbeans on the pan with olive oil (just to coat pan) ,bread crumbs and pepper.(5 to 10 max mins)This is NOT a sweet recipe bc I rather bitter (for lack of a better word) I've cook this about 5 times now and it's a hit every time. (Or at least thats what they tell me to be nice) I hope that u enjoy this as much as I do...
Bon Appétit!

I wanted to share a slight alternative to this recipe.  Instead of using brown sugar, mustard and ketchup, use tomato paste on top.  Just leave out the brown sugar and mustard and when the meatloaf is cooked, before serving, spread tomato paste on top.  It's so good and the way my mom always made it.

None
text:
Wow!  Best meatloaf I have made in ages. I did make the following changes. 
1. I didn't have onion so I used onion powder. 
2. I used fresh minced garlic that you can buy in a jar. 
3. I added Worcester sauce to the meat mixture. 
4. I used Italian breads crumbs. 
5. Once the meat was shaped a applied a thin coat of tomato paste. 
6. I double the recipe for the sauce.  Did one less tsp of mustard and added apple cider vinegar to cut the sweetness and thin out the mixture. Added til I got the taste and consistency I wanted. 
7. Covered with foil to keep it moist. 
The whole family came back for seconds!

text:
I was in a hurry, and made this exactly as written.  My entire family loved it, even the picky eaters.  My only complaint was that I used 1.4 lbs of ground beef and it took 1.5 hours to cook!  I even turned up the oven to 375 at the 40 minute mark.  I cooked in a glass loaf pan.  Cooking time aside, this was a very tasty and very moist meatloaf.  The sauce was a great compliment, though next time I'll double the sauce to pour over it once sliced (the rest of my family thought it was perfect as is, I just like things a little saucy personally).  This one is a keeper and my entire family told me it was the best meatloaf I've ever made.  :)

text:
It was delicious! All was the same except I had 2 lbs hamburger so I added a couple tablespoons of tomato paste and went over cup of milk. I added tsp. Salt and 1/2 tsp. Pepper.

Here I am, over a year later, having made it again. I was in a big hurry so quickly read the ingredients and threw it all in, not even measuring properly except the cup of milk. Added extra ketchup as I didn't have an egg. Filled my little loaf pans and checked back for the topping. What a laugh I had! I had added the ketchup, (dijon) mustard and brown sugar in with the 2lbs burger! So I just put ketchup on top. Well, it was the most delicious I'd had!! We loved it! PS only had about 1/3 cup bread crumbs left so added in a handful of regular Quaker oats. Plus healthy dose Worcester sauce. Proves how meatloaf is so versatile. This is a great recipe, with or without subs and tweaks. I did NOT saute onions but chopped them small. Perfect!

text:
Made exactly according to recipe the first time for Mother's Day 2016.  Very moist, quite easy to concoct; parents thought it very tasty.  It traveled well the 15+ miles to their house and re-heated beautifully without drying out (oven on 250 degrees for the time it took to cook everything else; about 15 minutes.)  My mom suggested reducing the amount of milk just slightly so the loaf wasn't quite so "loose."  Adding worcestershire sounds good to me - wondering if it would be better in the sauce rather than the loaf to offset the sweetness.  Hmmm - something to think about next time.  I would make this again.

text:
This is a very basic recipe and I like a little more in my meatloaf so I upgraded a bit....
-Instead of 1.5 lbs. of beef I used 1 lb. of beef and 1 lb. of hot sausage
-I used Italian Bread crumbs
-For the mustard I used Spicy Brown Deli Mustard
-Like the other reviewers, I cooked my chopped onion in butter for a bit to soften it up
-I served this with Oven Roasted Red Potatoes and it was an amazing meal.
